\----------------------------------------------------------/


Cuba Criticizes Plan

December 30, 2001 

By REUTERS


 

HAVANA, Dec. 29 (Reuters) - Cuban officials objected today
to Washington's plans for housing Taliban and Al Qaeda
prisoners at the American Navy base at Guantanamo Bay. 

Cuba's attorney general, Juan Escalona, scoffed at the
plan, announced Thursday by Secretary of Defense Donald H.
Rumsfeld to bring detainees from the conflict in
Afghanistan half-way around the world to the base on Cuba's
southeast tip. 

"It's another provocation from the Americans," Mr. Escalona
said. "I hope 15 or 20 get out and kill them." 

While condemning the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States,
Havana has also opposed the bombardment of Afghanistan,
calling it barbaric.

http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/30/international/americas/30CUBA.html?ex=1010974163&ei=1&en=2eaefe0d89f0ea3b

Post ID:2494

Subject:Imperialism, Class Warfare & The National Elections: Nov2000
Message:

Imperialism, Class Warfare & The National Elections: Nov2000
- Amiri Baraka (published before the 2000 election)

IMPERIALISM & THE NATIONAL ELECTIONNS; CAUGHT BETWEEN A SERIAL
KILLER & A PROSTITUTE, OR BEAT BUSH (NIX NADER), DEMAND MORE FROM
GORE!

Gore and Bush conflict around the use of public moneys because Gore
represents bank and industrial capital and the superstructural
combination, that shapes US monopoly, but as a bulky associate of
world monopoly in its more "rational" as the present mode confirmed
by International Finance Capital) international mores and forms.
Gore would not take money out of the public coffers at the same rate
as Bush, because Gores economic ideological base profits from the
revenues in public institutions. Banks, Insurance Companies, Trusts,
Bureaucracy, Wall St, Money Managers, Trade Revenues.

Bush is Oil, Cheney Oil. Annexationist, more reactionary since they
ride the oil juggernaut which still propose an"independent" US
power, as the White Cowboy Savage of Free Western (hemispheric and
US factual mythology) Post European Christendom. Like the mad
general in Dr Strangelove, they want to ride the big bomb of oil as
the single back offense of an invincible, sanctified ground game.

Bush would take more public funds because the privatization he
projects is into the interests, which bulk big oil. The
international politics, ironically, would use Israel as long as the
oil is safe, like Olivier in Marathon Man, "Is it Safe?" But if Arab
political upsurge began to dominate, Bushites would, like the
British, after they gave permission through Rothchild for the
Zionists to take Palestine, switch their allegiance without a blink.
Do the American Jews realize this? The Zionists are determined this
will never happen, but by their action not their trust.

But the fact that Bush thinks the US is still in a position economically, 
politically, militarily, to be the independent Tarzan of the world, reflects 
a nostalgia Imperialism that is most vicious because it is outdated and the 
main economic institutions think is dangers. Otherwise, why would the NY 
Times, W Post, S Ledger, &c back Gore? Prosperity is here, don't mess with 
it, don't fix what don't need, &c. Although they do admire the massive 
appetite Bush projects, part of that belongs to the present associations and 
alliances of international finance capital. And they understand they are not 
Tarzan, anymore, even collectively, but more like Jungle Jim. At least put 
your clother on.
_______________________________________________________________________
NADER-GREEN PARTY EMERGE AS A SUBURBAN CHAUVINIST RIGHT WING LIBERAL 
PETTY-BOURGEOISIE & WAGE CLASS WARFARE AGAINST THE WORKING CLASS, OPPRESSED 
NATIONALITIES & WOMEN WITH "LEFT" PHRASEMONGERING & METAPHYSICAL 
"BOYCOTTISM"

Nader and the Greens are now revealed as not the Left but the Right social 
democrats or the Menshevik sub-alterns of vanished Liberalism,, rural(now 
suburban) petty bourgeoisie, with their "Left" phrase mongering when they 
admit (Nader Ad, NYTIMES, Oct26,00) a vote for Nader will accomplish nothing 
except "anti-establishment" hocus pocus "feelgoodism". They have not even 
the ingenuousness of the no and gleefully acknowledge it.

They use the romantic misunderstanding of Boycottism, in essence, by 
providing a Don Quixote quest with which to subtract votes from the only 
option existing that can BEAT BUSH. To say "there is no difference" between 
Bush 2 & Gore" is the phrase mongering of juvenile delinquent infantile 
"left" untruths, as unscientific as their politics, here rooted either in 
yahoo ignorance or the brooding demagoguery of the political swindler. 
Affirmative Action, Social Security, Health Care, Tax Cuts, Education, 
Confederate Flag, Legal Murder of the working class, women, gays, 
anti-immigration, non-stop privatization.

In a recent NY Times article (Oct31) Nader is quoted saying 1st, "he doesn't 
like the word "Liberal, he prefers "Progressive". Probably because it is 
more vague! He mentions as important aspects of his "platform" Opposing 
drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge....." He criticized Gore 
saying "he had done nothing to force auto makers to make cars more fuel 
efficient."

He then modifies his disingenuous description that there's no difference 
between Gore and Bush, saying, "there are few major differences"/ Saying 
that the worst thing about the two parties was the was they coxied up to the 
special interests and encouraged a concentration of power made all other 
distinctions meaningless. "I don't care if they different on everything 
else"

Of the Supreme Court, Nader continues his amazing petty-bourgeois solipsism 
and establishes his "radicalness" as merely the whimpers of the "loyal 
opposition, saying, re: Bush's Supreme Court appointments would overthrow 
Roe v Wade, making abortions illegal, "You cant really predict how Supreme 
Court justices will behave....". He tops this disgusting dismissal of 
practical politics by confirming that he has no understanding of Democratin 
Struggle and is objectively in opposition to the needs of Blacks, Latino's, 
Women, Gays, when he says of Roe v Wade, that if Bush did overthrow it, "it 
would just revert to the states". Apparently not understanding or not caring 
that one of the most consistent of Democratic struggle of the Afro American 
People, Immigrants, Women, &c is the fight against STATES RIGHTS Long used 
by Racists and Right Wing Politicians to oppose democracy!

This fig leaf of opportunism masquerading as militancy is torn away by the 
projected results of their dangerous vaudeville. But also, most graphically, 
by Nader, &c dismissal of the actuality of U.S. Imperialism, and the needs 
of the working class and oppressed peoples, instead he laughingly 
acknowledges that his "campaign" could elect Bush2 This is not serious to 
him and them, because such National Liberal Chauvinists actually have no 
real fundamental problens with Imperialism and National Oppression, except 
it could be more efficien and they should be able to get a big time job 
helping it to be that way, if those dumb guys only understood!

Both Nader, a consumer advocate, a militant decorator of imperialism 
desiring to paint its toe nails so it looks civilised, and The Greens, petty 
bourgeois largely white suburban political drop-outs. No longer with even 
the political relevance of the anti war movement, but those upgraded "flower 
children" of the 60's communes who now can sell us tea or hip soap or 
chaming ice cream, or become respectable professionals, (stale Yippies in 
suits) whose main gripe is WHAT? The Environment. Like the NJ Green 
Senatorial Candidate, Bruce Afran, who says he "would be proud" to 
contribute to rich Democrat Jon Corzine's defeat. (Even though Corzine's 
platform is more progressive and more relevant to the working class and 
oppressed nationalities.) This Greens Man's main platform plank: "SAVE THE 
WETLANDS!"

This performance by Nader and the Greens shd effectively identify them as, 
objectively, the right wing of the rural petty bourgeois. Those not involved 
with saving Animals, rush to save the wetlands. While the plight of the 
working class, entrenched now perilously in the cities, they undermine and 
oppose, with ingenuous rhetoric and self-glorification as "independent 
progressives". Both lies.

It is to be noted that this sector of the rightist liberal petty bourgeois 
suburban yuppies and buppies are the pioneer settler group the Bigs are 
sending into the urban centers, like Newark, Harlem to reclaim for their 
young middle management hopefuls.

In fact, in the same NYTimes article quoted above, we find out that even 
though Nader criticixed Gore for hving stodk in the huge Occidental Oil 
Corp,  NADER TOO, HOLDS STOCK IN OCCIDENTAL. He sanitizes this by saying, 
"The key is whether you fight the company you have money in".

Bush is even buying ads for Nader to defeat Gore. But where are the Black 
issues or working class issues in detail in Nader's campaign? Aside from the 
wooden Indian lady he says is his running mate (has anybody seen her?) what 
aspects of Nader's campaign have addressed the issues of the working class, 
farmers or oppressed nationalities?

Are the Maxine Waters, Donald Paynes, John Conyers, .....&c Congressional 
Black Caucus (as undependable as they are) to be undermined, particularly 
those holding or scheduled to become Chairpersons of mahor Congressional 
committees to support an aging Yippie? Nader and The Greens must be held 
responsible, along with the irresponsible, opportunists, or ignorant social 
democrats, as well as the various sub rational Trots, Anarchists deviants, 
and newly costume black supermilitants frenziedly pimping attention, if the 
oil savage Bush 2, get in.

IN EFFECT, THE NADER GREENS ARE WAGING CLASS WARFARE AGAINST THE WORKING 
CLASS AND DEMOCRATIC MASSES. As such, they are allies of the far right! Just 
as the Trots were when they undermined the Spanish Republic by opposing the 
Popular Front with a traitorous rhetoric a "Anti-Stalinist" leaders of an 
fantasy "Proletariat Revolution", dismissing the actual political reality 
that the Spanish republic was facing fascism and must use the Popular Front 
even to maintain the hollow democracy of a Bourgeois Republic.

As backward as Clinton, &c are, the right lurch of the used to be liberal 
democrats. They are the Border States, Tennessee and Arkansas. Gare and 
Lieberman, added to assure Jews they are with them even though they want to 
cool out the Middle East with some rosy settlement and redivision of 
profits. (Its My Money, yells oily Bush) ...Bush Cheney represent a backward 
still more backward step, at this point just before another mass upsurge can 
begin.

The fake boycottism of the NaderGreens, in any real practical form, should 
only be used when there is a mass political upsurge, the boycott meaning to 
prevent the reintroduction of a past reform as alternative to the upsurge. 
But at the low ebb of the movement, not to use what tools, such as electoral 
politics to reverse the retreat, is criminally irresponsible, the ignorance 
of a brainless mouth, or the evil self possessed immorality of a "Bad Seed".

Between A SERIAL KILLER AND A PROSTITUTE is how the presidential election 
can be shown in metaphor. So the genuine Left, because it has not yet 
created a viable Anti-Imperialist United Front and the electorally effective 
LEFT BLOC, Lenin spoke of ("March Seperately, Strike Together!") is 
bookended between the liquidationist Social Democrat based Nader Green 
suburban, petty bourgeois, white gangster rap and the battery run juvenile 
delinquent infantile leftism & political swindling of the 
trot-anarchist-super-black minstrel militants. Just as it was after the 
defeat of the 1905 revolution in Russia. Gleeing Intellectuals, Ex anti 
imperialist petty bourgeois up-graded by bribes, disillusioned used to be 
militants reconfigured as Preachers, newly moderate teachers, costumed 
whores, traitors who are now negotiators for imperialism, various God 
Builders and nostalgic husks explaining why they are on the other side...now 
that they realize how the doo doo.
Woiks.

Against all this we say, once more, REVOLUTIONARIES UNITE WITH THE WORKERS 
OF ALL NATIONALITIES, FARMERS, OPPRESSED PEOPLES AND DEMOCRATIC MIDDLE 
FORCES, IN A UNITED FRONT AGAINST IMPERIALISM AND NATIONAL OPPRESSION.

UNITE THE MANY TO DEFEAT THE FEW!! And for those of us still claiming 
Marxism Leninism, Mao Tse Tsung Though, Let us unite around the 
revolutionary practice and theory of these great teachers and begin now more 
earnestly and scientifically to LEAD THE REVOLUTIONARY COUNTER ATTACK! 
TOWARD U.S. PEOPLES DEMOCRACY AND SOCIALISM!

_________________________________________________________________

After Black Teenager Is Slain, Norway Peers Into a Mirror

January 3, 2002 

By ALAN COWELL


The case of Benjamin Hermansen, a 15-year-old
African-Norwegian boy who was killed by neo-Nazis, has
offered a disturbing challenge to Norway's vision of
itself.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/03/international/europe/03NORW.html?ex=1011084440&ei=1&en=bfa977593795bbfd

Post ID:2497
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-04 11:41:30
Subject:Three Kings in the Bronx!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign wishes everyone a Happy Three Kings Day and 
hopes that folks will support this wonderful yearly activity.
______________________________________________________________________


CONTACT:  EDWIN PAGAN

DECEMBER 2001

Cell & Voice Mail: 917-653-2273 / 212-475-9184




THREE KINGS TO SHARE THEIR WISDOM AND CULTURAL GIFTS WITH

PAX AND HOSTOS AS PART OF THE 11TH ANNUAL CELEBRATION IN THE BRONX


PAX Theatre Community (PAX), in association with the Hostos Center for the

Arts & Culture, will present its 11th Annual Three Kings Celebration &

Cultural Exchange on Saturday, January 5, 2002 at the state-of-the-art

Hostos Center for the Arts & Culture.  Now proclaimed the "official" event

of its kind in Bronx County, PAX's annual festivity takes as its

point-of-departure the traditional Puerto Rican elements of D�a de los Reyes

(the day of kings; Epiphany), and combines them with PAX's standing

philosophy of cross-cultural sharing and Latino identity reinforcement.


Each year, PAX brings together a host of performance groups and artists

whose missions are the preservation and presentation of their country's

cultural treasures in a unified forum to be shared by all.  The 2002 Three

Kings Cultural Exchange Concert (7:00-10:30 PM) will feature: Trio New York

(Puerto Rico), La Cura Band (Dominican Republic), Mariachi Bustamante

(M�xico), and Agua Clara (Bolivia/Per�). PAX Theatre Community is currently

spearheading a campaign to have January 6, (Epiphany) declared a legal

holiday in New York City.


The event will also feature an arts & crafts fair and sale in the

facilities' atrium from 4 PM - 8 PM., that will showcase hand-made items

created by artisans from Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, Cuba, Chile,

and Mexico.


"The hope of PAX Theatre Community is that the next Latino generation will

again discover their rich cultural traditions, while bringing a bit of the

old world here to both our pioneering abuelitos  (grandparents) and recent

immigrants," said Edwin Pag�n, PAX's executive director and the festival's

producer.  "We also believe that this kind of cultural exchange with our

Latin-American neighbors will continue to bring the Latino community closer

together by helping us better understand each other, and crossing over the

stereotypes and barriers that separate us. It also lets us present these

customs to a non-Latino audience in an un-diluted form from our own

perspective."


Adults $12; Students & Seniors $8; Children 10 and under $5.  Two-for-one

admission with Bronx Council on the Arts' Bronx Cultural Card. Tickets are

currently on sale at Hostos' box office located at 450 Grand Concourse

(148th & 149th Streets - The Bronx).  Additional information can be obtained

by calling Hostos' box office at 718-518-4455, or by going to

www.hostos.cuny.edu.



ABOUT THE THREE KINGS DAY CELEBRATION


Epiphany (Greek epiphaneia, "appearance"), feast celebrated on January 6 by

the Anglican, Eastern, and Roman Catholic churches. The feast originated,

and is still recognized in the Eastern Church, as the anniversary of the

baptism of Christ. In the Western churches, Epiphany commemorates

principally the revelation to the Gentiles of Jesus Christ as the Savior, as

portrayed by the coming of the Three Wise Men (Matthew 2:1-12). In both the

Eastern and Western churches the feast secondarily commemorates the marriage

at Cana (John 2:1-11), at which Christ performed his first miracle.

Epiphany, known to have been observed earlier than 194 AD, is older than

Christmas and has always been a festival of the highest rank. The eve of

Epiphany is called Twelfth Night, and the day itself is sometimes referred

to as Twelfth Day. In England, the sovereign commemorates the day by

offering gold, frankincense, and myrrh at the altar in the Chapel Royal, at

Saint James's Palace. In the Eastern church, at Epiphany, the holy water is

blessed, a ritual customarily taking place on Holy Saturday (the day before

Easter) in the Roman Catholic church.


ABOUT PAX THEATRE COMMUNITY


Mission:    PAX Theatre Community (PAX) is an arts and education

collaborative which produces and presents works that celebrate and promote

Latino(a) identity and voice the concerns of people in underserved New York

City communities through the performing, visual, literary and media arts.


PAX (Latin for peace) was formed in the summer of 1990 in the South Bronx in

order to establish a group of artists who could pool their creative

abilities in an effort to enhance the educational programs in the region --

a sort of "culturally" responsive minute(wo)men.


Since then, PAX has developed a series of theatrical workshops for both

adolescents and adults; the Latin-unification and cross-cultural initiative

Com�nUnidad (common-unity/community) under whose non-partisan banner this

campaign is running; Una Noche de Caf� Teatro , an evening of dinner theater

where emerging theater troupes can showcase their works-in-progress in a

night-long marathon session; and PAX Youth Ensemble (PYE), a youth

leadership  theater training program.  In 1997, PYE kicked-off their Young

Voices series, which brings together youth-at-risk from the South Bronx, El

Barrio, Washington Heights, and the Lower East Side to create

conscience-raising forums and presentations based on issues of relevant

concern to them and their peers. The Young Voices project received a

three-year grant from the Citizens Committee of New York through funding by

The Rockefeller Foundation due to its innovative approach of creating a

youth program that effectively uses theater to teach essential leadership

skills and self-sufficiency as a necessary part of the developmental

process.


PAX Theatre Community also produces the annual Three Kings Celebration &

Cultural Exchange series in the Bronx, now heading into its 11th year of

observance.  In 1999, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer issued an

executive chamber citation proclaiming PAX's event the "official" festivity

of its kind in the county.

Subject:Vieques Update
Message:

The proLibertad Freedom Campaign is forwarding this meaage out in solidarity 
wih the struggle to free Vieques from the U.S. Navy's tyranny.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.proLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________

Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
P.O. Box 1424          Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel. (787) 741-0716   Fax (787) 741-0358  Email:  bieke@...

3 January, 2002

Press Release

Viequenses struggle every day for peace

According to the Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques (CRDV) 
the struggle  continues here every day, with or without bombing or 
maneuvers.  At the Peace and Justice Camp (PJC), headquarters of the CRDV 
located in front of the entrance to the Navy�s bombing zone, not a day goes 
by without activity in favor of the demilitarization of this island 
municipality.  �There is a continuous process of communication between our 
committee and the many support groups in Puerto Rico, as well as in other 
countries,� said Nilda Medina, member of the CRDV and principal leader of 
the PJC.  �From this office we coordinate with other Vieques groups and 
those from the main island, and we maintain contact with groups and 
individuals in solidarity with the Vieques cause from all around the world,� 
said Medina.

Members of the Vieques committee met yesterday at the PJC with lawyer Flavio 
Cumpiano, representative of the CRDV in Washington, DC, and with Federico de 
Jes�s, a young Puerto Rican pro Vieques activist, also residing in the 
federal capital.  They discussed the current situation and the implications 
of September 11th, among other topics.  Cumpiano emphasized the importance 
of the campaign directed by the CRDV to send letters to President Bush, to 
petition for an executive order for the immediate and permanent cessation of 
bombing.  �Bush is the Commander and Chief and has the constitutional 
authority necessary to stop the bombing on Vieques�, Cumpiano said.

In November and December, the Committee carried out regular activities in 
Vieques neighborhoods, handing out literature about the damages caused to 
the environment and health by Navy exercises, and to promote the next round 
of civil disobedience actions. The committee has collected and sent to the 
White House,  at this point, more than 1500 signatures on the petition to 
Bush calling for an end to the bombing.

Spokespersons for the community organization also announced that, while they 
prepare for Navy maneuvers planned for the end of January, thousands of feet 
of the fence separating the civilian sector from the Navy�s restricted zone 
have been dismantled.


To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
bieke_pr-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

Senate Democrats Plan to Subpoena Enron Papers

January 3, 2002 

By JOSEPH KAHN


Senate Democrats plan to subpoena documents from Enron
executives and to examine the company's high-level
connections to the Bush administration.

Subject:Support all Political Prisoners/POWs
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is forwarding this message out in 
solidarity WITH ALL POLITICAL PRISONERS/PRISONERS OF WAR and their 
respective support organizations.  We encourage people to write as many 
prisoners as you can and send them money for their commissary.  They need 
our support both monetarily and emotionally.  Please drop them a line and 
let them know that they are supported.

FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISSONERS!!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
____________________________________________________________________
On this day of Imani,  write to at least one political prisoner. This
is an
alphabetical list of political prisoners in the USA Compiled by the
Prison
Activist Resource Center.  The definition of political prisoner is
theirs.
Most are Black. Many  of these prisoners such as Mumia Abu Jamal and
Jamil
El Amin, aka H. Rap Brown are  Black prisoners of war.

1. Write them.
2. Send them Commisary money
3 Send money to their defense committees
4. Ask them what else they may want you to do.
5. Do what you can.
6. Get others to do the same
7. email us back to let us know what you did. We will publish what you
did in
the Cemotap Drum Newspaper in Black History Month.

Post ID:2501
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-06 23:02:40
Subject:Statements from Political Prisoners
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read and forward these 
statements out as far and wide as they can.  These are powerful statements 
from Political Prisoners Alvaro Luna Hernandez and Khalfani Malik Khaldun on 
the prison system and how individuals are treated behind the walls and 
fences.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Mahattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________
The following statements from Alvaro Luna Hernandez and Khalfani Malik
Khaldun were issued by the prisoners themselves as the American
Correctional Association's Winter conference in San Antonio, TX approaches.
The ACA is the prison industry's largest professional/trade association.
Organizers around the state are planning events in major cities around
Texas for the week of January 6, building to a convergence against prisons
the following weekend in San Antonio for the opening of the ACA conference.

For info on Alvaro:
www.freealvaro.org

For info on Khalfani:
www.prisonactivist.org/khalfani

****

For a new year of one, two, three, and many more Chiapas:
Solidarity Statement to Those Protesting the American Correctional
Association's Winter Conference

Texas prison officials boast of having one of the best, most
self-sufficient prison systems in the world -- facilities where prisoners
produce their food; raise chickens, swine and cattle; and maintain over 40
other prison industries, such as making clothing and garments, signs for
national highways, police bulletproof vests (the Hughes Unit, where I am
held captive, has a garment factory that produces such products for the
prison system and other free world agencies), canneries, soap, furniture
and the like. Of course, prisoners produce these goods without pay. Many
free world industries have thus moved inside prisons -- in effect, making
these places factories with fences, and America's private gulags.

Remember the "Easter Sunday" rebellion at Lucasville prison in Ohio on
April 11, 1993? Lucasville was an "accredited" prison under ACA guidelines.
The prisoner uprising was the end result of gross overcrowding, racist
practices against Muslim brothers, and other inhumanities against the
defenseless prisoner population. So much for ACA "accreditation."

The American Correctional Association designation is merely a facade, a
mask, to give national credibility to a prison system that continues to
trample over the human rights of its captive population. Despite federal
court decrees in favor of prisoners, the judiciary has its limits and will
never challenge the fundamental nature of prisons in a capitalist society.
Much like the armed, organized violence of the police, prison institutions
maintain brutal control over their subjects.

Despite many court-ordered "reform" victories we won in the celebrated
"Ruiz v. Estelle" (now "Ruiz v. Cockrell") decision in the areas of inmate
guards, overcrowding, staff brutality, access to the courts, medical care,
etc., those same problems continue to this very day.

For example, this unit, the Hughes Unit, is an "accredited" prison under
ACA guidelines. A walk through the main hall's corridors reveals the ACA
logo, no less. However, corruption, racism and brutality against prisoners
is widespread. I have been here close to a month and am already witnessing
such conditions.

Recently, an officer in charge of prisoner arts and crafts was terminated
after more than $3,000 in contract sales revenues came up missing. The
"investigation" is ongoing, but unless outside criminal prosecution is
initiated by the federal government, this internal probe is akin to the fox
being in charge of the chicken coop, charged with protecting the hens from
its own watering mouth and jaws. Prisoners continue to complain about their
stolen monies.

Staff assaults, described by Judge William Wayne Justice in his March 1,
1999 court order on the "Ruiz" case as indicative of a "culture of
violence," and evidence of ongoing use of excessive force against prisoners
is a fact of life at Hughes. The "Ruiz" case is pending a final decision
before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on this issue, and
on two others: conditions in administrative segregation and failure of
prison officials to protect prisoners from harm. A final decision may be
rendered by early 2002.

On the issue of medical care, the ACA was successful in politicking its way
out of a continued finding by Judge Justice for unconstitutional medical
care for prisoners. The ACA used its national political muscle to convince
the federal judge that the medical care system in Texas prisons, though not
up to par, was not "deliberately indifferent" -- sufficient to make it
unconstitutional under Eighth Amendment standards. We, the prisoners, have
reached the conclusion that the judge's decision was a matter of political
convenience of a federal judiciary ready to hand over the prison system
back to the state of Texas, despite years of official resistance to changes
and claims that attorneys of prisoners (Donna Brorby and Company out of San
Francisco) failed to present to the judge the complete picture as it
existed. These conclusions I have reached are based on special
investigative reports on medical care in Texas prisons done in December
2001 by the Austin American Statesman newspaper. The newspaper found
shocking results of the many unreported deaths of Texas prisonersdue to
inadequate medical care. See 
http://www.statesman.com/specialreports/prisons.

I and others, like brother Mumia Abu-Jamal, are serious threats to the
hegemony of elitist rule and the "corrections industry." We humanize the
over one-and-a-half million prisoners warehoused in America, and we work
diligently to expose the racist brutality, torture and other human rights
abuses. This exposure slows down the state's profiteering over these human
warehouses and slave labor camps for the continued misery of poor working
folks, as well as slows the economic livelihood and enrichment of locals
and their political hacks who do their bidding every legislative session.
We expose the utter hypocrisy and fallacy. We expose the true nature of the
capitalist, corporate democracy -- a paradise for the rich ruling class and
a murderous hell for the poor, the voiceless and the oppressed.

In the occupied territories of Aztlan, the Southwest United States,
incarceration rates for Raza have increased. White judiciaries are sending
first-time offenders more frequently to prison, and the racial composition
is increasingly Raza. This is a political plot, much like electoral
gerrymandering, for maintaining oppressive rule, where the white electorate
feels threatened by Raza population growth. We must look at these national
trends more closely.

History has demonstrated that it will take a concerted effort by the
prisoners themselves on the inside and a movement on the outside to bring
about respect for the rule of law, and for human rights protections for
those of us on the inside. We, as prisoners, have no political clout or
other lobbying tools to see that we are treated in a humane manner, or to
win freedom for those of us who are innocent of political charges. For
this, we need you on the outside. Your efforts are important, and these
actions to expose the American Correctional Association and the prison
system are not only necessary, but just and righteous. Keep up the fight.

Alvaro Luna Hernandez
#255735
Hughes Unit
Rt. 2, Box 4400
Gatesville, TX 76597

****

Unchecked Crimes Against the Confined:
An Open Statement in Support of All Protesters Against the Amerikan
Correctional Association's conference in Texas

For far too long, the blatant brutality and psychological warfare unleased
by prisoncrats in this country has gone unchecked -- from state and federal
prisons, to now special interests and privately owned prisons alike. These
prisons are administered by a host of monsters who regularly conceal the
viciousness behind the walls, as well as the victims, both male and female.

Like any conspirators, these officials collectively operate on a
three-pronged system -- see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil. After
reading Ernesto Aguilar's "Abuse and Profiteering Put Accreditation Under
Scrutiny," my mind was refreshed by the desire to further support and
encourage all actions launched to expose human rights violations in Texas
and elsewhere. False state-sanctioned accreditations are handed out as
violations continue to be exposed.

After spending nearly 16 years throughout Indiana's penal colony and being
on the frontlines of exposing racism and brutality, i am completely
convinced that, without your determination to stand up against these
injustices, these prisoncrats would try to murder us and even cover up the
facts in an effort to get away with it.

The Texas plantation prison colony symbolizes the racism of old South
slavemasters who never cared who they hurt, raped or killed. All that
mattered was the profit margin. And today money is the fuel that churns the
Texas death machine.

Being confined to a prison cell after being framed myself for the murder of
a prison guard, then literally hanged with a 60-year sentence, i am unable
to be there to stand side-by-side with you all. But my spirit is with you.
My heart is with you in this fight to destroy the prison reality and expose
what we can.

Comrades, it is very important to establish correspondence with many of the
prisoners housed in these units, to maintain factual updates on these
facilities. This will strengthen our overall effort.

i send a clenched-fist salutation and an embrace of the power of the people
to comrades in Houston, Austin, Dallas and San Antonio, and to the families
supporting loved ones behind the iron curtain.

The truth must be exposed!

Khalfani Malik Khaldun (fsn: Leonard McQuay)
#874304
Maximum Control Complex
P.O. Box 557
Westville, IN 46391



_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

Received: from unknown (216.115.97.167)  by m3.grp.snv.yahoo.com with QMQP; 
7 Jan 2002 04:02:41 -0000
Received: from unknown (HELO hotmail.com) (64.4.23.220)  by 
mta1.grp.snv.yahoo.com with SMTP; 7 Jan 2002 04:02:41 -0000
Received: from mail pickup service by hotmail.com with Microsoft SMTPSVC; 
Sun, 6 Jan 2002 20:02:40 -0800
Received: from 205.188.198.157 by lw15fd.law15.hotmail.msn.com with 
HTTP;Mon, 07 Jan 2002 04:02:40 GMT
From sentto-1569732-2341-1010376163-aunatural Sun, 06 Jan 2002 20:04:13 
-0800
X-eGroups-Return: 
sentto-1569732-2341-1010376163-aunatural=hotmail.com@...
X-Sender: uriyoan@...
X-Apparently-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
Message-ID: <F220oL2utJ4aLRm5gsH00018f2c@...>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 07 Jan 2002 04:02:40.0743 (UTC) 
FILETIME=[26C00F70:01C19730]
X-Yahoo-Profile: coquispirit
Mailing-List: list nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com; contact 
nbpeoplescampaign-owner@yahoogroups.com
Delivered-To: mailing list nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
Precedence: bulk
List-Unsubscribe: <mailto:nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com>

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read and forward these
statements out as far and wide as they can.  These are powerful statements
from Political Prisoners Alvaro Luna Hernandez and Khalfani Malik Khaldun on
the prison system and how individuals are treated behind the walls and
fences.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Mahattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________
The following statements from Alvaro Luna Hernandez and Khalfani Malik
Khaldun were issued by the prisoners themselves as the American
Correctional Association's Winter conference in San Antonio, TX approaches.
The ACA is the prison industry's largest professional/trade association.
Organizers around the state are planning events in major cities around
Texas for the week of January 6, building to a convergence against prisons
the following weekend in San Antonio for the opening of the ACA conference.

For info on Alvaro:
www.freealvaro.org

For info on Khalfani:
www.prisonactivist.org/khalfani

****

For a new year of one, two, three, and many more Chiapas:
Solidarity Statement to Those Protesting the American Correctional
Association's Winter Conference

Texas prison officials boast of having one of the best, most
self-sufficient prison systems in the world -- facilities where prisoners
produce their food; raise chickens, swine and cattle; and maintain over 40
other prison industries, such as making clothing and garments, signs for
national highways, police bulletproof vests (the Hughes Unit, where I am
held captive, has a garment factory that produces such products for the
prison system and other free world agencies), canneries, soap, furniture
and the like. Of course, prisoners produce these goods without pay. Many
free world industries have thus moved inside prisons -- in effect, making
these places factories with fences, and America's private gulags.

Remember the "Easter Sunday" rebellion at Lucasville prison in Ohio on
April 11, 1993? Lucasville was an "accredited" prison under ACA guidelines.
The prisoner uprising was the end result of gross overcrowding, racist
practices against Muslim brothers, and other inhumanities against the
defenseless prisoner population. So much for ACA "accreditation."

The American Correctional Association designation is merely a facade, a
mask, to give national credibility to a prison system that continues to
trample over the human rights of its captive population. Despite federal
court decrees in favor of prisoners, the judiciary has its limits and will
never challenge the fundamental nature of prisons in a capitalist society.
Much like the armed, organized violence of the police, prison institutions
maintain brutal control over their subjects.

Despite many court-ordered "reform" victories we won in the celebrated
"Ruiz v. Estelle" (now "Ruiz v. Cockrell") decision in the areas of inmate
guards, overcrowding, staff brutality, access to the courts, medical care,
etc., those same problems continue to this very day.

For example, this unit, the Hughes Unit, is an "accredited" prison under
ACA guidelines. A walk through the main hall's corridors reveals the ACA
logo, no less. However, corruption, racism and brutality against prisoners
is widespread. I have been here close to a month and am already witnessing
such conditions.

Recently, an officer in charge of prisoner arts and crafts was terminated
after more than $3,000 in contract sales revenues came up missing. The
"investigation" is ongoing, but unless outside criminal prosecution is
initiated by the federal government, this internal probe is akin to the fox
being in charge of the chicken coop, charged with protecting the hens from
its own watering mouth and jaws. Prisoners continue to complain about their
stolen monies.

Staff assaults, described by Judge William Wayne Justice in his March 1,
1999 court order on the "Ruiz" case as indicative of a "culture of
violence," and evidence of ongoing use of excessive force against prisoners
is a fact of life at Hughes. The "Ruiz" case is pending a final decision
before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on this issue, and
on two others: conditions in administrative segregation and failure of
prison officials to protect prisoners from harm. A final decision may be
rendered by early 2002.

On the issue of medical care, the ACA was successful in politicking its way
out of a continued finding by Judge Justice for unconstitutional medical
care for prisoners. The ACA used its national political muscle to convince
the federal judge that the medical care system in Texas prisons, though not
up to par, was not "deliberately indifferent" -- sufficient to make it
unconstitutional under Eighth Amendment standards. We, the prisoners, have
reached the conclusion that the judge's decision was a matter of political
convenience of a federal judiciary ready to hand over the prison system
back to the state of Texas, despite years of official resistance to changes
and claims that attorneys of prisoners (Donna Brorby and Company out of San
Francisco) failed to present to the judge the complete picture as it
existed. These conclusions I have reached are based on special
investigative reports on medical care in Texas prisons done in December
2001 by the Austin American Statesman newspaper. The newspaper found
shocking results of the many unreported deaths of Texas prisonersdue to
inadequate medical care. See
http://www.statesman.com/specialreports/prisons.

I and others, like brother Mumia Abu-Jamal, are serious threats to the
hegemony of elitist rule and the "corrections industry." We humanize the
over one-and-a-half million prisoners warehoused in America, and we work
diligently to expose the racist brutality, torture and other human rights
abuses. This exposure slows down the state's profiteering over these human
warehouses and slave labor camps for the continued misery of poor working
folks, as well as slows the economic livelihood and enrichment of locals
and their political hacks who do their bidding every legislative session.
We expose the utter hypocrisy and fallacy. We expose the true nature of the
capitalist, corporate democracy -- a paradise for the rich ruling class and
a murderous hell for the poor, the voiceless and the oppressed.

In the occupied territories of Aztlan, the Southwest United States,
incarceration rates for Raza have increased. White judiciaries are sending
first-time offenders more frequently to prison, and the racial composition
is increasingly Raza. This is a political plot, much like electoral
gerrymandering, for maintaining oppressive rule, where the white electorate
feels threatened by Raza population growth. We must look at these national
trends more closely.

History has demonstrated that it will take a concerted effort by the
prisoners themselves on the inside and a movement on the outside to bring
about respect for the rule of law, and for human rights protections for
those of us on the inside. We, as prisoners, have no political clout or
other lobbying tools to see that we are treated in a humane manner, or to
win freedom for those of us who are innocent of political charges. For
this, we need you on the outside. Your efforts are important, and these
actions to expose the American Correctional Association and the prison
system are not only necessary, but just and righteous. Keep up the fight.

Alvaro Luna Hernandez
#255735
Hughes Unit
Rt. 2, Box 4400
Gatesville, TX 76597

****

Unchecked Crimes Against the Confined:
An Open Statement in Support of All Protesters Against the Amerikan
Correctional Association's conference in Texas

For far too long, the blatant brutality and psychological warfare unleased
by prisoncrats in this country has gone unchecked -- from state and federal
prisons, to now special interests and privately owned prisons alike. These
prisons are administered by a host of monsters who regularly conceal the
viciousness behind the walls, as well as the victims, both male and female.

Like any conspirators, these officials collectively operate on a
three-pronged system -- see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil. After
reading Ernesto Aguilar's "Abuse and Profiteering Put Accreditation Under
Scrutiny," my mind was refreshed by the desire to further support and
encourage all actions launched to expose human rights violations in Texas
and elsewhere. False state-sanctioned accreditations are handed out as
violations continue to be exposed.

After spending nearly 16 years throughout Indiana's penal colony and being
on the frontlines of exposing racism and brutality, i am completely
convinced that, without your determination to stand up against these
injustices, these prisoncrats would try to murder us and even cover up the
facts in an effort to get away with it.

The Texas plantation prison colony symbolizes the racism of old South
slavemasters who never cared who they hurt, raped or killed. All that
mattered was the profit margin. And today money is the fuel that churns the
Texas death machine.

Being confined to a prison cell after being framed myself for the murder of
a prison guard, then literally hanged with a 60-year sentence, i am unable
to be there to stand side-by-side with you all. But my spirit is with you.
My heart is with you in this fight to destroy the prison reality and expose
what we can.

Comrades, it is very important to establish correspondence with many of the
prisoners housed in these units, to maintain factual updates on these
facilities. This will strengthen our overall effort.

i send a clenched-fist salutation and an embrace of the power of the people
to comrades in Houston, Austin, Dallas and San Antonio, and to the families
supporting loved ones behind the iron curtain.

The truth must be exposed!

Khalfani Malik Khaldun (fsn: Leonard McQuay)
#874304
Maximum Control Complex
P.O. Box 557
Westville, IN 46391



_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos:
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:2504
Sender:TRACYFORD1420@...
Post Date/Time:2002-01-07 15:14:58
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Statements from Political Prisoners
Message:

DEAR FRIEND,

HOW MANY PRISONERS DESERVE THEIR PUNISHMENT? 90% NEVER RECEIVED A TRAIL.
45% OF DEATH PENALTIES ARE REVERSED - OFTEN AFTER DECADES OF
IMPRISONMENT. NEARLY ALL PRISONERS LIVED IN POVERTY PRIOR TO
INCARCERATION. PRISONS OFFER NO PATH TOWARD EARNING A BETTER LIVING
LAWFULLY. IT'S A CRIME TO BE POOR IN AMERICA. WE NEED JOBS AT LIVING
WAGE FOR ALL WORKERS!

THANK YOU,
TRACY FORD





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:2506
Sender:TRACYFORD1420@...
Post Date/Time:2002-01-08 17:18:25
Subject:Re: Fwd: Re: [coalitionforjustice] Fwd: Re: [nbpc] Statements from Political Prisoners
Message:

DEAR FRIENDS,

VOLUNTEER SERVICE GROUPS, CHURCHES, PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATIONS AND
ASSOCIATIONS OF LOW-INCOME WORKERS ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO BUILD AN
AMERICA WHOSE ACCOMPLISHMENTS CAN BE MEASURED BY THE ACHIEVEMENTS OF OUR
LOWEST-INCOME  WORKERS. HELP US HELP OURSELVES ORGANIZERS ARE URGENTLY
NEEDED DON'T WAIT, DON'T HESITATE VOLUNTEER TODAY,AND EVERY DAY.

THANK YOU,
TRACY FORD

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2507
Sender:"joseph smith" <can_bush@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-09 14:48:03
Subject:booker announces slate
Message:

                     Booker enters ring with James

                     01/09/02

                     BY NIKITA STEWART
                     STAR-LEDGER STAFF

                     Calling for a "renaissance for the rest of us," Newark 
Central Ward Councilman Cory Booker announced his challenge to longtime 
Mayor Sharpe James yesterday at an outdoor rally.

                     His voice quavering from the bitter cold, Booker, 32, 
outlined his assessment of Newark's social ills -- from its ranking as one 
of the worst places to raise children to its murder rate.

                     "There's so much work to be done," he said. "Some of 
our leaders say we need no change. If there is a renaissance in Newark, then 
it's time for a renaissance for the rest of us."

                     The phrase, repeated often in his speech, drew cheers 
from a crowd that endured the chill to watch Booker speak from a stage in a 
parking lot on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard.

                     Television crews and magazine and newspaper reporters 
surrounded the stage yesterday to cover the start of a campaign that may be 
the city's most-watched since 1970, whenNewark elected its first black 
mayor, Kenneth Gibson.

                     James declared his candidacy for a record fifth term at 
his 65th birthday party and campaign fund-raiser last February. But 
yesterday the mayor had little to say about Booker or the May 14 nonpartisan 
election.

                     "I'm busy being mayor," James said. "I'm not 
politicking. I'm running the city of Newark at a crisis time in America 
where we have a budget problem, where we have a health problem, where we 
have a threat to our national and local security."

                     At yesterday's rally, Booker pointed to the city's 
health problems, poverty and unemployment rates and criticized James' 
combined $171,000 salary as mayor and state senator. "While residents are 
looking for jobs, Sharpe James has two," he said.

                     Some onlookers were distracted by the outbursts of 
Dwayne Smith, a mayoral candidate running under the banner of "New Newark 
Social Order." Wielding an oversized, orange plastic baseball bat, Smith 
promised to challenge both Booker and James. "I ain't singing. I'm swinging. 
Cory Booker who?" he asked.

                     But nationally, Booker is known.

                     The Newark election will follow a national trend of 
young, well-educated upstarts taking on longtime politicians to head major 
cities, said Al From, founder and chief executive of the Democratic 
Leadership Council, a national organization of moderate Democrats.

                     "In city after city, there are new mayors coming to the 
forefront to replace the old guard," From said, referring to Baltimore, 
Indianapolis, Detroit and Columbus, Ohio. "Cory is in the context of the 
young reform politicians."

                     Booker was a Rhodes Scholar who went to Stanford 
University on a football scholarship in 1987. James won his first election 
in 1970.

                     Newark politics, however, has often been immune to 
national trends.

                     "Newark may be an anomaly," From said. "Everybody tells 
me this is going to be a tight race."

                     It's not just about the old guard versus the new guard. 
James is the city's quintessential Newarker -- born in the South but raised 
with northern street-smarts and sensibilities. And he is the king of the 
city's political machine, never losing a race.

                     Booker is an outsider, growing up in Bergen County's 
Harrington Park and moving to Newark only in 1996. And he is an independent, 
narrowly winning his council seat in 1998.

                     The city's unofficial slogan -- "Brick City. We play 
tough here"-- is emblazoned on T-shirts sold by street vendors.

                     The slogan applies to politics as well.

                     In July, Booker and James ran into each other on an 
East Ward street, and the councilman tried to hug the mayor. James said he 
raised an elbow to fend off the hug, but witnesses said he pushed Booker.

                     Gibson, ousted by James in 1986, predicted a fierce 
fight months ago: "This election will probably be one of the most heated."

                     To compete with James' $1.7 million war chest of 
employee and Newark business contributions, Booker has raised money all over 
the country. He has collected $628,000 in contributions, including money 
from his former classmates at Stanford University, Oxford University and 
Yale Law School.

                     His detractors are already making an issue of the 
contributions since Booker proposed campaign finance reform legislation last 
month. Critics have mailed hundreds of anonymous letters throughout the city 
and state, questioning why a reformer would accept so many contributions.

                     In an earlier interview about the letters, Booker said 
his proposed reform is about preventing people who do business with the city 
from influencing city contracts with campaign funds. He said his stance 
might hurt him in future campaigns.

                     But for now, he'll take the money. "Sharpe James is not 
the only million-dollar man in town," Booker said.

                     James' unsuccessful opponents in past elections have 
never had the kind of money required to compete against him.

                     Political observers say it takes more than money to 
beat James.

                     "He's a very skillful politician," said James Garner, 
mayor of Hempstead, N.Y., and chairman of the advisory board of the U.S. 
Conference of Mayors.

                     James has overseen the city's development, helping to 
bring the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a minor league baseball stadium 
and -- potentially -- a sports complex for the New Jersey Nets and Devils to 
Newark.

                     New housing has popped up around the city, crime has 
decreased significantly and businesses such as IDT and MBNA are relocating 
to the state's largest city.

                     Booker attacked those accomplishments yesterday as 
catering to the downtown while neighborhoods suffer higher crime rates and 
get fewer services.

                     He also unveiled three members of his slate: Ronald 
Rice Jr., son of state Sen. Ronald Rice (D-Essex), for council at-large; 
Marjory Avant, an attorney and financial analyst, for at-large; and Dana 
Rone, president of the advisory school board, for the Central Ward seat.

                     James' slogan this year is "Experienced Leadership . . 
. Let's Continue the Progress."

                     As Booker listed the city's problems yesterday, he 
turned the mayor's slogan around and said, "This is not progress."

                     Staff writer Barry Carter contributed to this report. 
Nikita Stewart covers Newark City Hall. She can be reached by e-mail at 
nstewart@... or (973) 565-0155.

Enron Auditor Admits It Destroyed Documents

January 11, 2002 

By KURT EICHENWALD and FLOYD NORRIS


Arthur Andersen officials destroyed "a significant but
undetermined number" of documents relating to the company
and its finances, Enron's accounting firm disclosed.

Post ID:2511
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-14 15:20:25
Subject:[FRIENDSWBAINJ] VICTORY at WBAI & PACIFICA
Message:

Congradulations & and heartfelt gratitude to all those whose struggle & 
perseverance have brought back 99.5 WBAI to the airwaves as a 
revolutionary-democratic public institution!!

Waking up this morning to Amy Goodman & Democracy Now! was the first time in 
over a year that I've felt the weight of the far-right's retrogressive & 
fascist policies offset by not only the *hope* for better days, but the 
strength of knowledge and conviction that our collective action will 
ultimately bring qualitative and sweeping transformation when set on 
attainable and tangible goals.

Next stop: Ras Baraka for Newark City Council, May 2002

Matthew Smith
NewArkitecture@...

----Original Message Follows----
From: "ken nash" <knash@...>
To: "ken nash" <knash@...>
Subject: [FRIENDSWBAINJ] VICTORY at WBAI & PACIFICA
Date: Sun, 13 Jan 2002 20:41:16 -0500

iPNB agrees to fire Daughtry, rehire WBAI fired & banned; names Coughlin 
acting ED
January 13, 2002: With an invincible, better-than-two-thirds majority, and 
backed by a supportive audience of more than 500 listeners and activists, 
the reformers on the interim Pacifica National Board made a clean sweep of 
many of the serious issues affecting the network at its three-day meeting in 
New York.

Working methodically through a long agenda, the board:

o Adopted a committee report calling for the firing of WBAI general manager 
Bob Daughtry and the return of those fired and banned by the station since 
the Dec. 22, 2000 "Christmas coup." Daughtry will be replaced by Valerie Van 
Isler, who was removed as WBAI manager after the coup and fired when she 
resisted a transfer to Pacifica headquarters.

o Agreed to hire former Pacifica Network News Director Dan Coughlin, who was 
fired after allowing news of a nationwide affiliate boycott of Pacifica on 
the air and has been working with the Pacifica Campaign to unseat the 
previous board, as interim Executive Director.  Coughlin will serve until a 
permanent ED is chosen, a process that may take 60 days.

o Told the warring Houston Local Advisory Boards to merge and get into 
compliance with  Pacifica's bylaws.

o Agreed to fire the law firms of Williams and Connolly and Fulbright and 
Jaworski, which had been hired by the old board to fight the listener, LAB, 
and intraboard lawsuits.

The meeting was held Friday night, Saturday, and Sunday at the New York 
Hotel Trade Council headquarters in mid-Manhattan and was packed with 
interested listeners at every session.  Although rowdy, frequently 
applauding and hooting, the audience did not disrupt the completion of the 
long agenda.  They were given opportunities to speak to the board at several 
sessions scheduled throughout the meeting.

The new majority was assured of a free hand when only three representatives 
of the old majority showed up at the meeting. Wendell Johns resigned by fax 
before the meeting and Dick Gregory did not appear, leaving Marion Berry, 
Bert Lee and James Ferguson to carry the opposition.  It wasn't enough, 
since the nine former dissidents could always manage a two-thirds majority 
-- a requirement under the settlement of the lawsuits.

Berry suggested that the decisions might be challenged in court, a course 
that board member Carol Spooner, who sponsored the long listener lawsuit, 
invited him to take.  Berry presumably will not have access to the old 
Pacifica board law firms.

A previous attempt to fire the firms did not obtain a two-thirds majority 
and was rejected by Judge Ronald Sabraw, to whom it was referred.  The new 
ballot was taken after Spooner reported that all parties had signed off on 
the lawsuit settlement, including the judge; and that therefore there was no 
reason for the law firms to be retained.

The board did not agree, however, to move Pacifica headquarters back from 
Washington to Berkeley, even though Friends of Free Speech Radio offered a 
grant to cover relocation expenses. That motion failed, to the surprise of 
many long-time activists, who pointed out that the Foundation had been 
founded in Berkeley and resided there for 50 years. It had been moved in the 
dead of night by the former board majority and spirited away to Washington 
DC in an effort to escape from Bay Area listeners' protests. The board did 
agree to study the matter and consider it again later.

The board also heard reports from station managers Jim Bennett (KPFA), Mark 
Schubb (KPFK), Lew Hankins (WPFW), and Daughtry (WBAI).  Garland Ganter, the 
GM of KPFT (Houston) has resigned and no successor had been named to 
represent the station.

Schubb was strongly critical of the national board and complained that 
Pacifica was interfering with local programming while refusing to pay local 
bills.  KPFK, he said, has been broadcasting under reduced power because it 
cannot afford to replace its transmitter.

Each LAB also reported to the board; and Dave Adelson, representing the Los 
Angeles LAB, challenged Schubb�s report and said that KPFK was broadcasting 
a cart that falsely aligns the malpractice of the old PNB with the new iPNB.

Similarly, Sam Husseini, head of the WPFW LAB, challenged Hankins' report 
and called for the new board to fire him.

As executive secretary, Coughlin will have the power to hire and fire, a 
point that was specifically authorized by the board when it defeated Barry's 
motion to prevent firings without board approval.

However the firing of Daughtry was specifically ordered by the board in 
accepting the report of the special committee formed to investigate the WBAI 
management.  That committee recommended:

o Immediate removal of Daughtry.
o Immediate return of the fired of banned (since 12-22-00)
o Lifting all banning orders
o Requiring committee approval for hiring and firing at the station.
o Seeking a union solution that includes unpaid staff. Until then the last 
union agreement will be followed.
o Holding LAB meetings at the station.
o Working with the executive director to carry out the recommendations.

Defeating a move by Barry, the board agreed to accept the report in its 
entirety.
The issue of the PNN stringers' strike, originally on the agenda for Sunday, 
was tabled due to lack of time, but that several listeners and board members 
spoke of their strong commitment to return the striking stringers and their 
newscast, Free Speech Radio News, to Pacifica. The PNN strikers distributed 
a written statement to the board and audience.

The board also noted an announcement from Jim Bennett that Larry Bensky, 
fired from his position of National Affairs Correspondent by Lynn Chadwick, 
who has been working as a volunteer since KPFA got control of its airwaves, 
would be put on KPFA's paid staff.
The board voted to meet next in Los Angeles, from March 8-10.

[RETURN to savepacifica site]

Judge Fust� of the federal court in Puerto Rico, imposed the maximum 
sentence of six (6) months in federal prison on
Carlos "Taso" Zen�n, leader of the Fishermen's Association of
Vieques, for "trespassing" in order to prevent the U.S. Navy from
further bombing in Vieques. Judge Fust� also imposed the maximum sentence of 
six (6) months in federal prison on Zen�n's youngest son, 19-year old 
Yabureibo, for the same offense, a misdemeanor which usually carries a 
citation and US $25 fine.

DEAR FRIENDS,

 A LIE HAS BEEN PERPETRATED UPON THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THAT RESOURCES ARE
SCARCE. THEY ARE NOT. THERE IS PLENTY TO GO AROUND. OUR NATION IS BEING
PURPOSEFULLY MISMANAGED. WE NEED TO GET TO CHANGE COURSE.

WE MUST START WHERE THE NEEDS ARE GREATEST BECAUSE IF WE CAN GET THE
NEEDED RESOURCES THERE, WE CAN MOVE THEM ANYWHERE ELSE WITH GREATEST
EASE. WHEN THE LOWEST INCOME WORKERS HAVE DECENT PAY AND JOB SECURITY.
THERE IS NO LACK OF WORK TO DO!

YOU CAN PLAY AN ACTIVE PART IN CHANGING THE COURSE OF HISTORY BY
VOLUNTEERING YOUR TIME TO HELP THOSE LESS FORTUNATE HELP THEMSELVES BY

Post ID:2515
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2002-01-16 16:42:59
Subject:Nb Info, Devco
Message:

New Brunswick plan raises ethical concerns 

01/13/02

BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAR-LEDGER STAFF

The New Brunswick council is scheduled to vote this
week on whether to designate a blighted site at French
and Somerset streets -- owned by several prominent
city insiders -- as a "redevelopment area," a move
likely to drive up the property's value. 


It also has raised some eyebrows and ethical
questions. 


A partnership that includes Christopher Paladino,
George Zoffinger, Thomas Schrum and John Sisti owns
the triangular site near New Brunswick's border with
Franklin. 


Paladino is president of the New Brunswick Development
Corporation, or Devco, a nonprofit that engineers many
city redevelopment deals. Zoffinger is the chairman of
the corporation's board. 


Thomas Schrum is the brother of city Councilman Joseph
Schrum, who until last April had also been a partner.
He dropped out because of concerns that an ethical
conflict might emerge, he said. The men bought the
property for $450,000 in mid-September of 2000. 


A developer acting on behalf of the Magyar Savings
Bank, a downtown bank, has expressed interest in
buying the land from the partners for $990,000, so the
bank can move there. 


Magyar President Robert Pastor said the redevelopment
designation would make the site more attractive to the
bank. The designation would allow the bank to seek a
tax break and more easily bypass zoning restrictions,
among other benefits. 


With money fronted by Zoffinger, the partnership,
called Somerset Street Associates LLC, also spent
about $250,000 cleaning up environmental problems and
paying other expenses, Zoffinger said. 


Zoffinger, a banker, is the president and CEO of the
Constellation Capital Corp. He was state commerce
commissioner under Gov. Jim Florio, and is Gov-elect
James E. McGreevey's point man in working to save
union jobs at the Ford Motor Co. plant in Edison. 


In the last 25 years Devco has, by most accounts, done
an impressive job revitalizing New Brunswick with
large-scale downtown redevelopment projects. 


However, the agency has been criticized for not doing
much to improve outlying city neighborhoods, like the
one near Somerset and French streets. Critics also say
Devco's ability to operate out of public view leads to
mistrust of the corporation. 


One activist says that the fact that Zoffinger,
Paladino and the Schrums are doing real estate deals
together confirms their worst fears. 


"I think it's despicable," said Judy Mason. "I am of
the opinion that Zoffinger, along with other Devco
people and the city politicians, have the inside
information, and they're trying to profit from it." 


"Devco keeps their dealing and their finances and
everything they do very private," Mason continued.
"It's the city's way of keeping the public locked out
of the information we should have access to." 


The Schrums, Paladino and Sisti put up virtually no
money to get in on the deal. However, they all shared
the debt, the partners said. Zoffinger said he made
the partnership with the Schrums because Thomas Schrum
suggested the deal and managed the property. Joseph
Schrum, the councilman, said he shared those duties
with his brother until he backed out of the
partnership. 


Under the deal, Zoffinger and Paladino, as a pair,
would split the profits from the sale of the site
50-50 with Sisti and the two Schrums. 


Paladino and Zoffinger said they never asked for the
city to designate the property a redevelopment area,
and they do not think it would necessarily raise their
property's value. 


"I'll give you my word, I didn't know they were doing
this," Zoffinger said, referring to the city council's
action. "And secondly, I don't even care." 


Paladino and Zoffinger, who live in Montgomery and
have done real estate deals in and outside of Devco
for years, said there was nothing wrong with their
buying and selling real estate in New Brunswick as
long as they do not use inside information. 


However, the two men said that due to the public
perception that their private deals could be
unethical, they would sell all of their property in
the city and not buy any more as long as they worked
for Devco. 


"It's not good from a public relations standpoint, so
we won't do it," Paladino said. "Live and learn." 


Several business ethics experts said there was not
necessarily an ethical problem with Zoffinger and
Paladino making real estate transactions in New
Brunswick. 


"Their involvement with Devco shouldn't automatically
preclude their doing business in New Brunswick," said
Ed Hartman, a Rutgers University business ethics
professor. 


However, Hartman and other experts said the Devco
board should develop an ethics policy. The
organization has no such policy now. 


As part of an ethics policy, Devco's board should
disclose to the public any deals they or members of
their staff are privately conducting in New Brunswick,
several experts said. 


"The best thing to do is face these potential
conflicts of interest and try to deal with them head
on," said W. Michael Hoffman, director of the Center
for Business Ethics at Bentley College in
Massachusetts. "They should be absolutely transparent
about them to their constituency, and set up some
protocols as to how they plan to proceed to avoid any
kind of inappropriate or debilitating conflict of
interest." 


Zoffinger and Paladino said they twice told Devco's
board about the deal. Board members said the pair did
not appear to have inside information, and their deal
did not conflict with any Devco transactions. 


After the purchase of the property was made public,
Zoffinger directed the Devco staff to research ethics
policies for its board to consider, Paladino said.
When contacted, several board members showed little
interest in an ethics policy. 


"People have a right to invest their money how they
want to," said board member Alvin Rockoff, retired
president of a Woodbridge investment firm and former
chairman of the Rutgers Board of Governors. "If
someone wants to be a moralist let them go to church."



Rockoff said he owned no property in New Brunswick. 


Board member Aldrage Cooper, retired vice president of
corporate affairs at Johnson & Johnson, was equally
uninterested in Paladino and Zoffinger's deal or in an
ethics policy. "I have no concern. I've got more
important things on my mind," Cooper said. 


Board member Vito Nardelli, a senior vice president at
First Union Bank, did not return calls on the matter.
Board Vice Chair Robert Gamgort, vice president of
real estate for Johnson & Johnson, would not comment.
Nor would board member David Harris, executive
director of the Mae J. Strong Child Development Center
in New Brunswick. 


The only board member who endorsed an ethics policy
was Ira Novak, a partner at the Somerville law firm
Norris, McLaughlin & Marcus and the general counsel
for Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New
Brunswick. 


"Of course it's a good idea," Novak said. "How could
it not be a good idea?"

Post ID:2517
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-17 10:23:03
Subject:Dinner for New Afrikan Political Prisoners
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges all communities to make it out to 
this amazing activity on Sunday Jan. 20th, 2002.  Please support the 
families of African-American Political Prisoners.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________

Malcolm X Commemoration Committee
P.O. Box 340084
Jamaica, N.Y. 11434
Contact Person: Herman Ferguson (Chairman) 718-949-5153

MALCOLM X COMMEMORATION COMMITTEE PAYS TRIBUTE TO FAMILIES OF POLITICAL 
PRISONERS

7th Annual Dinner To Be Held at Restoration Plaza In Bed-Stuy Brooklyn
On January 20th

The Malcolm X Commemoration Committee is hosting its 7th annual dinner for 
the families of New Afrikan political prisoners and prisoners of war on 
January 20th at Restoration Plaza, 1368 Fulton Street (near New York Avenue) 
from 3p.m. to 8p.m.

The theme of this year's dinner will be  "Against All Odds: Resisting State 
Terrorism And Repression By Any Means Necessary!" This year's special guest 
speaker will be longtime activist and elder of the Black Liberation 
Movement, Brother Ed Brown, the older brother of Imam Jamil Abdullah 
Al-Amin, formerly known as H.Rap Brown, who is about to go on trial for his 
life in Atlanta, Georgia. Other presenters will include fire-spitting Black 
Liberation theologist Father Lawrence Lucas, and veteran people's poet and 
publisher, Louis Reyes Rivera of Shamel Books.

Other cultural events and the usual well-prepared dinner will be part of the 
activities. "We are again inviting our elected  Black officials to join us 
in this community-supported tribute and we are expecting all the recently 
elected new City Council members to be there to meet the families and to 
show their support for our struggle to free our pp/pows which is one of our 
central demands for Reparations." stated Jean Reynolds in a no-nonsense 
voice.
Jean is a founding member of the MXCC and a founding member of Malcolm
X's Muslim Mosque, Inc., and his Organization of Afro-American Unity.

Speakers this year have been chosen for their long involvement in the 
campaign to free political prisoners and their resolute concern about the 
parents and siblings of our heroic freedom fighters who have languished in 
dreary prison cells serving sentences that in many instances exceed three 
decades. "We are fortunate to have two speakers of the caliber of Father 
Lawrence Lucas and Brother Ed Brown for this year's program," exclaimed an 
obviously excited Terry Adams, who is heading the committee that is in 
charge of the event. "Father Lucas is the Catholic priest who serves as the 
chaplain at Riker's Island jail and he knows from the inside the pressures 
and problems that our brothers and sisters behind the wall have to put up 
with. He also knows first-hand about the terrible problems their relatives 
face everyday in trying to cope with the absence of their fathers, brothers, 
uncles, aunts, sisters and grandparents, who if we really look at it are 
also serving time out here," she ontinued. "It is important to drive home to 
the public that just as we have always done in the past, the proceeds of 
this moving evening of analysis, organization and people's culture will go 
into the commissary accounts of the political prisoners and prisoners of 
war, whose families live in the greater New York City area", explained 
Herman Ferguson, an elder in the movement and who is Chairman of the MXCC, 
"to provide them with necessities like soap, toothpaste, vitamins, 
toothbrushes, stamps, stationery, etc., that are not provided by the State 
Department of Correction," he lamented.
MXCC Press Officer Zayid Muhammad added, "We are going to place emphasis on 
the political prisoners who were put in solitary confinement following the 
World Trade Center bombing like Sundiata Acoli (who is still under severe 
restrictions), to the upcoming trial of Imam Al-Amin and, of course, to the 
latest developments in the case of Mumia Abu-Jamal.

The implications of the Homeland Security measures announced recently by the 
Bush
administration, the passage of the Patriotic Act of 2001, and how these acts 
will bring more grief and suffering to the Black community will be analyzed 
and explained by the speakers." Tickets for this event are $35 and will be 
available at the door. Or call:718-949-5153 for information or reservations

Post ID:2518
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-17 11:16:35
Subject:Fwd: joe, cliff smith arrested at board of ed mtg
Message:



----Original Message Follows----
From: "cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
To: cliffsmith69@...
Date: Thu, 17 Jan 2002 16:07:13 +0000



NEW BRUNSWICK: 2 charged in ed board fracas

               Published in the Home News Tribune 1/17/02

               By SHARON WATERS
               STAFF WRITER

               Misdemeanor charges have been filed against city activists 
Joe Smith and Cliff Smith for their confrontation with officials at Tuesday 
night's Board of Education meeting at New Brunswick High School.

               Joe Smith was charged with disrupting a lawful meeting and 
two counts of simple assault -- one for contact with high school Principal 
Pierre Embrey and the other for contact with Donald Bowling, chief of 
police-community relations, said police Lt. Thomas Selesky.  According to 
Bowling he was bit by Joe Smith who also allegedly scratched Embrey's neck.

               Cliff Smith was charged with disorderly conduct, Selesky 
said.

               At the meeting, the Smiths were distributing a flier stating 
the percentage of city students who passed standardized tests. Embrey asked 
the Smiths to leave, but the pair refused. As Bowling and two security-staff 
members held Joe Smith with Embrey nearby, a scuffle ensued during which 
Bowling was bit and Embrey scratched, according to Bowling.

               Joe Smith released a statement saying he and Cliff Smith were 
treated at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital and released. The Smiths 
plan to file assault charges against Embrey and the school security guards, 
the statement said.

               The Smiths said their arrests were an attempt to distract 
attention from the standardized-test scores, according to the statement.

               Sharon Waters: (732) 565-7270; e-mail swaters@...

               from the Home News Tribune

               Published: January 17, 2002

Post ID:2519
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-17 11:24:20
Subject:Fwd: 1st story, activists arrested at board of ed mtg
Message:



----Original Message Follows----
From: "cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
To: cliffsmith69@...
Date: Thu, 17 Jan 2002 16:08:17 +0000



               Two brothers arrested in school ruckus

               Published in the Home News Tribune 1/16/02

               By SHARON WATERS
               STAFF WRITER

               NEW BRUNSWICK: City activists Joe Smith and Cliff Smith were 
arrested after a confrontation with officials at last night's
Board of Education meeting.

               The brothers were distributing literature while the board was 
in closed session and were asked to leave by Principal Pierre Embrey, 
according to Donald Bowling, chief of police community relations.

               Cliff Smith refused to leave and "jumped" on Embrey, Bowling 
said. After high school security staff removed Cliff Smith, Joe Smith also 
refused to leave the building, said Bowling.

               Bowling and two security staff held Joe Smith with Embrey 
nearby and a scuffle ensued in which the activist fell to the ground and 
Bowling said he was bit by Joe Smith, who also scratched Embrey's neck.

               Joe Smith's phone was taken when it fell to the ground, 
Bowling said, and was turned over to police. The high school has received 
bomb threats and Joe Smith is a suspect, Bowling said.

               It was not known last night what charges were filed against 
the Smith brothers. As he was led away, Joe Smith said he wanted to file his 
own charges.

               Last month, Cliff Smith was found not guilty for a September 
2000 incident with Embrey. The principal, who declined to testify at trial, 
had charged that Cliff Smith assaulted and verbally abused him while the 
activist distributed literature at the high school.

               Sharon Waters: (732) 565-7270; e-mail swaters@...

               from the Home News Tribune

               Published: January 16, 2002

Date: Tue, 15 Jan 2002 02:36:19 +0000

New Brunswick Standardized Test Scores

11th grade High School Proficiency Test (HSPT) *req'd for graduation

		Passing
2000-2001: 51%
1999-2000: 56.5%
1998-1999: 74.5%

NJ state avg: 77.7%


8th grade proficiency assessment (GEPA) 2000-2001:

                Passing
Redshaw School: 32%
Roosevelt School: 41.5%
Paul Robeson School: 34.4%
McKinley School: 50%
Livingston School: 30.8%
Lincoln School: 60%

NJ state avg: 64.4%


4th grade elementary school proficiency assessment (ESPA) 2000-2001:

			Passing
Lincoln School: 12.1%
Livingston School: 68%
Lord Stirling School: 33.3%
McKinley School: 41.5%
Paul Robeson School: 27.5%
Redshaw School: 21.4%
Roosevelt School: 78.9%
Woodrow Wilson School: 62.5%

NJ state avg: 67.7%
