Post ID:2521
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-18 14:55:37
Subject:wise, why's y's
Message:


Introduction



Why's/Wise is a long poem in the tradition of the Djali(Griots) but this 
about African American (American) History.  It is also
like Tolson's "Liberia", WCW's "Paterson", Hughes' "Ask Yr Mama", Olson's 
"Maximus" in that it tries to tell the history/life
like an ongoing-offcoming Tale.



                                W I S E

                                 WHY'S

                                  Y's

by Amiri Baraka


                              Djeli Ya
                         (THE GRIOT'S  SONG)                                 
                          (1-40)

Each of these sections is accompanied by a piece of music.  The work is 
meant to be visualised by painters Vincent Smith and Tom Feelings.

Before "Wise I" there is a long improvisation, not yet completely 
transcribed.  It is called, in its entirety, PRE-HERE/ISTIC
Sequence: It is divided like this---

DAT--Africa                                    (Drums-R Walker)

DEUCE--Ghost (Snake Eyes)                      ("Space Spy"--Moncur)

TREY--My Brother the King                      (3/4 solos & Dun Dun)

Fo'--Railroad of African Bones (Box Cars)      (Under water African          
                                           Funeral Music)

Fi'--I Aint From Here                          (Wade In The Water,           
                                           Afro-Xtian Lament)

WHY'S Intro: NOBODY KNOWS THE TROUBLE I SEEN    Traditional
                                                 (Trombone Solo)

                               Wise 1

                                                   WHY's
                                                  ("Nobody Knows The
                                                   Trouble  I  Seen")
                                                   Trad.


If you ever find
yourself, some where
lost and surrounded
by enemies
who won't let you
speak in your own language
who destroy your statues
& instruments, who ban
your oom boom ba boom
then you are in trouble
deep trouble
they ban your
oom boom ba boom
you in deep deep
trouble

humph!

probably take you several hundred years
to get
out!



				Wise 2
						("Billie's Bounce")
						Charlie Parker

I was of people
caught in deep trouble
like I scribe you
some deep trouble, where
enemies had took us
surrounded us/ in they
country
then banned our
ommboom ba boom

the confusion
the sickness

	/What vision in the blackness
		of queens
		of kings
			/What vision in the blackness
		      that head
		      & heart
		      of yours

		that sweet verse
		you made, I still hear
		that song, son
		   of the son's son's son's
			son
			I still hear that
			song,
			that cry
			cries
			screams
		    life exploded

		    our world exploding us
		     transformed to niggers

What vision
in the blackness
your own hand sold you
"I am not a king or queen," your own hand
if you bee of the royal catch
or the tribes soulwarped by the ghoulishness

I still hear those songs and cries
of the sons and sons and daughters and daughters
I still bear that weeping in my heart
that bleeding in my memory

And I am not a king
nor trader in flesh
I was
of the sufferers
I am among those
to be avenged!









unite the many, defeat the few!





unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2522
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-18 15:19:51
Subject:wise 3,4,5
Message:

				Wise 3
							("Hipnosis")
							 Grachan Moncur III

Son singin
fount some
words/ Son
singin
in that other
language
talkin bout "bay
bee, why you
leave me
here," talkin bout
"up unner de sun
cotton in my hand."  Son
singin, think he bad
cause he
can speak
they language, talkin bout
"dark was the night
the ocean deep
white eyes cut through me
made me weep."

Son singin
fount some words.  Think
he bad.  Speak
they
language.

'sawright
I say

'sawright
wit me
look like
yeh, we gon be here
a taste.



				Wise 4
						("Dewey's Circle")
						 David Murray


No coat has I got
no extra chop
no soft bed or favor
no connection with the slaver

dark was the night
our eyes had not met
I fastened my life to me
and tried to find my way

talk did I hear
of fires and burning
and death to the gods

on the dirt where I slept
such talk
warmed me

such talk
lit my way

I has never got nothing but hard times and punishment
Any joy I had I made myself, and the dark woman
who took my hand and led me to myself

I has never got nothing
but a head full of blood
my scar, my missing teeth.

I has never got nothing but
killer frustration/ yes dark
was the night
cold was the ground

I has never got nothing, and talk
of rebellion
warmed me

Song to me, was the darkness
in which I could stand
my profile melted into the black air
red from the flame of the burning big house.

in those crazy dreams I called myself
Coltrane
bathed in a black and red fire
in those crazy moments I called myself
Thelonius
& this was in the 19th century!



				Wise 5
						("Breaks")
						 Baby Dodds

I overheard the other night
standing by the window
of the big house

a nigra say, through an alabaster
mask, "the first negro
was a white man."

slanty red darts angulate the darkness
my hands got cold, my head was sweaty

like a mystery
story
like a gospel
hymn
like the tales of the wizards
and the life of the gods

I did not know
who my father
was

I only barely
knew
my mother

But I knew something that night
about a negro
something even
the tv cant wash
away

I fount out something
about the negro

the wind may blow
the train don't dome
the mayor might belch
his mistress might gain weight

but I fount out something that night
about the Negro
& the world
got clear

you can hurray all you want to
you can kiss an elephant's ass

but I fount something
that night, before I slid
back to the field hands' quarters
I fount out something
about
the magic
of slavery

& I vowed not to be
a slave
no more.

Subject:Press Release on Vieques PPs
Message:

The ProLibertad sends this message out in solidarity with the forces that 
are trying to remove the U.S. Navy out of Vieques and the 
organizations/actions in support of the release of VIEQUES POLITICAL 
PRISONERS Carlos Zenon and his son Yabo Zenon!!

Look for local (New York/East Coast)action alerts from ProLibertad coming 
soon.

The ProLibertad FReedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
____________________________________________________________________
Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
P.O. Box 1424
Vieques, Puerto Rico  00765
Tel. 787  741-0716
Fax 787 741-0358
E mail:  bieke@...

16 January, 2002

Press Release

Viequenses denounce sentences for Zenon�s as abusive

The Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques (CRDV) denounced as 
excessive, abusive and violent, the six month sentences given yesterday to 
anti-military activists Carlos Zen�n and his son, Yabureibo.  Spokespersons 
for the Vieques organization suggested the sentence is part of a military 
strategy developed at the Navy base of Roosevelt Roads, in the town of 
Ceiba, Puerto Rico.  �We have no doubt that Admiral Green was consulted by 
Judge Fust� on this sentence,� said Nilda Medina, CRDV.  �The sentence can 
only be understood in the context of military plans to do away with the 
civil disobedience movement and thereby continue with their maneuvers in 
Vieques�, she concluded.

Members of the Committee affirmed their total support for the Zenon family, 
who have played a central role in the struggle during decades, and most 
particularly, after the death of  David Sanes in April of 1999, when they 
established the Monte David civil disobedience camp in the bombing zone.  
Yabureibo Zen�n, age eighteen, is part of the Vieques youth movement that 
has become very active in the struggle for peace here.  Carlos �Taso� Zen�n, 
has been active in the struggle against the Navy since the founding of the 
Vieques Fishermen�s Association at the end of the 1970�s.  In that period of 
the struggle, Zen�n and other fishermen blocked military maneuvers on 
several occasions, resulting in arrests and repression by federal marshalls, 
courts and jails.

The Committee urges people in solidarity to write to these most recent 
prisioners for peace on Vieques:

Carlos Zen�n                   # 23214-069
Yabureibo Zen�n             #23213-069

MDC Guaynabo, PO BOX 2147, San Juan, PR 00922-2147



Also write to:

Tito Kayak (Alberto De Jes�s Mercado, #19580-069
Sigan escribi�dole a la administraci�n carcelaria exigiendo su regreso a 
Puerto Rico.  (Keep writing to the jail authorities demanding his return to 
Puerto Rico)


Send letters to:

Gregory Park, Warden
Metropolitan Correctional Center - Manhattan
150 Park Row
New York, NY 10007

Subject:Jan. 25th and 31st Events!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all activists to attend and 
enjoy the following two activities in January.

The Welfare poets have been long time activists supporting all endeavors 
towards true freedom and justice.  For years, they worked with ProLibertad 
helping us get the message of freedom for the Puerto Rican political 
prisoners out to all communities.  Please support their efforts to raise 
money for their travel costs to Vieques.

The Latina/o Community Organizing Network has provided all communities with 
amazing forums and resources to improve and enhance all community organizing 
efforts.  Please attedn this forum and bring people with you.

The ProLIbertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244

______________________________________________________________________

The Latina/o Community Organizing Network/Red de Organizadores Comunitarios 
and The Center for Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College Invite you to a 
Free Symposium:

"The State of Organizing in Latino Communities Post Sept 11th: Challenges 
and Issues"�

Hear about how the tragedy of Sept 11th has affected other community 
practitioners 's work with Latino Communities New York City.  Learn about 
the Latina/o Community Organizing Network/Red de Organizadores Comunitarios� 
    Network among organizers, faculty, and students throughout CUNY and 
other institutions

Featured Speakers Include:
Richie Perez, National Congress for Puerto Rican Rights
Benjamin Ramos, The Latino Peace Coalition
Monica Santana, The Latino Workers Center

Thursday, January 31st, 2002
Place: Hunter College School of Social Work
129 East 79th Street (Between Lexington & Park Ave.)
Room 919 (9th Floor)
Time: 5:30-7:30 PM
Refreshments served

RSVP: Dr. Hilda Rivera, Hunter College School of Social 
Work/Community>Organizing (212) 452- 7100                       
e-mail:>hriver@...>Carlos Vargas-Ramos (212) 772-5707  
cvargas@...>The mission of the Latina/o Community Organizing 
Network/Red de Organizadores>Comunitarios is to serve as a support network 
and resource exchange for>community organizers of Puerto Rican, Caribbean, 
and Latino descent working>in these communities. We utilize the Paulo Freire 
principles of community>organizing, as well as participatory research. Using 
a variety of>methods/technologies we seek to bring together community and 
university based>organizers to reflect upon our accomplishments, challenges 
and to celebrate>our important work.

Post ID:2525
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-22 14:42:01
Subject:activists in nb court today for publicizing test scores
Message:

Two activists charged in fight at meeting

Star-Ledger, January 22, 2002

New Brunswick:  Two local political activists--brothers Cliff and Joseph 
Smith--are to appear in municipal court today to face charges related to a 
fight with officials at a school board meeting.

The Smiths tangled with New Brunswick High School Principal Pierre Embrey 
and New Brunswick police officer Donnie Bowling, chief of community 
relations for the department, when Embrey prohibited them from handing out 
fliers at last Tuesday's board of education meeting.

Cliff Smith, 32, allegedly refused to leave the meeting.  Joseph Smith, 25, 
allegedly punched Embrey and bit Bowling when they tried to carry Cliff 
Smith out.

Cliff Smith is charged with disrupting a public meeting.  Joseph Smith is 
charged with disrupting a public meeting and two counts of assault.

Cliff Smith said he filed charges of assault Friday against Embrey and 
Bowling, and he said his brother would file similar charges today.

The Smiths' pamphlets criticized the board for the low performance of city 
students on standardized tests.  The Smiths have long pressed for an elected 
school board in New Brunswick.  Currently, the mayor appoints the board.

Embrey charged Cliff Smith with assault for an altercation outside the high 
school during the 2000 campaign, but the charge was dropped after Embrey 
failed to show up in court.

Post ID:2526
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-23 13:24:52
Subject:DiaspoRICAN Dementia
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges all our supporters and allies to 
attend this powerful play written by Mariposa.  Mariposa has worked for 
years as  an activist fighting against sexism, racism, ageism, colonialism 
and for true freedom and self-determination.

As a member of ProLibertad she has used amazing and creative methods of 
voicing her demands for the freedom of the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, 
freedom for Puerto Rico and for Vieques.

Her spirit, talent and love has inspired us all to greater heights.  Please 
come out to the Nuyorican on Saturday Feb. 2nd!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
___________________________________________________________________
SISTAHS UNDERGROUND
presents

The 2nd Incarnation of

"DiaspoRICAN DEMENTIA"

Written and Performed by
MARIPOSA

Directed and Developed by
MARLYN MATIAS

Bronx Poet and actor, Mariposa delivers a poetic healing from internalized
colonialsim in this Nuyorican coming of age story that traces a young
woman's journey--complete with cultureal clases, identity issues, madness
and rebirth.

Special Appearances by
melleSOL
AND
Angel Rodriguez

SATURDAY
02.02.02
10PM 10PM 10PM

$12 at the Door

NUYORICAN POETS CAFE
236 EAST 3RD STREET
BTWN AVES B AND C

"F" train to 2nd Ave
or "6" train to Bleeker Street

THIS you don't want to MISS
COME BE RE-ENERGIZED, RE-INSPIRED and ANSWER THE QUESTION FOR YOURSELF:
WHAT IS IT TO BE CRAZY?

SPREAD THE WORD AND THE LOVE


MARIPOSA . a rising star of the underground poetry scene, is a spoken word
performance artist, freelance writer, educator, activist has been published

in numerous journals and anthologies including Def Poetry's "Bumrush the
Page" and was featured in Edward James Olmos'and Time warner's "Americanos:

Latino Life in the U.S., a documentary aired on HBO in May 2000.

http://groups.yahoo.com/invite/BLES?email=Nbpc_2002%40hotmail%2Ecom&iref=ebhfO1PGU0B_1_hipHhgPPrFS78
>By joining BLES, you will be able to exchange messages with other group 
>members. Yahoo! Groups also makes it easy to store photos and files, 
>coordinate events and more.
>
>Here's an introductory message from the group moderator:
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>Hello,
>
>Please subscribe to the Black and Latino Education Summit. We are a 
>Statewide Coalition of concerned parents, grandparents, educators and 
>community members.  Our main interest is the education of all children, 
>especially our urban children. We are their voice... We need as many 
>community members and organizations as possible to voice their concerns and 
>to share ideas,suggestion and visions on making our School Administrators 
>and Teachers accountable.
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>
>If you do not wish to join the BLES group, please
>ignore this invitation.

>privacy,
>it is a violation of our service rules for moderators to abuse this

>at abuse@yahoogroups.com

Post ID:2529
Sender:"nbpc_2002" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-24 16:39:48
Subject:Fwd: Introduction
Message:

--- In BLES@y..., "bevmar_08901" <bevmar_08901@y...> wrote:
Hello! Members:

As you are aware, the Educational Law Center has been leading the 
struggle in New Jersey for equal and adequate educational 
opportunities for urban children.  The Whole School Reform process, 
includes the School Management Teams (SMT).  The role of the SMT'S 
are to stay focused on their school's educational direction - that 
is, the overall educational vision, its goals and priorities.  The 
strategies that will be used to achieve that vision and the 
assignment of resources to accomplish those strategies.  The team is 
expected to engage in a concensus-based decision-making process 
following the ground rules of group discussion.  The School 
Management Teams should consists of parents, community and teachers.

Come join the Black and Latino Education Summit members on Thursday-
January 31, 2002, at the Teen Center, located at 65 Morris Street, 
New Brunswick, NJ.  The meeting will begin at 6:00pm.

                           AGENDA

1. Roles team members play?
2. How many parents are SMT'S?
3. How many community members are involved?
4. Are your suggestions and ideas implemented by the team?
5. Are you allowed to make decisions concerning your school?
6. Have you received adequate training to be an SMT member?
7. Have you met any SMT members from other New Brunswick schools?
8. How many parents do you know that are SMT members?

Please join us at our first meeting in New Brunswick.

Sincerely,

Beverly A. Marshall, BLES Member
--- End forwarded message ---





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2530
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-24 17:08:40
Subject:Fwd: [NB_CC_TF] (BLES) BLACK AND LATINO EDUCATION SUMMIT
Message:



----Original Message Follows----
From: "bevmar_08901" <bevmar_08901@...>
Reply-To: NB_CC_TF@yahoogroups.com
To: NB_CC_TF@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [NB_CC_TF] (BLES) BLACK AND LATINO EDUCATION SUMMIT
Date: Wed, 23 Jan 2002 20:15:21 -0000


Hello! Members,

As you may be aware, the Education Law Center has been leading the
struggle in New Jersey for equal and adequate educational
opportunities for urban children.  The Whole School Reform process,
includes the School Management Teams (SMT).  The role of the SMT'S
are to stay focused on their school's educational direction - that
is, the overall educational vision, it's goals and priorities, the
strategies that will be used to achieve that vision and the
assignment of resources to accomplish those strategies. The team is
expected to engage in a consensus-based decision-making
process,following the ground rules of group discussions.  The SMT'S
should consists of parents, community and teachers.

Come join the Black and Latino Education Summit Members on Thursday-
January 31, 2002.  The meeting will be held at the Teen Center,
located at 65 Morris Street, New Brunswick, NJ. The meeting will
begin at 6:00pm.

                             AGENDA

1. Roles Team Members Play
2. How many parents are SMT'S?
3. How many community members are involved?
4. Are your suggestions and ideas implemented by the team?
5. Are you allowed to make decisions concerning your school?
6. Have you received the proper training to be an SMT member?

Please join us at our first meeting in New Brunswick.

Sincerely,

Beverly A. Marshall, BLES Member








unite the many, defeat the few!

despair, youth programs over gang violence, solutions over sell outs.  

I've lived in Newark for three years and I wouldn't even know any of 
the current city council people's names if they didn't post it  on 
their self-congratulatory bus shelters!

Please come on Friday, Feb. 8th, at 7 pm to find out why you should be 
supporting the campaign to elect Ras Baraka. Refreshments will be 
served and donations are gladly accepted.

Post ID:2532
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-29 17:34:49
Subject:reparations...
Message:

               Tuesday's letters to the Home News Tribune

               Published in the Home News Tribune 1/29/02


               Reparations a democratic ideal

               All democratic peoples should support reparations and 
self-determination for the oppressed black nation and the demand for such 
put out by those like letter writer Joseph Mosely (Jan. 16). The social 
inequality of black America, enforced by the industrialists' betrayal of the 
post-Civil War Reconstruction, belies any promise of "democracy" and 
progress for the masses of people.

               To deny this historic and current inequality gives shelter to 
the likes of the Enron thieves and their cohorts in the counterfeit Bush 
administration; allows education, jobs, health care, etc., to be denied to 
tens of millions of U.S. residents, and allows monopolies to run roughshod 
over any and all constitutional rights and human development.

               You see, if Amadou Diallo can be legally shot 41 times, a 
poor white worker can be shot 40 and still be also told he's a full citizen. 
Divided, we fall.

               Our multinational strength, against the anti-democratic 
monopolies, depends on our unity, which can only be established through 
active support for national equality via reparations and self-determination. 
Minimally, this must take the form of, for example, free education for all 
American blacks.

               Cliff Smith
               NEW BRUNSWICK

Post ID:2533
Sender:"joseph smith" <can_bush@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-30 16:54:28
Subject:Fwd: 9-11 BOOK RELEASE at RasBararka2002 Meet & Greet Event: Feb 8
Message:


          SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT!!  (please foward widely)

***9/11 Book Release*** to Coincide with "Meet & Greet" Open House for Ras 
Baraka, candidate for Newark City Council (At-Large), Friday, February 8 @ 
7pm, 50 Columbia St., Newark, Apt. 3A (directions below)

    **ANOTHER WORLD IS POSSIBLE: CONVERSATIONS IN A TIME OF TERROR**

This book is the first progressive response to 9/11 and the continued
aggression in Afghanistan.  It is edited by 5 twenty-something editors,
representing activist committee ranging from CAAV, Intl Friends of Mumia, 
Students for Justice in Palestine, and Chicano Youth Organizing, the Rawkus 
Society, and anti-CitCorp, and Unity and Struggle.  It features diverse 
voices such as Angela Y. Davis, Eduardo Galleano, Fidel Castro, Barbara 
Kingslover, survivors of 9/11, Arundhati Roy, Suheir Hammad, Danny Hoch, 
Boots Riley from the Coup,(there is also a quote from Ras Baraka).

The book is being marketed and conceived primarily as an organizing &
fund-raiser tool--out of the 10K printed 1st round, 1/2 have been given to 
primarily youth organizations to help them raise $$$$ for their activities. 
The editors have commenced a nation wide tour to promote
anti-war/anti-fascist organizing.  The book has already got props from
MSNBC, BET.COM, City Lights Bookstore, and the Village Voice, and a few
Korean newspapers from Phili.  The book is being marketed with a 9/11 film 
by a collective of independent media folk, and an immanent CD from a small 
label on the West Coast featuring Dead PRez and the Coup.

(summary by Jeremy Glick, Another World is Possible, editor & Unity &
Struggle Edit Board member)



________________________________________________________________________
>
>*****************ATTENTION ALL ARTISTS AND STUDENTS*********************
>
>IF YOU BELIEVE that art should serve the people,
>IF YOU BELIEVE that architecture should be democratic,
>IF YOU BELIEVE that design should have substance,
>IF YOU BELIEVE in transformation of the real,
>IF YOU BELIEVE in slaying mediocrity & elitism,
>IF YOU BELIEVE that people make history,
>IF YOU BELIEVE in creative justice,
>IF YOU BELIEVE that wealth is not the source of ideas,
>IF YOU BELIEVE in relating academia to the street,
>
>...then come to a discussion led by RAS BARAKA, At-Large Candidate for
>Newark City Council, concerning:
>
>* The state of housing for Brick City Residents
>* Bringing the Newark Renaissance to the people,
>* Building Artist Housing,
>* Zoning Special Arts Districts in Newark,
>* Transforming Education
>
>...on Friday, February 8 at 7pm at our warehouse loft (Apt 3A) in the old
>sewing factory behind city hall on the corner of Green St. & Columbia.
>Refreshments will be served.
>
>
>For more information, contact us at (973) 824-2949 or email Matthew Smith 
>at
>NewArkitecture@...

>50
>Columbia St. Apt 3A -or- form Rt 21 South, turn right onto Lafayette St., 2
>blocks turn left onto Columbia St., one block to Green St.

Post ID:2534
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-01-31 09:26:21
Subject:Defend New Brunswick's Youth!
Message:

**--letter to the editor --**

Defend New Brunswick's Youth!
New Brunswick's Campaign for the Elected Board of Education is calling for 
state-wide support for our efforts toward a victorious campaign this 
November. New Brunswick public schools, while having the only Mayoral 
Appointed board of education, are the worst educational institutions in 
Middlesex County.
Over the past two years this criminal board has accomplished only what the 
enemy of a proper education can accomplish! High School Proficiency, which 
is required for graduation, has dropped over 33%:
76.8% proficient 1999 - 51% proficient 2001. What would people in Highland 
Park, Edison, East Brunswick, Piscataway &tc. do if this happened to their 
public schools? They would vote out the jokers on the BOE. And that is what 
we must do in New Brunswick! But first we must must organize & Win the 
elected school board this November.
For the New Brunswick city machine to defend/support this oppressive mayoral 
appointed BOE shows that they support this attack on the youth of this city. 
And therefore they must be gotten rid of too! For it is the lack of a proper 
education which leads to & is connected to every social problem throughout 
New Brunswick. Unemployment, Crime, Drugs, Gangs, and all other 
anti-productive social issues are a direct result of the lack of a proper 
education.
It is a terrible contradiction that New Brunswick is home to the most 
advanced institution of education throughout the state, Rutgers, but yet 
less than 50% of NB High School enrollers graduate.
Abott districts throughout New Jersey must organize and rise. We must fight 
the scientific segregation, we must defeat the crooks & the crooked, our 
time to unite is now, because you can't survive a genocide alone. The most 
advanced democratic struggle exists in the question of how schools are to be 
organized and run. Just study the Abott district cities and you will see the 
most oppressive, anti-democratic cities throughout New Jersey. Your study 
will show that these cities are where the highest forms of unemployment & 
Krime-Korruption-Khaos & segregation exist.
Somebody tell Bush we got his war on terror right here - In our struggle to 
defend public education in New Jersey! New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002 - 
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Joe Smith can_bush@...
732.729.0390
63 May St. New Brunswick

_________________________________________________________________
Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

Post ID:2537
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-01 14:19:21
Subject:Fwd: The Bombshell !! Bush Asks Daschle to Limit 9-11 Investigations !! WAKE UP CALL
Message:



>From: "wtcqd2000" <findtruth38@...>
>Reply-To: rusch@yahoogroups.com
>To: rusch@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [rusch] The Bombshell !!  Bush Asks Daschle to Limit 9-11 
>Investigations !! WAKE UP CALL
>Date: Thu, 31 Jan 2002 22:47:43 -0000
>
>Don't go there: Bush Asks Daschle to Limit Sept. 11 Probes [Daschle
>is perplexed by notion of not looking into 9-11]
>
>  Date: Wednesday, January 30 @ 10:09:24 EST
>
>  WASHINGTON (CNN) -- President Bush personally asked Senate Majority
>Leader Tom Daschle Tuesday to limit the congressional investigation
>into the events of September 11, congressional and White House
>sources told CNN.
>  The request was made at a private meeting with congressional leaders
>Tuesday morning. Sources said Bush initiated the conversation.
>  He asked that only the House and Senate intelligence committees look
>into the potential breakdowns among federal agencies that could have
>allowed the terrorist attacks to occur, rather than a broader inquiry
>that some lawmakers have proposed, the sources said.
>  Tuesday's discussion followed a rare call to Daschle from Vice
>President Dick Cheney last Friday to make the same request.
>  "The vice president expressed the concern that a review of what
>happened on September 11 would take resources and personnel away from
>the effort in the war on terrorism," Daschle told reporters.
>  But, Daschle said, he has not agreed to limit the investigation.
>  "I acknowledged that concern, and it is for that reason that the
>Intelligence Committee is going to begin this effort, trying to limit
>the scope and the overall review of what happened," said Daschle, D-
>South Dakota.
>  "But clearly, I think the American people are entitled to know what
>happened and why," he said.
>  Cheney met last week in the Capitol with the chairmen of the House
>and Senate intelligence committees and, according to a spokesman for
>Senate Intelligence Chairman Bob Graham, D-Florida, "agreed to
>cooperate with their effort."
>  The heads of both intelligence committees have been meeting to map
>out a way to hold a bipartisan House-Senate investigation and
>hearings.
>  They were discussing how the inquiry would proceed, including what
>would be made public, what would remain classified, and how broad the
>probe would be.
>  Graham's spokesman said the committees will review intelligence
>matters only.
>  "How ill prepared were we and why? We are looking towards the
>possibility of addressing systemic problems through legislation,"
>said spokesman Paul Anderson.
>  Some Democrats, such as Sens. Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut and
>Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, have been calling for a broad
>inquiry looking at various federal government agencies beyond the
>intelligence community.
>  "We do not meet our responsibilities to the American people if we do
>not take an honest look at the federal government and all of its
>agencies and let the country know what went wrong," Torricelli said.
>  "The best assurance that there's not another terrorist attack on the
>United States is not simply to hire more federal agents or spend more
>money. It's to take an honest look at what went wrong. Who or what
>failed? There's an explanation owed to the American people," he said.
>  Although the president and vice president told Daschle they were
>worried a wide-reaching inquiry could distract from the government's
>war on terrorism, privately Democrats questioned why the White House
>feared a broader investigation to determine possible culpability.
>  "We will take a look at the allocation of resources. Ten thousand
>federal agents -- where were they? How many assets were used, and
>what signals were missed?" a Democratic senator told CNN.
>  CNN Capitol Hill Producer Dana Bash and CNN Correspondents Jon Karl
>and John King contributed to this report.
>
>
>The DISTURBING REPORTS AROUND 9-11:
>
>- The Bush Administration forced the FBI to back off of the Bin Laden
>investigation months before 9-11. [BBC transcript BUSH � BIN LADEN
>HIDDEN AGENDA!!!]
>http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/events/newsnight/newsid_1645000/16455
>27.stm
>
>"I Don't Buy It"     " I was one of the first tenants in the World
>Trade Center (WTC) back in 1979.  Back then----over 20 years ago----
>it was known to all the tenants of the WTC that the WTC was a "no
>fly" zone.  If you came within 12 miles of the WTC, flying outside of
>a pattern where you were supposed to be, you were warned to back
>off.  If you came within five miles, they would threaten to shoot you
>down.  If you came within three miles, they could shoot you down.  If
>I remember correctly, on the roof of tower No. 2 they had surface to
>air missiles for that purpose, plus also the Spatz helicopters for
>that purpose.       "I had a friend who was flying a small plane who
>got warned away and they almost blew him out of the sky 20 years ago
>because he was showing somebody a close view of the towers.      "I
>can see the first tower getting hit by surprise, but 15 minutes later
>the second tower also gets hit?  I don't buy it."
>Walter Burien,  Radio Free America, Nov 11, 2001 [See FAA and DOD
>standard procedures for off course flight intercepts and shoot downs
>(all violated on 9-11)].
>
>- The CIA station chief in Dubai met with Bin Laden 7 weeks before
>9-11, and at a time when Bin Laden was supposedly "wanted" by the CIA.
>http://www.guardian.co.uk/waronterror/story/0,1361,584444,00.html�
>(German Trans.) http://www.orf.at/orfon/011031-44569/index.html
>(US Wash Times Artcl: www.washtimes.com Report: bin Laden treated at
>US hospital
>Elizabeth Bryant UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL Published 10/31/2001
>
>           An interview with Michael Springman exposes the CIA's links
>with the terrorist attacks on September 11
>       Straight Goods reader Ken MacAllister of Vancouver, BC writes:
>       Michael Springmann worked for the US government for 20 years
>with the foreign service and consulate. He just went public with the
>story of his involvement in a large scale CIA operation that brought
>hundreds of people from the middle east to the US, issued them
>passports and trained them to be terrorists. Springmann says that the
>CIA is working closely with Bin Laden and his operatives in Jeddah
>and has been since 1987. The most haunting implication from this
>interview is that all of the terrorist acts of late were planned and
>paid for by the CIA with US taxpayers money so that the US could
>legitimately bomb the hell out of Afghanistan
>       The interview is riveting, and I urge you to give it a listen.
>       Hear the CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) interview here.
>       http://www.straightgoods.ca/ViewNote.cfm?REF=1267
>
>- INSIDER TRADING PROFITS off of 9-11 were frenzied over by the US
>media when they thought it was Arab terrorists . . . but then the
>story mysteriously died.  Until, the UK Independent reveals that it
>leads to a firm chaired by the 3rd highest man in the CIA (and
>stranger still is that $2.5 million of the "winnings" are still
>unclaimed (see below for URL to entire story).
>http://globalresearch.ca/articles/RUP110A.html . Info confirmed by
>Independent Newspaper in UK: http://www.independent.co.uk/story.jsp?
>story=99402
>
>- ABC News.com's May/2001 story resurfaces about how the US Joint
>Chiefs of Staff have in the past ACTUALLY DESIGNED a plan to committ
>domestic terror on Americans to whip them into a war hysteria, to
>support war efforts by the govt.
>http://abcnews.go.com/sections/us/DailyNews/jointchiefs_010501.html

>Northwoods plan, which author James Bamford says "may be the most
>corrupt plan ever created by the U.S. government." It can be found at
>the following URL:]
>http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/news/20010430/
>
>- Strangely Anthrax is sent to (not the President, or Republicans)
>but to the top Democrat and to the media.  A foriegn terrorist would
>probably want to "divide" the country, not unite the opposition and
>the media in the war effort.
>- New Science Journal says Anthrax sent to Daschle is NOT Russian or
>Iraqi, but likely US military strain.
>
>- San Francisco Chronicle reports, the anthrax strain produced in US
>University is destroyed on ok of FBI (they had studied this for
>years, some at university question the timing of the destruction of
>those anthrax spores . . . right now of all times (?))
>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?
>f=/chronicle/archive/2001/11/09/MN153227.DTL

>The powder used in the anthrax attacks is virtually
>indistinguishable from that produced by the United States
>military, according to federal scientists.
>http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/03/national/03POWD.html?todaysheadlines
>
>- Bush Admin. declares they will "seal the records of presidents
>beginning with Father Bush/Reagans (an act never before done in US
>presidential history)."  AND What bizarre timing.  In the midst of a
>war and an economic disaster --  they find the time and "the desire"
>to seal the records of the Reagan/Bush admin, just as info is
>surfacing about Bush/Bin Laden connections from years back. (Details
>in Scripps-Howard News Service, appearing in Chico, CA paper on
>11/5/2001)
>
>"It is not a stretch to wonder if this White House is up to something
>that it doesn't want known 12 years from now or anytime thereafter.
>[A direct quote from the piece carried by Scripps Howard News
>Service.  Re: Bush's sealing of presidential records for the first
>time in U.S. history]
>
>
>"We must try to find out why the twin towers fell" By James Quintiere,
>Baltimore Sun 1/3/01
>http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/opinion/oped/bal-
>op.towers03jan03.story
>WTC "INVESTIGATION"?: A CALL TO ACTION from Fire Engineering Magazine
>	..."There are many, many questions to be asked by us about
>the World Trade Center collapse and its implications on high-rise
>firefighting across the nation. Some questions are political, many
>are technical, others are philosophical.      ..."you would think we
>would have the largest fire investigation in world history. You would
>be wrong. ..."We, the undersigned, call on FEMA to immediately
>impanel a "World Trade Center Disaster Review Panel" to coordinate a
>complete review of all aspects of the World Trade Center incident."
>http://fe.pennnet.com/Articles/Article_Display.cfm?
>Section=OnlineArticles&Su
>bSection=Display&PUBLICATION_ID=25&ARTICLE_ID=130026
>
>
>FORMER GERMAN CABINET MINISTER ATTACKS OFFICIAL BRAINWASHING ON
>SEPTEMBER 11 ISSUE
>[Source: Tagesspiegel, Berlin, Jan. 13] PARTIAL TRANSLATION
>
>In a full-page interview with the Sunday edition (Jan. 13) of the
>Berlin Tagesspiegel daily, former German Minister of Technology,
>Andreas von Buelow, said he does not buy any of the official theories
>that have been presented to date, on the events of September 11.
>
>Q: You seem so angry, really upset.
>
>Von Buelow: I can explain what's bothering me: I see that after the
>horrifying attacks of Sept. 11, all political public opinion is being
>forced into a direction that I consider wrong.
>
>Q: What do you mean by that?
>
>Von Buelow: I wonder why many questions are not asked. Normally, with
>such a terrible thing, various leads and tracks appear that are then
>commented on, by the investigators, the media, the government: Is
>there something here or not? Are the explanations plausible? This
>time, this is not the case at all. It already began just hours after
>the attacks in New York and Washington and--
>
>Q: In those hours, there was horror, and grief.
>
>Von Buelow: Right, but actually it was astounding: There are 26
>intelligence services in the U.S.A. with a budget of $30 billion--
>
>Q: ...more than the German defense budget...
>
>Von Buelow: --which were not able to prevent the attacks. In fact,
>they didn't even have an inkling they would happen. For 60 decisive
>minutes, the military and intelligence agencies let the fighter
>planes stay on the ground, 48 hours later, however, the FBI presented
>a list of suicide attackers. Within ten days, it emerged that seven
>of them were still alive.
>
>Q: What, please?
>
>Von Buelow: Yes, yes. And why did the FBI chief take no position
>regarding contradictions? Where the list came from, why it was false?
>If I were the chief investigator (state attorney) in such a case, I
>would regularly go to the public, and give information on which
>leadsare valid and which not.
>
>Q: That sounds like--
>
>Von Buelow: --like assailants who, in their preparations, leave
>tracks behind them like a herd of stampeding elephants? They made
>payments with credit cards with their own names; they reported to
>their flight instructors with their own names. They left behind
>rented cars with flight manuals in Arabic for jumbo jets. They took
>with them, on their suicide trip, wills and farewell letters, which
>fall into the hands of the FBI, because they were stored in the wrong
>place and wrongly addressed. Clues were left like behind like in a
>child's game of hide-and-seek, which were to be followed!
>
>There is also the theory of one British flight engineer: According to
>this, the steering of the planes was perhaps taken out ofthe pilots'
>hands, from outside. The Americans had developed a method in the
>1970s, whereby they could rescue hijacked planes by intervening into
>the computer piloting [automatic pilot system]. This theory says,
>this technique was abusedin this case. That's a theory....
>
>Q: Which sounds really adventurous, and was never considered.
>
>Von Buelow: You see! I do not accept this theory, but I find it worth
>considering. And what about the obscure stock transactions? In
>theweek prior to the attacks, the amount of transactions in stocks in
>American Airlines, United Airlines, and insurance companies,
>increased 1,200%. It was for a value of $15 billion. Some people must
>have known something. Who?
>
>Q: Why don't you speculate on who it might have been.
>
>Von Buelow: With the help of the horrifying attacks, the Western mass
>democracies were subjected to brainwashing. The enemy image of anti-
>communism doesn't work any more; it is to be replaced by peoples of
>Islamic belief. They are accused of having given birth to suicidal
>terrorism.
>
>Q: Brainwashing? That's a tough term.
>
>Von Buelow: Yes? But the idea of the enemy image doesn't come from
>me. It comes from Zbigniew Brzezinski and Samuel Huntington, two
>policy-makers of American intelligence and foreign policy. Already in
>the middle of he 1990s, Huntingon believed, people in Europe and
>theU.S. needed someone they could hate-- this would strengthen their
>identification with their own society. And Brzezinski, the mad dog,
>as adviser to President Jimmy Carter, campaigned for the exclusive
>right of the U.S. to seize all the raw materials of the world,
>especiallyoil and gas.
>
>Q: You mean, the events of Sept. 11--
>
>Von Buelow: --fit perfectly in the concept of the armaments industry,
>the intelligence agencies, the whole military-industrial-academic
>complex. This is in fact conspicuous. The huge raw materials reserves
>of the former Soviet Union are now at their disposal, also the
>pipeline routes and--
>
>Q: Erich Follach described that at length in Spiegel: ``It's amatter
>of military bases, drugs, oil and gas reserves.''
>
>Von Buelow: I can state: the planning of the attacks was technically
>and organizationally a master achievement. To hijack four huge
>airplanes within a few minutes and within one hour, to drive them
>into their targets, with complicated flight maneuvers! This is
>unthinkable, without years-long support from secret apparatuses of
>the state and industry.
>
>Q: You are a conspiracy theorist!
>
>Von Buelow: Yeah, yeah. That's the ridicule heaped [on those raising
>these questions] by those who would prefer to follow the official,
>politically correct line. Even investigative journalists are fed
>propaganda and disinformation. Anyone who doubts that, doesn't have
>all his marbles! That is your accusation.
>
>Q: Your career actually speaks against the idea that you are not in
>your right mind. You were already in the 1970s, state secretary in
>theDefense Ministry; in 1993 you were the SPD [Social Democratic
>Party] speaker in the Schalk-Golodkowski investigation committee--
>
>Von Buelow: And it all began there! Until that time, I did not have
>any great knowledge of the work of intelligence agencies. And now we
>had to take note of a great discrepancy: We shed light on the
>dealings of the Stasi and other East bloc intelligence agencies in
>the field of economic criminality, but as soon as we wanted to know
>something about the activities of the BND [German intelligence
>agency] or the CIA, it was mercilessly blocked. No information, no
>cooperation, nothing! That's when I was first taken aback.
>
>
>Not at war. ----- "On the surface, selling arms to a country that
>sponsors terrorism, of course, clearly, you'd have to argue it's
>wrong, but it's the exception sometimes that proves the rule." -
>George Bush on Good Morning America. 01/28/87
>
>




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Post ID:2539
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-01 15:36:15
Subject:queens 2 Political prisoners/Hearts and Hands
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read, attend and forward the 
following messages.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
Ne Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________

SUPPORT FOR POLITICAL PRISONERS
THE QUEENS 2



�This arrest/conviction was not only political, it was racially motivated 
without a doubt.  It is political and racial because the issue at stake here 
is the state�s deep-seated fear that they had certain African people who 
would speak up and would be effective in the African community.  America 
doesn�t want any dissent. This is what this trial expressed.� 		-Abdul Majid 
(excerpt of statement to court upon sentencing)


Free The Land

To the consciously free in heart and mind, I write to you today on behalf of 
the Queens 2.  Bashir Hameed and Abdul Majid collectively known as the 
Queens 2 have been imprisoned since the early 1980�s in New York State.  
Abdul and Bashir have the distinction of having been tried three times by 
the state of New York.  Their first trial ended in a hung jury, the second 
in a mistrial and the third in a conviction.   Currently, the Queens 2 have 
a pending appeal in the eastern district of New York pertaining to a 
violation of their constitutional rights.  In their final trial the district 
attorney used 14 of their 20 votes to remove Black people from the jury 
pool.

The Queens 2 are still seeking to expose the truth and need our support to 
do so. An updated and revised version of their story is about to be 
published. This booklet will be used as a fundraiser, circulated 
internationally and printed in Spanish for the upcoming political prisoner 
strategizing conference, Tear Down The Walls. However, much of this work 
will not come to fruition without the support of individuals like you. We 
need for people to contribute whatever they can to the production of this 
booklet.  All donations can be made out to:  Malcolm X Grassroots Movement, 
1195 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11216. Please write Queens 2 in the memo 
portion of your check and on the bottom of money orders.


In Love & Struggle,
Malcolm X Grassroots Movement


P.S. We would appreciate receiving all donations by February 28, 2002. You 
may also find more information on the Queens 2 and the Tear Down The Walls 
conference at: thejerichomovement.com.
________________________________________________________________________

and
Mario Murillo,
Host of WBAI's "Our Americas"
Invite you to celebrate and discuss the new book by
Luis Rodriguez

HEARTS AND HANDS

Divine Pryor, Executive Director of ADAPT (Assn of Drug Addiction,
Prevention, and Treatment)

Luis Barrios
Professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice

John Rodriguez
Former gang member and community activist

on Thursday, February 7th, 6:30-8:30 pm

445 West 59th St., Room 1311-N (Lecture Hall)
(Between 9 & 10 avenues)
New York City

Post ID:2540
Sender:Dwayne Middleton <nia7@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-01 20:14:07
Subject:Ras Baraka 2002 Headquarters Kickoff!!!!
Message:

Please join the Committee to Elect Ras Baraka to the opening of the
campaign headquarters!!!
*************************************************************************

Date:            Saturday, February 2, 2002

Location:       350-70 W. Market Street
                    Newark, NJ

Time:            4:00 pm
*************************************************************************

              For more information, please call (973) 242-0522.

                       Donations gladly accepted!!!

Frequently Asked Questions about the Ras Baraka Campaign for
Council-At-Large
(Newark, NJ)

Q1. Why are you running for Council-At-Large?

I'm running so that resources of public office can be better used for
working families and so that resources are redistributed into the hands
of the people. I also want to ensure that Newark's Renaissance means a
citywide rebirth, not just downtown.

Q2.  What are the main things you'd like to see changed in Newark?

Education, employment, and recreation.   I'm currently a Vice Principal
in Newark and before
that I was a public school teacher in this city for 10 years. I believe
that we need to return to
local control of our school system. I also believe that we need to raise
standards in the
classrooms by offering advanced courses and 'state of the art'
technology and resources.

On employment: while there are a mere 1,000 jobs available for our
youth this summer, we watch the tragedy of car thefts and gang
recruitment.  Newark's Renaissance must translate into more jobs for
city residents. Everyone is
entitled to a job that pays a living wage. Employment not only  provides
income and keeps our
kids out of trouble, but it gives
dignity as well.

On recreation: it needs to be meaningful, structured, and it
should  involve the entire family. Recreation just doesn't mean sports,
it includes dance, theater, computers, art, literature, trips, etc. and
can be an effective approach in developing our community - culturally
and
socially.

Q3. What are your views on crime and the police in Newark?

I know residents are concerned with the proliferation of drugs on our
streets and the growing amount of gang activity. I also share these
concerns. I am opposed to all forms of crime - be it committed by
civilians or by the police.
Education, employment, and recreation can reduce crime. Until
then,  there should be a visible level of community policing. Also, the
police should be controlled by the community, not by politicians or
police fraternities.

Q4. What do you think are your strongest assets for this position?

I have been a community activist for about 15 years, meaning that
I've been very engaged in the lives of the people of Newark. They
respect me
because of my respect for them. On top of that, I graduated from Howard
University with a Bachelor's degree in Political Science & History. I
also have a Master's in
Education from St. Peters College in Jersey City.

Q5. What are your long-term political objectives? And when is the actual
election?

My only objective is to win a seat for the people of Newark. The
election is  May 2002.

          TIME TO TAKE IT PERSONAL!!!!!!!!!!!

The Latin@ Coalition for Peace with Justice (LCPJ) is calling on all 
activists, organizers and allies to attend our first Community forum of the 
year 2002.  We ask that people who receive this message forward it out to 
others!!  Help build the Anti-War Movement in the Latin@ community.

Commuity Forum:

---How can we build and support an anti-war/pro-peace movement in the 
community?
---How is the war  effecting the undocumented immigrant community?
---What are our civil rights during this period?

Panelists include:
Rev. Luis Barrios, La Iglesia san Romero
Rosita Romero, Centro de desarollo de la mujer Dominicana
Frank Morlaes, Lower Eastaide Activist

When: Friday Feb. 15th, 2002 at 6:30pm
Where: 2005 Amsterdam Avenue 2nd floor (between w159th-w160th St.)

Post ID:2542
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-03 10:44:20
Subject:Pedro Colon Almenas
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read and forward out this 
quick update on the case of Pedro Colon Almenas.  This text was translated 
from Spanish to English by proLibertad.  This update comes from Pedro Colon 
Almenas' support committee in Puerto Rico.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Last Sept. 10th, Pedro Colon Almenas, a student and member of the Union de 
Juventudes Socialistas and the Movimiento Socialista de Trabajdores, was 
found guilty of "Aggravated Assualt against a Military Officer" by Judge 
Hector Lafitte (an ex-JAG Lawyer, pro-navy advocate, who has made it his 
goal to punish all activists who have done civil disobedience in Vieques 
with absurd sentences).  Pedro sentencing which was first scheduled for Jan. 
22nd, has been postponed to Friday February 22nd, 2002.  Pedro could face up 
to five years in jail.  Pedro is a graduate student who has been a powerful 
student leader.  His only "crime" has been to fight for a University of 
Puerto Rico without a military/ROTC presence on it, and for demanding that 
the U.S. Navy leave Vieques.  It is important that all communites become 
aware of Pedro's case; He is a victim of a sham trial and a colonial 
government intent on jailing activists that work against the colonial status 
quo.

It is important that people check out  http://www.bander.org/pedro/  the 
site is back up and the information is in Spanish.

______________________________________________________________________
ProLibertad will be translating and sending out further emails on Pedro's 
case.

Post ID:2547
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-10 11:19:00
Subject:Celebrate-Julia De Burgos' Birthday
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign forwards out this message in solidarity 
with the Puerto Rican progressive artists' community.

For years, the cultural workers and activists in our community have used 
their unique talents and artistry to bring to the community the issues 
around the 6 Puerto Rican Political priosners, the independence of Puerto 
Rico, and the need for the U.S. Navy to leave Vieques.

Please support this activity.  It is in honor of an amazing Independentista 
freedom fighter/artist; Julia De Burgos.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________
Mixta Gallery & AsirayWorks

Invite you to join us
at the Celebration of Julia De Burgos' Birthday
with Music, Poetry and Art

Sunday, February 17, 2002
at 3:00pm

Central Park at 106 Street
In front of the lake

Bring a gift for Julia!
Candles, flowers, poems, art

>eliminate Democrats and Republicans at the local level, but not at the 
>national level.

>removed from the list two months ago. This is a Green Party list, and since

Post ID:2552
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-13 15:37:06
Subject:Fwd: Important Green Party Events at Rutgers-New Burnswick
Message:

the counter revolutionary efforts are in full swing. where is u&s? -joe 
smith


>From: whcoon@...
>To: <rugreens@yahoogroups.com>
>CC: <kiddryan@...>
>Subject: [RUGreens] Important Green Party Events at Rutgers-New Burnswick
>Date: Wed, 13 Feb 2002 11:21:47 EST
>
>If anyone would liek to attend these events. Please feel free to walk in on 
>the day of! Beat seating is available if you contact either myself (Ray 
>Higbee, Secretary of the Green Party) at whcoon@... or Steve Welzer at 
>ecovillager@..., enjoy!
>
>
>SAVE THE DATES!
>
>IMPORTANT GREEN PARTY EVENTS IN MARCH AND APRIL
>
>
>Event #1: Petition Drive Kick-off for NJ Green Campaign 2002
>
>Date: Saturday, March 9    11:00am to 2:00pm
>Location: Rutgers Labor Education Center, Room 115
>
>The Greens expect to be fielding one of our most extensive slates this 
>year, running candidates for national, state, county, and municipal 
>offices.  Among others, GPNJ Chair Joseph Fortunato will be running for 
>U.S. Congress and Vice Chair Jane Hunter will be running for council in her 
>home town of Bound Brook.  We are still soliciting candidates, and we hope 
>all locals will encourage one or several of their members to step forward 
>to take the Green Party message to the voters in some capacity next fall.
>
>In our highest-visibility race this year Ted Glick, National Coordinator of 
>the Independent Progressive Politics Network, will be the Green Party 
>candidate challenging for the U.S. Senate seat currently held by Robert 
>Torricelli.  Ted has been a prominent activist for decades and has 
>participated in a wide range of struggles -- such that we expect his 
>candidacy to resonate among peace, environment, labor, minority, and other 
>social change activists all across the state.  To show the extent of 
>support for this campaign we'd like to submit more petition signatures than 
>we've ever done before.  As Greens and supporters hit the streets this 
>spring to gather signatures for local candidates (all petitions must be 
>submitted by the first week of June) we will be encouraging everyone to 
>carry a clipboard with a Glick for Senate petition.
>
>Please join us March 9 to meet our candidates and discuss strategy for NJ 
>Green Campaign 2002!
>
>
>Event #2: GPNJ Sixth Annual Convention
>
>Date: Sunday, April 28    9:00am to 4:30pm
>Location: Rutgers Labor Education Center, Main Auditorium
>
>The Green Party has emerged as New Jersey's leading alternative party.  Our 
>bedrock principles of nonviolence, grassroots democracy, social justice, 
>and environmental protection have never been more relevant than in this 
>period of national crisis and apprehension.
>
>The Annual Convention is a time for members to make their voices heard on 
>the variety of issues that face our party, to sign up to participate on 
>statewide committees, to modify the organizational bylaws, and to elect 
>party officers.  Non-members are welcome to join us as observers--check out 
>this dynamic new party and learn about the international movement for Green 
>politics.  An extensive collection of Green Party literature will be 
>available.
>
>
>So save the dates!  Join us March 9 and April 28 in New Brunswick!
>
>
>

New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002

Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Post ID:2554
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-15 13:44:47
Subject:A special Invite...
Message:

This is an invite to all the organizations and individuals that work with or 
support ProLibertad and the Malcom X Grassroots Movement...

Solidarity folks,

This is Benjamin Ramos of the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, I am sending 
this email out as an invitation and inquiry for endorsement for a very 
special activity that is coming up on March 9th.  On Saturday March 9th, The 
Malcom X Grassroots movement and ProLibertad are putting together a special 
forum on the Patriot Act and how it effects our organizing in communities.

Kamau Franklin, of MXGM, will be putting together a panel of lawyers that 
will address the issues of immigration, FBI repression and a basic "What is 
the Patriot Act?" analysis.  It will be held at Hunter College West building 
6th floor room 615 from 1pm-3pm, e68th St. and Lexington Avenue.

This forum's goal is to educate  the community around the new legislation 
and how it will and has already effected our anti war work, our political 
prisoner work, our anti-imperialism, and immigration work.  It is shocking 
that many in all our communities (especially the people of color activist 
community) are unaware of the new blatantly repressive/pro-facist 
legislation that has become common law.

I invite you all to the forum, but more importantly I ask you to endorse 
this forum.  Please lend your organizations' name and promotional resources 
for this event.  I ask that if you endorse the forum that you get the flyer 
and mobilize your organization and its constituents to come it out.  We ask 
you to send out the info. to your email lists, to send out the flyers in 
your mailings and to adversitse the activity on any media sources you have 
access to as well.

We need to build this forum and get our communities educated.  We are in a 
repressive time and we must be informed.  Our work and security are at 
stake.  Let us fill those seats with our communities.

Please email me ( uriyoan@... ) with your organizational endorsement 
and to ask for the flyer.  An endorsement list will also be sent with the 
flyer.  This list will be constantly be updated until March 9th, 2002.



_________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp.

Post ID:2555
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-16 19:20:05
Subject:nb murals
Message:


               Tammy Paolino: Mural projects give vision of city life 
through the eyes of their artists

               Published in the Home News Tribune 2/16/02

               I have lots of favorite things to do in Philadelphia.

               I love to take in a folk show at the Tin Angel, for instance. 
I also love to go to the Vet and watch the Yankees whoop the Phils, and 
maybe even grab a late-night cheesesteak at Pat's Steaks.

               When in Philly, I enjoy a visit to the Rodin Museum, shopping 
in Manyunk, a leisurely brunch with the bo-hos at the Morning Glory, or a 
rainy afternoon browsing at Tower Records.

               While I'm doing all of that, I have another favorite thing to 
do -- checking out the murals that adorn the brick faces and exposed walls 
of buildings throughout the City of Brotherly Love.

               All over town, larger-than-life images of historical figures, 
professional athletes, ballerinas and jazz musicians, hot-house flowers, 
geometric abstractions, and, these days, especially, bursts of patriotism, 
loom above the taxis and minivans and buses and huddled masses that fill the 
streets.

               Philadephia's murals are a result of The Mural Arts Project, 
a program administered by the city's recreation department. In addition to 
beautification, the projects' goals are to eliminate "graffiti vandalism" 
and to "(expand) educational visual arts opportunities throughout the 
Philadelphia region."

               Through the program, artists and kids - including some of 
those interested in graffiti art and spray cans -- work together to create 
art in public spaces throughout the city.

               Here at home, murals can be found in some downtown areas -- 
including several colorful works scattered around downtown New Brunswick. In 
March, for instance, the Hungarian-American Athletic Club on Somerset Street 
offered a wall of its building for a mural dedicated to the Bristol-Myers 
Squibb Children's Hospital at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.

               New Brunswick has so much to celebrate -- what with its rich 
ethnic diversity, its proximity to the river and the D&R canal, its 
reputation as a cultural center for the arts and, of course, its growing 
prominence as a leader in medical research and health care.

               Murals are an enduring and dramatic way to pay tribute to 
civic leaders and local heroes, recall historical events, encourage civic  
pride, or just add some urban charm to an otherwise drab section of town.

               The People's Community Arts Mural Project of New Brunswick 
has several public mural projects planned throughout the city. CAMP 
volunteers -- artists, community leaders, students and others interested in 
sprucing things up -- work weekends on mural
projects in the area. (Those interested in picking up a paint brush can 
contact Tamara Dahan at tamaradahan@... or Maura Carey at 
mauracarey@...)

               Collaborative public art projects are meant to bring diverse 
groups of people together in an ongoing conversation about their vision of 
their neighborhood, their city and their world.

               While the Mural Project is likely to benefit from the many 
talented artists and art students from the New Brunswick and Rutgers 
University communities, the program will have an even greater impact on the 
city if members of lots of other groups get involved as well.

               It's my hope, for instance, that the graffiti artists 
currently showcasing their talents in the cavernous tunnels and on the 
towering bridges along Route 18 will grab their spray cans, come into the 
light and make their marks where they will really count.

               Tammy Paolino's column appears every Saturday. (732) 
565-7330. E-mail tpaolino@...

               from the Home News Tribune

               Published: February 16, 2002






unite the many, defeat the few!


_________________________________________________________________

http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

Post ID:2556
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-16 22:18:57
Subject:new brunswick community murals arts project
Message:

Tammy Paolino: Mural projects give vision of city life
through the eyes of their artists

Published in the Home News Tribune 2/16/02

I have lots of favorite things to do in Philadelphia.

I love to take in a folk show at the Tin Angel, for instance. I also love to 
go to the Vet and watch the Yankees whoop the Phils, and maybe even grab a 
late-night cheesesteak at Pat's Steaks.

When in Philly, I enjoy a visit to the Rodin Museum, shopping
in Manyunk, a leisurely brunch with the bo-hos at the Morning Glory, or a 
rainy afternoon browsing at Tower Records.

While I'm doing all of that, I have another favorite thing to do -- checking 
out the murals that adorn the brick faces and exposed walls of buildings 
throughout the City of Brotherly Love.

All over town, larger-than-life images of historical figures, professional 
athletes, ballerinas and jazz musicians, hot-house flowers, geometric 
abstractions, and, these days, especially, bursts of patriotism, loom above 
the taxis and minivans and buses and huddled masses that fill the streets.

Philadephia's murals are a result of The Mural Arts Project, a program 
administered by the city's recreation department. In addition to 
beautification, the projects' goals are to eliminate "graffiti vandalism" 
and to "(expand) educational visual arts opportunities throughout the 
Philadelphia region."

Through the program, artists and kids - including some of those interested 
in graffiti art and spray cans -- work together to create art in public 
spaces throughout the city.

Here at home, murals can be found in some downtown areas -- including 
several colorful works scattered around downtown New Brunswick. In March, 
for instance, the Hungarian-American Athletic Club on Somerset Street 
offered a wall of its building for a mural dedicated to the Bristol-Myers 
Squibb Children's Hospital at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.

New Brunswick has so much to celebrate -- what with its rich ethnic 
diversity, its proximity to the river and the D&R canal, its reputation as a 
cultural center for the arts and, of course, its growing prominence as a 
leader in medical research and health care.

Murals are an enduring and dramatic way to pay tribute to civic leaders and 
local heroes, recall historical events, encourage civic pride, or just add 
some urban charm to an otherwise drab section of town.

The People's Community Arts Mural Project of New Brunswick has several 
public mural projects planned throughout the city. CAMP volunteers -- 
artists, community leaders, students and others interested in sprucing 
things up -- work weekends on mural projects in the area. (Those interested 
in picking up a paint brush can contact Tamara Dahan at 
tamaradahan@... or Maura Carey at
mauracarey@...)

Collaborative public art projects are meant to bring diverse groups of 
people together in an ongoing conversation about their vision of their 
neighborhood, their city and their world.

While the Mural Project is likely to benefit from the many talented artists 
and art students from the New Brunswick and Rutgers University communities, 
the program will have an even greater impact on the city if members of lots 
of other groups get involved as well.

It's my hope, for instance, that the graffiti artists currently showcasing 
their talents in the cavernous tunnels and on the towering bridges along 
Route 18 will grab their spray cans, come into the light and make their 
marks where they will really count.

Tammy Paolino's column appears every Saturday. (732)565-7330. E-mail 
tpaolino@...

                from the Home News Tribune

                Published: February 16, 2002


New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002

Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:2558
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-17 22:31:24
Subject:Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Message:

all the injuries inflicted on the community at the 1/15 board of ed mtg are 
'reprehensible'.  the issue is to fix responsibility on the antagonists.

but none of those 'reprehensible occurences' shd distract from the massive, 
daily 'reprehensible occurence' of nb's pitiful education record, to which 
we are all 'witness'.  for instance, the cut in funding suffered by the 
Puerto Rican Action Board's early childhood development center, at the hands 
of the un-elected board of education, which prefers to give public nb 
dollars to a private charter school and a private high school, over which 
the community has no democratic control.

there is no excuse whatever, given the vast wealth and education resources 
to be found in this city, why nb public school students shd not be provided 
the highest level of education imaginable. this despite the conspicuous (and 
likewise inexcusable) local poverty and related social degradation.  rather, 
it is most disingenuous to suggest eliminating these problems w/o first 
prioritizing education.

the public school board must be accountable, certainly to parents, but also 
to the entire community, as we are all affected in no small way by the 
success or failure of the education of nb's youth. or where do these 
children end up?

the connected issues of the 'taxation w/o representation' of nb's latino 
community, and nj's regressive tax structure, will also be resolved, like 
all social problems, only through more democracy, not less.

as we have seen, the elimination of democratic community control over 
newark's education system did nothing to eliminate 'patronage', 
'corruption', and lack of 'concern for the welfare of the students'.  to the 
contrary, the conditions there have worsened.

cliff

----Original Message Follows----
From: GUILLO@...
Reply-To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Date: Sun, 17 Feb 2002 18:06:32 EST

I can't comment much on the incident at the BOE meeting for I was not a
witness; nevertheless it is my understanding that Police Chief Don Bowling
was bitten during a scuffle, a reprehensible occurrence.
I agree that all Boards of Educations should be accountable to parents, 
their
natural constituency.  I question, though, some of the reasoning used or
implied in this letter.
All New Brunswick BOE members do and must reside in New Brunswick, and it is
my understanding that most of those that have school-aged children have them
attending city schools.   What would assure the elected Board members have
their children attend city schools?
Performance at Lincoln School must be scrutinized, particularly because of
Rutgers' acclaimed involvement in the academic "enhancement" of this
particular school. But to compare New Brunswick schools to the State average
is inappropriate.
Although the district possesses a great deal of issues that need 
improvement,
the majority of the students attending New Brunswick Public Schools are
affected by many environmental factors that influence negatively on their
performance.  Poverty, overcrowded housing conditions, substance abuse,
delinquency, teen pregnancy, the inability of many parents to assist 
children
with coursework because of their lack of command of English or their work
schedules, among many other things, have a definite impact.  When compared 
to
other urban areas that share the same intensity of problems and barriers, 
New
Brunswick schools do surprisingly well.

Lastly, if 65 percent of the children enrolled in the public school district
is Latino, and most of their parents cannot yet vote - although contributing
to society and the tax base, whom will elected Board members represent?
Which constituency will be represented?  Could it be Senior Citizens on 
fixed
incomes - which have the highest percentage of participants in elections -
whom because of the unjust NJ tax structure are obliged to endeavor to 
reduce
their property taxes?  Moreover, I keep getting flashbacks of the abuses of
the elected Board in Newark and the patronage and corruption that occurred
there without concern for the welfare of students.

An elected Board might be a good idea.  But we need sound arguments to
support the question.

Guillo







unite the many, defeat the few!


_________________________________________________________________
Join the world�s largest e-mail service with MSN Hotmail. 
http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2559
Sender:GUILLO@...
Post Date/Time:2002-02-17 23:48:06
Subject:Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Message:

The cut in funding this year of ALL New Brunswick community preschool 
providers was enacted by the State Department of Education (it's still under 
appeal).  In order to equalize education between richer and poorer districts, 
the Supreme Court Abbott decision requires preschool - paid by the State - in 
the poorer districts.  That same Department, because of State legislation, 
requires local school districts to fund Charter Schools approved by the 
State.  Again, no local control of the issue, whatever type of Board exists.

The private High School is another matter.  Public dollars directed to a 
large absentee for-profit company is distasteful.  I'm waiting to see if it 
will be successful, and if it will hurt the main High School student 
population.  I'm also interested in the demographics of the school, and the 
demographics of the Charter School, for that matter.

I must totally agree that "there is no excuse whatever, given the vast wealth 
and education resources to be found in this city, why New Brunswick public 
school students should not be provided the highest level of education 
imaginable."  The available resources are not interacting effectively.

By the way, I didn't mean to prioritize any social problem over another.  
They all need attention.  Nonetheless, performance will be affected by 
environmental factors, even if students are provided the highest level of 
education imaginable.

My position on Latino parents is that now they DO have representation in the 
school Board.   With an elected Board …….. ?   Maybe.

Regardless, I still believe that an elected Board might be a good idea.  But 
we need sound arguments to support the question.  Maybe individuals that 
would run for an elected Board should begin disseminating platforms 
explaining how they could make the necessary changes?   If they have the 
answers, I'm sure the community would back them.

Guillo

In a message dated 2/17/02 10:52:30 PM Eastern Standard Time, 
cliffsmith69@... writes:

<< all the injuries inflicted on the community at the 1/15 board of ed mtg 
are 
 'reprehensible'.  the issue is to fix responsibility on the antagonists.
 
 but none of those 'reprehensible occurences' shd distract from the massive,

 we are all 'witness'.  for instance, the cut in funding suffered by the 
 Puerto Rican Action Board's early childhood development center, at the hands 
 of the un-elected board of education, which prefers to give public nb 
 dollars to a private charter school and a private high school, over which 
 the community has no democratic control.
 
 there is no excuse whatever, given the vast wealth and education resources 
 to be found in this city, why nb public school students shd not be provided 
 the highest level of education imaginable. this despite the conspicuous (and 
 likewise inexcusable) local poverty and related social degradation.  rather, 
 it is most disingenuous to suggest eliminating these problems w/o first 
 prioritizing education.
 
 the public school board must be accountable, certainly to parents, but also 
 to the entire community, as we are all affected in no small way by the 
 success or failure of the education of nb's youth. or where do these 
 children end up?
 
 the connected issues of the 'taxation w/o representation' of nb's latino 
 community, and nj's regressive tax structure, will also be resolved, like 
 all social problems, only through more democracy, not less.
 
 as we have seen, the elimination of democratic community control over 
 newark's education system did nothing to eliminate 'patronage', 
 'corruption', and lack of 'concern for the welfare of the students'.  to the 
 contrary, the conditions there have worsened.
 
 cliff
