to recommend execution or life in prison for the 58-year-old Al-Amin. He was 
found guilty of 13 counts, including murder, aggravated assault on a police 
officer, obstruction and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
The jury will return at 10 a.m. Monday. According to the judge, the death 
penalty phase will last most of the week. The jury may recommend sentences 
of life with the possibility of parole, life without the possibility of 
parole or death by injection.

thigh, once in the right side and once in the upper arm. For Kinchen, it 
would be worse. An autopsy determined he was shot six times with three 
different types of ammo. A few days later, Al-Amin was arrested in the small 
town of White Hall, Ala., a town he once had hoped would be the site of his 
dream community.

semiautomatic pistol found nearby were the same weapons used to shoot 
Kinchen. A bullet-riddled black Mercedes-Benz, that English said Al-Amin was 
driving when they tried to arrest him - was also found on Johnson's 
property.
While in jail awaiting trial, Al-Amin claimed jailers were threatening to 
kill him. He spent much of his time in solitary confinement. He was set to 
go on trial Sept. 12, 2001. But, a day earlier, radical Muslims hi-jacked 
four airplanes, killing thousands of American. Fearing that a jury could be 
tainted by the sudden national backlash against Muslims, Al-Amin's trial was 
delayed.
Jury selection finally began on Jan. 8, 2002, and on Feb. 19, a jury of nine 
blacks, two whites and one Hispanic was picked. In picking the jury,

Post ID:2596
Sender:GUILLO@...
Post Date/Time:2002-03-12 00:47:05
Subject:Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Marshall Trial
Message:

What a convenient, timely, and so aptly articulated discourse.  

Opportune to say the least.

Guillo

In a message dated 3/11/02 3:32:37 PM Eastern Standard Time, 
cliffsmith69@... writes:

<< To: New Brunswick Peoples' Campaign and Sisterhood & Struggle:
 
 From: Drena T. Carter (Mother of Corey Ashford, key witness, State v.
                        James Marshall)
 
 8 March, 2002
 
 I deeply regret not being able to attend your meeting today, however, due to 
 the serious nature of this case, I was advised against attending.  I do 
 however, would like to thank each and every one of you for your support and 
 continued interest surrounding the police corruption case of Jim Marshall.
 
 Unfortunately because I am a witness in this case, particulars cannot be 
 discussed.  However, I will fill you in on facts that have been made public 
 either in court, or the newspapers.  People seem to think that James 
 Marshall was acquitted and are deeply confused with regards to legalities of 
 this case.  It is most unfortunate that people only read the headlines and 
 not between the lines especially in cases such as this one.  James Marshall 
 was losing this trial by a landslide, and the only way that his attorney 
 could come up for air was to drag things out to the point where the jury was 
 getting restless and bored.  After six weeks of trial, only four witnesses 
 had been called, one being the key witness, my son, Corey Ashford.  After 
 the prosecution concluded its questioning of Corey, the defense attorney 
 begun its cross examination.  However, the questions were redundant of what 
 the prosecution had just finished up with.  Most would have questioned the 
 line of mild questioning that the defense attorney brought to the table.  
 However, we all know now that the defense attorney had a hidden agenda, and 
 suddenly he was sick for a week and court was postponed only to find out 
 that some of the jurors asked to be released due to prior commitments.  
 Either this was a stroke of luck for the Marshall team, or a well planned 
 strategy on the part of Marshall's attorney.  They say that most attorneys 
 can feel the jury, and I don't think there were any connections on behalf of 
 Marshall.  Marshall's attorney is rude and obnoxious, and tries to set the 
 scene of the courtroom of a Perry Mason show.  However, after the tapes were 
 played, the jury seemed quite interested.
 
 After testifying, I appeared on the day my son was to testify.  Noone in the 
 courtroom had a problem with my presence, with the exception of Marshall's 
 attorney.  He made up the excuse that he might have to call me back as a 
 witness.  However, Corey's girlfriend was also asked to leave the courtroom 
 [illegible] witness to testify.  Marshall's attorney's real motive was to 
 make it seem like Corey had no family support, and that he was just some 
 street thug out there alone making this entire thing up, while Marshall is 
 being surrounded by a loving family that has his support.
 
 Marshall is as guilty as the day is long, however, he is determined that he 
 won't go down without a fight not caring who he hurts or destroys.  His 
 pride won't allow him to take a plea bargain although his attorney did 
 inquire about having one on the table...  And where is he getting all this 
 money for legal fees.  According to a very reliable source, Marshall's 
 attorney fees have exceeded $100,000, and he still has three more trials to 
 go.  I didn't realize legal cops made that kind of money, or are the 
 taxpayers of New Brunswick footing the bill?
 
 I say to you people, if Marshall walks, the struggle for justice will have 
 to start from the beginning again.  Everything that you have worked for in 
 demanding fair and equal treatment for mankind will be conceived as a joke.  
 Don't let this happen.  If Marshall walks, so should every criminal that has 
 ever been locked up for selling and distribution of illegal drugs, not to 
 mention the king pin of a brothel aka whorehouse.
 
 James Marshall has tried to destroy my family, however, we are strong and 
 believe in the fight.  If we all weren't witnesses, we'd be passing out 
 fliers and sitting in the courtroom just as you are.  However, we don't want 
 any more excuses for mistrials and delays, so we must stay in the 
 background.  We want Marshall to pay for his crime and do his time.  If 
 there is justice in Middlesex County, this will happen.  However, the only 
 way that justice will be served is if the good people of New Brunswick and 
 the surrounding areas come forward and demand just that, justice be served.  
 Stop pussyfooting with Marshall and get this nightmare over with.  How can a 
 convicted felon be allowed to walk freely as we law abiding citizens do, 
 leave town at his leisure and continue to manipulate the system.  Who does 
 Marshall really have in his back pocket, or should I say his little black 
 book.
 
 Again, I express my deepest regrets for not physically being here, however, 
 you have my full support in all that you do.  Peace and strength be with 
 you.
 
 Sincerely,
 
 Drena T. Carter
 
 
 
 
 
 
 unite the many, defeat the few! >>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2597
Sender:"Sash Zlatanovic" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-12 11:22:51
Subject:Response to having the NBPC convention on May 21st
Message:

I was rather disappointed to learn that the New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 
convention would be held on such a late date in May. Although some have 
mentioned that students are welcome and should be motivated to vote in this 
year's elections, very little has been done to avoid a major problem: by May 
21st, the vast majority of Rutgers students would have already left, either 
graduating or going back to their principal residence, which for the most 
part isn't New Brunswick.

There's no better way to lose credibility and seem tactless in efforts to 
attract students than to fail to schedule a convention that is much 
earlier--or deliberately be absolutely thoughtless. Or even to find an 
alternative venue to hold this convention for that matter. If the New 
Brunswick Public Library doesn't have space any earlier, look for another 
place. If no other place can be found for the dozen or more people that are 
going to vote, which is doubtful in a city of hundreds of blocks, set up 
polling places throughout the city in the form of outdoor and indoor ballot 
boxes in supporters' homes and in various other places. This was neither 
considered by those clumsily organizing the campaign nor even put to a vote. 
Clearly, the decision to hold the convention on May 21st was made privately, 
utterly oblivious of common sense.

Were these concerns raised at all? Of course they were. I argued on several 
occasions, including at February's general meeting of about a dozen people, 
to have the convention much earlier, preferably in late April, so that we 
could have a larger student turnout and have enough time for our candidates 
to iron out any problems that may arise before the June deadline for 
petitions. But, no, I'm afraid that isn't the case. Not only will far fewer 
students be able to attend the convention, but coverage by the Daily Targum 
has been needlessly lost, since they stop publishing in early May.

Apparently, not everyone's opinion or advice counts. Certainly not mine, and 
considering that only a couple of people are actually the ones making the 
decisions for the campaign, some people are more equal than others. Contrary 
to the claim that everyone's vote counts, only a couple of certain people 
actually choose who gets to vote and actually count.

Some can say that a decision was indeed made publicly, but considering that 
none was made at any of the meetings I've had publicly and privately with 
NBPC and that I've been the source of this research concerning campaign 
contributions and property ownership by city hall insiders and the fellow in 
charge of taking care of papers with the state Election Law Enforcement 
Commission (ELEC) and trying to attract student attention to issues 
important to the city, it's tough to imagine how I may have overlooked such 
a major meeting.

Moreover, it's been sorely overlooked that, following last year's change in 
officers which I admit I wasn't yet active with the NBPC to experience, 
whoever is supposed to be the treasurer hasn't taken care of the ELEC 
papers, which should've been filed soon after the officer change. Clearly, 
this raises questions of the competence and legitimacy behind the decisions 
being made. Finally, from my understanding, there's no record of any such 
decision to have such an inopportune date for the convention being made 
publicly.

I expect that these concerns will likely be immaturely and unprofessionally 
ignored, but I may just be a cynic at heart. I look forward to any serious 
discussion on this matter.

Sash Zlatanovic
New Brunswick, NJ

P.S. Considering the 2,059 votes "gained" by the NBPC in 2000, if one were 
to add up all the votes gained by the three candidates for City Council for 
the establishment (i.e., R. Recine, B. Valenti, J. Schrum), like Cliff 
conveniently had done for alternative candidates, the establishment gained 
many more votes than what's being mentioned.



  ***



  Message: 5

  Date: Mon, 11 Mar 2002 20:14:48 +0000
  From: "cliff smith"
  Subject: (unknown)
  New Brunswick
  Peoples� Campaign 2002
  unite the many, defeat the few!
  Dear Community Member,
  As you may know, Mayor James Cahill has announced his campaign for
  re-election in November, with council members, Joseph Egan and Blanquita
  Valenti. It was also reported that, as of March 1, their campaign chest
  already has over $80,000!
  Cahill won in 1998 with 3500 votes, out of 25,000 registered voters. It is
  not popular support that maintains his administration, but a tight,
  well-funded organization. Which is also what is needed to defeat him�
  The 2000 New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign council candidates took 2059 
votes,
  in our first time out. This is by far the greatest threat Cahill has 
faced.
  And we have strengthened our position in the community since then. But we
  need your help to win! Contributions can be made to: New Brunswick 
Peoples�
  Campaign, c/o 39 Throop Ave. #1, New Brunswick, NJ 08901. Individual
  contributions may not exceed $2200.
  Petitions for candidates are due June 4. We will hold an 
open-to-the-public
  Peoples� Convention, to democratically nominate and elect our Peoples�
  Candidates, on Tuesday, May 21, 5:00-9:00pm, NB Public Library. Everyone�s
  vote counts!
  Then we must mobilize a massive, grassroots, voter registration and
  education drive. This will include petitioning for the Elected School 
Board
  Referendum question. We must also organize social and cultural events to
  motivate and drive our campaign.
  We are in immediate need of a central office, office supplies, volunteers,
  and $$$!
  Put the word out. The city�s gonna change hands.
  Cliff Smith
  39 Throop Ave #1
  NB, NJ 08901
  732.214.8828
  nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
  unite the many, defeat the few!
  unite the many, defeat the few!

_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2598
Sender:"de_plomb" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-12 11:30:05
Subject:Correction in response to having the NBPC convention on May 21st
Message:

Near the end of my response, I mentioned Council members Recine, 
Valenti and Schrum. It was Jimmie Cook, not Valenti, that I meant to 
write.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2599
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-12 14:42:31
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Response to having the NBPC convention on May 21st
Message:

sash-

may 21 is the 1st available day at the library, which is the only public 
space accessible as of now.  until another opportunity presents itself, we 
must work with what we have.

a central location is necessary, in my view, to the convention to allow 
candidates to be heard.

while the community needs student involvement, it must be recognized that 
students are largely transient and temporary residents, and that the 
interests and concerns of permanent residents must take priority.

lastly, most off-campus students will still be around on may 21. & they are 
the generally the ones with the greatest interest in city politics, as 
opposed to those in dormitories.

your concens and contributions are much appreciated.

cliff

----Original Message Follows----
From: "Sash Zlatanovic" <aug_cae@...>
Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
To: nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nbpc] Response to having the NBPC convention on May 21st
Date: Tue, 12 Mar 2002 11:22:51 -0500

I was rather disappointed to learn that the New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
convention would be held on such a late date in May. Although some have
mentioned that students are welcome and should be motivated to vote in this
year's elections, very little has been done to avoid a major problem: by May
21st, the vast majority of Rutgers students would have already left, either
graduating or going back to their principal residence, which for the most
part isn't New Brunswick.

There's no better way to lose credibility and seem tactless in efforts to
attract students than to fail to schedule a convention that is much
earlier--or deliberately be absolutely thoughtless. Or even to find an
alternative venue to hold this convention for that matter. If the New
Brunswick Public Library doesn't have space any earlier, look for another
place. If no other place can be found for the dozen or more people that are
going to vote, which is doubtful in a city of hundreds of blocks, set up
polling places throughout the city in the form of outdoor and indoor ballot
boxes in supporters' homes and in various other places. This was neither
considered by those clumsily organizing the campaign nor even put to a vote.
Clearly, the decision to hold the convention on May 21st was made privately,
utterly oblivious of common sense.

Were these concerns raised at all? Of course they were. I argued on several
occasions, including at February's general meeting of about a dozen people,
to have the convention much earlier, preferably in late April, so that we
could have a larger student turnout and have enough time for our candidates
to iron out any problems that may arise before the June deadline for
petitions. But, no, I'm afraid that isn't the case. Not only will far fewer
students be able to attend the convention, but coverage by the Daily Targum
has been needlessly lost, since they stop publishing in early May.

Apparently, not everyone's opinion or advice counts. Certainly not mine, and
considering that only a couple of people are actually the ones making the
decisions for the campaign, some people are more equal than others. Contrary
to the claim that everyone's vote counts, only a couple of certain people
actually choose who gets to vote and actually count.

Some can say that a decision was indeed made publicly, but considering that
none was made at any of the meetings I've had publicly and privately with
NBPC and that I've been the source of this research concerning campaign
contributions and property ownership by city hall insiders and the fellow in
charge of taking care of papers with the state Election Law Enforcement
Commission (ELEC) and trying to attract student attention to issues
important to the city, it's tough to imagine how I may have overlooked such
a major meeting.

Moreover, it's been sorely overlooked that, following last year's change in
officers which I admit I wasn't yet active with the NBPC to experience,
whoever is supposed to be the treasurer hasn't taken care of the ELEC
papers, which should've been filed soon after the officer change. Clearly,
this raises questions of the competence and legitimacy behind the decisions
being made. Finally, from my understanding, there's no record of any such
decision to have such an inopportune date for the convention being made
publicly.

I expect that these concerns will likely be immaturely and unprofessionally
ignored, but I may just be a cynic at heart. I look forward to any serious
discussion on this matter.

Sash Zlatanovic
New Brunswick, NJ

P.S. Considering the 2,059 votes "gained" by the NBPC in 2000, if one were
to add up all the votes gained by the three candidates for City Council for
the establishment (i.e., R. Recine, B. Valenti, J. Schrum), like Cliff
conveniently had done for alternative candidates, the establishment gained
many more votes than what's being mentioned.



   ***



   Message: 5

   Date: Mon, 11 Mar 2002 20:14:48 +0000
   From: "cliff smith"
   Subject: (unknown)
   New Brunswick
   Peoples� Campaign 2002
   unite the many, defeat the few!
   Dear Community Member,
   As you may know, Mayor James Cahill has announced his campaign for
   re-election in November, with council members, Joseph Egan and Blanquita
   Valenti. It was also reported that, as of March 1, their campaign chest
   already has over $80,000!
   Cahill won in 1998 with 3500 votes, out of 25,000 registered voters. It 
is
   not popular support that maintains his administration, but a tight,
   well-funded organization. Which is also what is needed to defeat him�
   The 2000 New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign council candidates took 2059
votes,
   in our first time out. This is by far the greatest threat Cahill has
faced.
   And we have strengthened our position in the community since then. But we
   need your help to win! Contributions can be made to: New Brunswick
Peoples�
   Campaign, c/o 39 Throop Ave. #1, New Brunswick, NJ 08901. Individual
   contributions may not exceed $2200.
   Petitions for candidates are due June 4. We will hold an
open-to-the-public
   Peoples� Convention, to democratically nominate and elect our Peoples�
   Candidates, on Tuesday, May 21, 5:00-9:00pm, NB Public Library. 
Everyone�s
   vote counts!
   Then we must mobilize a massive, grassroots, voter registration and
   education drive. This will include petitioning for the Elected School
Board
   Referendum question. We must also organize social and cultural events to
   motivate and drive our campaign.
   We are in immediate need of a central office, office supplies, 
volunteers,
   and $$$!
   Put the word out. The city�s gonna change hands.
   Cliff Smith
   39 Throop Ave #1
   NB, NJ 08901
   732.214.8828
   nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
   unite the many, defeat the few!
   unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2602
Sender:"de_plomb" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-12 20:35:41
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Response to having the NBPC convention on May 21st
Message:

To be fair, no, I wasn't silenced.

However, once again, I was never present at any vote whereby an April 
convention was considered. Moreover, as it was aptly and so clearly 
mentioned time and again, most notably during the February general 
meeting, Republicans don't have a voting say. As a reminder, I myself 
am a registered Republican and, for the most part, being railroaded 
into re-registering as something different in order to have a voting 
say in a process that's supposed to be democratic is not only 
unethical but just plain obnoxious.

Concerning an April convention, when I first met Joe at Cafe 52 
sometime in mid-December, we discussed a number of things, including 
the scheduling of the convention. Even at that point in time, I most 
vociferously argued to have the convention held in April.

Also, I've decided to contact a number of places throughout New 
Brunswick concerning open spaces.

Sash Zlatanovic
New Brunswick, NJ

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2604
Sender:"de_plomb" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-14 11:26:50
Subject:May convention
Message:

Out of curiousity, what places have been looked into in terms of 
holding the convention elsewhere? Or was the New Brunswick Public 
Library the only place that was actually considered?

Moreover, what's the problem with holding the convention over a period 
of two days and in two or three locations, rather than limit 
participation to one four-hour session? I called the reservations 
offices for Douglass and College Avenue campuses and discovered that 
costs would be remarkably low between $50 and $300. In addition, rooms 
are in fact available for meetings of upwards of 60 people at the same 
time.

I recall raising the issue of holding an April convention as early as 
late December. Yet, noone has responded to this, aside from claims 
that there's absolutely no other space available--even when I 
suggested the idea four months earlier.

Why can't there be extra effort made to hold a convention over a 
longer period of time in order to increase turnout? Why wasn't there 
an attempt to reserve space at the public library for April as early 
as January and February?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2605
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-14 18:21:10
Subject:Re: [nbpc] May convention
Message:

everyone was encouraged to locate available, accessible venues for the 
convention.  no one came back w/ any. including you, sash. what places did 
you look into prior to our mtg? none that you spoke of until just now.  what 
is your great opposition to the library 21 may?

i sought the public library & the public schools, the only free, public 
spaces i am aware of. the library is booked thru april w/ a george 
washington exhibit. the schools are not favorable to political events.

the library is more central & recognizable to the community than are campus 
centers. & there is no cost. the community must take precedence, w/o 
diminishing the need for student involvement and representation. it is the 
students who must take the step into the community. further, the vast 
majority of peoples' campaign supporters and participants have come from the 
community.

if we do our jobs, we shd expect more than 60 people.  there is no reason to 
expect that a second day wd significantly increase turnout. rather, it is 
giving ourselves until the end of may to organize, instead of april, which 
will increase turnout, if this is your actual concern.

why shd it be alarming that republican party members are restricted in the 
peoples' campaign?  can i vote at the republican convention?  the republican 
party operates 'democratically' among its members. we are have the same 
prerogative, and are independent of the corporate republican and democratic 
parties. everyone makes their own free choice as to their party allegiance. 
why complain?

----Original Message Follows----
From: "de_plomb" <aug_cae@...>
Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
To: nbpeoplescampaign@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nbpc] May convention
Date: Thu, 14 Mar 2002 16:26:50 -0000

Out of curiousity, what places have been looked into in terms of
holding the convention elsewhere? Or was the New Brunswick Public
Library the only place that was actually considered?

Moreover, what's the problem with holding the convention over a period
of two days and in two or three locations, rather than limit
participation to one four-hour session? I called the reservations
offices for Douglass and College Avenue campuses and discovered that
costs would be remarkably low between $50 and $300. In addition, rooms
are in fact available for meetings of upwards of 60 people at the same
time.

I recall raising the issue of holding an April convention as early as
late December. Yet, noone has responded to this, aside from claims
that there's absolutely no other space available--even when I
suggested the idea four months earlier.

Why can't there be extra effort made to hold a convention over a
longer period of time in order to increase turnout? Why wasn't there
an attempt to reserve space at the public library for April as early
as January and February?








unite the many, defeat the few!


_________________________________________________________________
Chat with friends online, try MSN Messenger: http://messenger.msn.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2606
Sender:"de_plomb" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-15 12:31:53
Subject:Re: [nbpc] May convention
Message:

Cliff, perhaps your memory is as faulty as your intelligence. Need I 
remind you that I raised the issue of having the convention earlier 
back in late December? Are you that much of a twit that you weren't 
even paying attention?

And, interestingly enough, you still haven't answered my earlier 
questions. You answer my question about what other venues were looked 
into with another question. In addition, your claim that I had 
nothing before the March meeting is an outright lie. 

Now, it's interesting that you refer to students as transients and 
imply that students aren't actually part of the community. Well, 
considering that students do have many other things to do than just 
follow your whims and edicts, deliberately making it difficult or 
simply being so incompetent as to have much lower student turnout 
doesn't exactly encourage them to be part of the community, now does 
it?

In other words, if it were made easier for students to participate, 
then they would be more likely to be part of the community. Surely, 
Cliff, even you could understand that.

Furthermore, the issues that are salient and important to the 
community also impact students, or have you already forgotten this? 
By describing students as "transients"--even though most are in New 
Brunswick for four years or more--you deliberately distinguish them 
from the rest of the community or make absolutely no extra effort to 
increase student turnout.

Noone can deny that students have class schedules. And noone can deny 
that students need to work to pay for school and other things. But, 
apparently, in not making an extra effort to increase student turnout 
and encourage participation, this has fallen deaf on Cliff's ears.

What could've been done? I don't argue with having the convention at 
the library. I do argue, however, that the convention should've 
included something oncampus and, at least for this oncampus aspect, 
been held earlier. Alternative venues were NOT looked into by the 
NBPC leadership (which doesn't include me and most others, save for 
Cliff). However, in doing Cliff's job, I found out what a room for 60 
would cost oncampus for four hours: only about $100. I would suggest 
that, rather than getting constantly arrested, Cliff should save some 
of his money and pool it together with several others to pay for this 
room. Unfortunately, because of ineptness, this wasn't even realized.





--- In nbpeoplescampaign@y..., "cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@h...> 
wrote:
> everyone was encouraged to locate available, accessible venues for 
the 
> convention.  no one came back w/ any. including you, sash. what 
places did 
> you look into prior to our mtg? none that you spoke of until just 
now.  what 
> is your great opposition to the library 21 may?
> 
> i sought the public library & the public schools, the only free, 
public 
> spaces i am aware of. the library is booked thru april w/ a george 
> washington exhibit. the schools are not favorable to political 
events.
> 
> the library is more central & recognizable to the community than 
are campus 
> centers. & there is no cost. the community must take precedence, 
w/o 
> diminishing the need for student involvement and representation. it 
is the 
> students who must take the step into the community. further, the 
vast 
> majority of peoples' campaign supporters and participants have come 
from the 
> community.
> 
> if we do our jobs, we shd expect more than 60 people.  there is no 
reason to 
> expect that a second day wd significantly increase turnout. rather, 
it is 
> giving ourselves until the end of may to organize, instead of 
april, which 
> will increase turnout, if this is your actual concern.
> 
> why shd it be alarming that republican party members are restricted 
in the 
> peoples' campaign?  can i vote at the republican convention?  the 
republican 
> party operates 'democratically' among its members. we are have the 
same 
> prerogative, and are independent of the corporate republican and 
democratic 
> parties. everyone makes their own free choice as to their party 
allegiance. 
> why complain?

Post ID:2607
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-19 11:13:17
Subject:March 23rd-Political Prisoner EVENT
Message:

An evening in solidarity with ALL POLITICAL PRISONERS in the U.S.!!
FREEDOM NOW!!

Come and hear messages of solidarity, updates on the cases of U.S. political 
prisoners, cultural performances and more...

Panelists:
Safiya Bukhari, Jericho
Paulette d'Autiel, Leonard Peltier
Ben Ramos, ProLibertad
Andres G0omez, Free the Miami Five/Cuban Political Prisoners

and Representatives from the Free Mumia Coalition, Move 9, and David Wong 
Support Committee

SATURDAY MARCH 23RD, 2002 4PM AT
MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. AUDITORIUM
310 W43RD ST. (BETWEEN 8TH-9TH AVENUES)

Suggested donation: $10 for the commissary of all political prisoners!! (no 
one will be turned away for lack of Funds)

Sponsored by: The Free Mumia Coalition, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, 
Leonard Peltier Committee, The Free The Miami Five/Cuban Political Prisoners 
NYC Committee, and the Jericho Movement

Endorsers: Casa de las Americas, International Action Center, 
Inter-Religious Foundation for Community Organizing, The U.S. Health care 
trade union Committee, Partido Socialista Dominicano, and the Vieques 
Support Campaign

Post ID:2609
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-19 17:31:37
Subject:Another World Is Possible: Book Tour at Rutgers!
Message:

Jeremy Glick, graduate student at the English Department and editor of
_Another World Is Possible: Conversations in a Time of Terror_, will bring
the Another World is Possible book tour to Rutgers on
Monday, March 25
8:00 PM-11:00 PM
Trayes Hall A
Douglass College Center
Douglass College; Rutgers University; New Brunswick, NJ
The event is free, and open to the public; it will feature performance,
film, and discussion! It promises to be an enlightening, important event.
All are encouraged to attend!

See http://www.anotherworldispossible.net/ for more information!

Sponsored by the Women's Defense Coalition
                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2610
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-20 08:55:03
Subject:nb activists trial today, open to the public
Message:

                     The trial of community activists, Cliff and Joe Smith, 
arrested at the 15 January New Brunswick Board of Education meeting, is 
scheduled for 20 March, 5:30pm, in the NB Municipal Courthouse.

                     The activists, who have long organized for an elected 
school board, were charged with disrupting a public meeting, after Cliff 
Smith distributed copies of recent, low standardized test scores. Joe Smith 
was also charged with two counts of simple assault.

                     The activists have filed their own charges of assault 
against High School Principal Pierre Embry, and Donald Bowling, who 
physically threw them from the meeting. �The administration prefers thug 
tactics to cover up their criminal failure of New Brunswick�s youth,� said 
Joe Smith. �No amount of arrests and intimidation will help raise these test 
scores.�

                     11th grade students scored 51% passing in the High 
School Proficiency Test, required for graduation. This is down from 74.5% in 
1999. Lincoln School 4th graders scored 12.5% passing their own test. The 
district�s scores are the lowest in Middlesex County.

                     New Brunswick has the only un-elected Board of 
Education in Middlesex County. The Board is instead appointed by Mayor 
Cahill, who is up for election in November. The activists state that they 
are being strong-armed as an opening salvo in Cahill�s campaign.






unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2611
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-20 13:17:10
Subject:The Ponce Massacre
Message:

El Partido Nacionalista de Puerto Rico, Junta de Nueva
York

The New York City Junta of the Puerto Rican
Nationalist Party

les invita a
Invites you to

una conmemoraci�n de:
A commemotation of:

La Masacre de Ponce
The Ponce Massacre

el d�a 21 de Marzo del 2002
on March 21st of 2002

en Galer�a MIXTA
1706 de Lexington Ave. (esquina con la calle 107)

7:30 pm

"Misa Popular" oficiada por el Padre Luis Barrios
"dando espacio a la espiritualidad pol�tica
Nacionalista"

Mon�logo por Alma Villegas, "Testimonio de Do�a
Dominga"

"La Patria es Valor y Sacrificio"
Don Pedro Albizu Campos
___________________________________
�Viva la Rep�blica!
�Abajo los asesinos!

Long Live the Republic!
Down with the assassins!

This is what Bol�var M�rquez, a young Puerto Rican
Nationalist wrote with his own blood on the pavement
as he laid dying on Palm Sunday, March 21st of 1937, a
day which will be remembered in our history as the
date of the cruelest act committed by the US invaders
in Puerto Rico. Bol�var M�rquez passed onto eternity
along with over 20 other Puerto Rican patriots who
were assassinated in the southern town of Ponce during
a peaceful demonstration organized by the Nationalist
Party in the city of Ponce where the Cadets of the
Republic (Cadetes de la Rep�blica) and the Daughters
of Liberty (Hijas de la Libertad) gathered to march.

Once more the local police force served as the murder
weapon of the colonial oppressor. The police
indiscriminately opened fire on a group of
Nationalists who were about to begin the peaceful
march demanding the release of Puerto Rican political
prisoners, including Albizu Campos. This tragic act is
known as La Masacre de Ponce (the Ponce Massacre).
Alongside the fallen martyrs, 150 men, women, and
children were injured by machinegun fire.

"La independencia requiere, como todo supremo bien, el
sacrificio de todo lo m�s sabio, noble y puro de la
nacionalidad."

"Independence requires, as does every supreme good,
the sacrifice of all that is most wise, noble and pure
of nationality."

Don Pedro Albizu Campos

During that ten minute shooting at the Ponce Massacre,
the flag-bearer of the Cadets of the Republic was
killed. Carmen Fern�ndez then tried to take the flag
herself when she saw the flag-bearer fall, she was
shot and gravely injured. At that point, Dominga Cruz
Bacerril, a lady from Mayag�ez who had already taken
cover, saw the flag fall on the pavement. She ran up
to the flag, picked it up, waved it and then ran with
it towards a close by hospital without being harmed.
When asked why she exposed herself to such danger, she
calmly answered: "El Maestro has told us that the flag
must always be raised up high." "The Teacher" she
referred to was Don Pedro Albizu Campos.

As it is evident in the photographs taken by a
journalist, the members of the Nationalist Party and
the Cadets of the Republic ("black shirts") were
unarmed and trapped by the police who shot them at
close range. This crime was committed under direct
orders of General Winship, the colonial governor of
the island at the time. After this act of terrorism by
the colonial government, the imprisoned Nationalist
leaders were transferred to Atlanta.

A year later Winship was executed by a team of
Nationalists when  he returned to Ponce to celebrate
another anniversary of the US invasion.  Angel Esteban
Antongiorgi one of the members of the commando, fired
his weapon until he ran out of bullets before being
killed by a police officer.




_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

7:30 pm

"dando espacio a la espiritualidad pol�tica
Nacionalista"

Mon�logo por Alma Villegas, "Testimonio de Do�a
Dominga"

"La Patria es Valor y Sacrificio"
Don Pedro Albizu Campos
___________________________________
�Viva la Rep�blica!
�Abajo los asesinos!

Long Live the Republic!
Down with the assassins!

This is what Bol�var M�rquez, a young Puerto Rican
Nationalist wrote with his own blood on the pavement
as he laid dying on Palm Sunday, March 21st of 1937, a
day which will be remembered in our history as the
date of the cruelest act committed by the US invaders
in Puerto Rico. Bol�var M�rquez passed onto eternity
along with over 20 other Puerto Rican patriots who
were assassinated in the southern town of Ponce during
a peaceful demonstration organized by the Nationalist
Party in the city of Ponce where the Cadets of the
Republic (Cadetes de la Rep�blica) and the Daughters
of Liberty (Hijas de la Libertad) gathered to march.

Once more the local police force served as the murder
weapon of the colonial oppressor. The police
indiscriminately opened fire on a group of
Nationalists who were about to begin the peaceful
march demanding the release of Puerto Rican political
prisoners, including Albizu Campos. This tragic act is
known as La Masacre de Ponce (the Ponce Massacre).
Alongside the fallen martyrs, 150 men, women, and
children were injured by machinegun fire.

"La independencia requiere, como todo supremo bien, el
sacrificio de todo lo m�s sabio, noble y puro de la
nacionalidad."

"Independence requires, as does every supreme good,
the sacrifice of all that is most wise, noble and pure
of nationality."

Don Pedro Albizu Campos

During that ten minute shooting at the Ponce Massacre,
the flag-bearer of the Cadets of the Republic was
killed. Carmen Fern�ndez then tried to take the flag
herself when she saw the flag-bearer fall, she was
shot and gravely injured. At that point, Dominga Cruz
Bacerril, a lady from Mayag�ez who had already taken
cover, saw the flag fall on the pavement. She ran up
to the flag, picked it up, waved it and then ran with
it towards a close by hospital without being harmed.
When asked why she exposed herself to such danger, she
calmly answered: "El Maestro has told us that the flag
must always be raised up high." "The Teacher" she
referred to was Don Pedro Albizu Campos.

As it is evident in the photographs taken by a
journalist, the members of the Nationalist Party and
the Cadets of the Republic ("black shirts") were
unarmed and trapped by the police who shot them at
close range. This crime was committed under direct
orders of General Winship, the colonial governor of
the island at the time. After this act of terrorism by
the colonial government, the imprisoned Nationalist
leaders were transferred to Atlanta.

A year later Winship was executed by a team of
Nationalists when  he returned to Ponce to celebrate
another anniversary of the US invasion.  Angel Esteban
Antongiorgi one of the members of the commando, fired
his weapon until he ran out of bullets before being
killed by a police officer.

Post ID:2613
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-25 18:26:23
Subject:today's home news tribune
Message:

Monday's letters, e-mails to the Home News Tribune

               Published in the Home News Tribune 03/25/02


               Is Marshall getting favored treatment?

               Convicted criminal and former New Brunswick narcotics 
detective James Marshall must face the court as any other member of the
community. His defense strategy of stall and evade must be put to rest.

               Enjoying free-on-appeal status from his four-year brothel 
sentence, Marshall sought, at his March 11 hearing, to postpone his 
drug-running charges until September, after the anticipated retirement of 
Judge Barnett Hoffman. Further, he attempts to remove his
case from the scene of the crime, to a court outside Middlesex County.  He 
still faces three more trials.

               Why does Marshall get favored treatment? Who is afraid of 
Marshall's conviction? Who was the clientele in his Paterson Street
brothel, across the street from the Middlesex County Administration 
Building? Who was a partner in its operation? Why has the New Brunswick 
Police Department not retracted its false suspect profile of a "young Black 
male" in the fake Marshall/Chinchilla retirement-scheme shooting at Remsen 
and Baldwin in 1998 and apologized for the $10,000 reward, which endangered 
the safety of every black youth in the city?

               Why was Carolyn Adams killed? And how did New Brunswick 
police officer Kenny Ford die? When Mayor James Cahill took the stand as a 
character witness for Marshall and Marco Chinchilla was he a liar or a fool? 
The people want answers.

               Cliff Smith
               NEW BRUNSWICK







unite the many, defeat the few!

McGreevey,

you met me @ your visit to rutgers - the "vote mcgreevey" poster with 
"Outlaw White Supremacy" on the back. We successfully stood up to the far 
right-wing during the election '01 & we must double our efforts with all the 
resources the governor's office has.

from your position a proper alliance with the people can help "root out" 
this state run terrorism - racist profiling; National Oppression! (biggest 
terror aggressions in usa are sexual oppression, national oppression, 
economic oppression)

OPEN ALL FILES ON POLICE  -
STATE, LOCAL, & NATIONAL!
democracy!

and while we're talking, i suggest you join the lawsuit with the woman suing 
the companies that profited from slavery, go after all the Imperial Masters, 
& get our cities our fullest Abbott resources!

the new jersey independent forces currently cannot win a campaign for 
governor, but we can swing a primary to defeat the far right democrat.

joe smith

>Subject: [poprogress] STOP NJ FROM SEALING STATE TROOPERS RECORDS!
>Date: Wed, 27 Mar 2002 05:39:57 EST
>
>URGENT ACTION!   MUST ACT ON THIS BY APRIL 20TH ! ! !
>
>NJ is now proposing regulation that would make the records
>of the State Troopers confidential information that the public
>would not be able to access!  This is just another step
>to protect the police and one more step toward making
>NJ a police state!
>
>In light of all that documentation that has come out about
>racial profiling, this is an insult to the integrity of all justice
>seeking people and human rights activists.
>
>They are taking public comment on this issue until April 20th.
>So it is imperative that we act NOW!
>
>We must call, write and e-mail to stop this from happening!
>
>PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE call Governor James McGreevey
>now at (609)292-6000 and demand that these records remain opened
>to the public!
>Please also e-mail him at www.state.nj.us/governor/govmail.html
>
>PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE call Attorney General David Samson
>at (609)292-4925.
>Please also e-mail him at citizens.services@...
>
>Below is a form letter that can be mailed.  Simply
>print it out and send it.   The AG's address and the
>Governor's address is listed on the letter.
>
>AND PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE PASS THIS ON!
>IF YOU DON'T LIVE IN NEW JERSEY, PLEASE PASS
>THIS ON TO THOSE WHO  DO!
>
>And if you can print out copies of the letter and get
>others to sign and mail it, please do so.
>
>THANKS!   KEEP ON FIGHTING FOR JUSTICE AND
>NEVER GIVE UP ! ! !
>
>
>
>Attorney General David Samson
>Office of the Attorney General
>P.O. Box 080
>Trenton, New Jersey   08625-0080
>
>
>I am against sealing state troopers records and demand that these records 
>be
>kept opened to the public!
>
>It is  appalling that after all of the proof that has come to the fore 
>about
>State Trooper misconduct and racial profiling, that the strongest action 
>that
>the State is now seeking pertaining to this issue is to further protect the
>Troopers by sealing their records from the public!    In light of the
>Troopers  horrific and racists patterns, the proposal to seal the state
>troopers record from the public is an affront to the intelligence of the
>citizenry of this state, especially members of the Black and Latinos
>communities.
>
>We are a Republic, which means for the people and by the people.   The 
>people
>pay the salaries of the troopers and the people have a right to have access
>to information pertaining to their job performance!   State Troopers are
>public employees that are employed by the State.!  And they, along with 
>every
>other state employee, are accountable to the people of the state in which
>they work!  And as part of that accountability,  we the people have a right
>to review their records as it relates to their public employment.   This is
>especially important when it comes to those who we hold responsible for
>ensuring public safety, (i.e. the troopers) since any negativity associated
>with their performance can have serious consequences on our society.
>
>We will not allow the continuous erosion of our civil rights ! ! !  Sealing
>these records is one more step toward making New Jersey an outright police
>state.   And I reiterate my demand to keep the records of the state 
>troopers
>opened to the public!
>
>

Post ID:2617
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-29 12:02:12
Subject:Vieques and Leonard!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read and forward out these 
two important messages around the local organizing work for Vieques and an 
Update on our brother Political Prisoner Leonard Peltier.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________
>Please Pass ON!
>
>The U.S. Navy has announced for Monday, April 1st, the renewal of bombing 
>practices on the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico. These war rehearsals will 
>take place despite the continued protests by the people living on the 
>island.  The Committee for the Rescue & Development of Vieques has called 
>on everyone to protest this outrage.
>
>Monday, April 1
>THE DAY U.S. NAVY BOMBINGS BEGIN WE WILL STAND WITH THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES
>
>David Sanes Brigade 6:AM
>Protest at Good Morning America and the Today Show
>46St. and 6th Ave  <Bring flags, posters and banners>
>For more info. call (917) 622-5847
>
>Vieques Support Campaign, 4:30 PM
>Protest at the Office of Federal Affairs of Puerto Rico
>Located at 3 Park Avenue (Between 33RD AND 34TH ST.)
>in Manhattan, New York City
>For more info.
>http://palfrente.tripod.com
>E-mail viequessc@...
_______________________________________________________________________

UNTIL FREEDOM IS WON!
UPDATE ON THE PELTIER CAMPAIGN FOR TRUTH AND JUSTICE

INCLUDED IN THIS MESSAGE:
Updates on the Motion to Reduce Leonard's Sentence, Progress Made Toward
Obtaining New Evidence, Civil Rights Case, Government Reform Committee

Dear Friends,

We are writing today with both good and bad news on the case of Leonard
Peltier.  But before we begin we want to thank all of you who have been
sponsoring LPDC speakers and organizing Peltier events in your communities.
Raising awareness continues to be essential and supporters have organized
several successful events.   Let's keep the LPDC speakers bureau busy and
word of Leonard's case flowing!  We also want to let you know that there
will be three important events on June 26 marking 27 years since the
shoot-out occurred.  They include gatherings in Oglala, South Dakota, San
Francisco, California and Boston, Massachusetts.  We encourage you to plan
on attending one of these events or organizing something in your community.
More details will be released soon.

BAD NEWS, BUT NOT SURPRISING
We regret to announce that the motion to reduce Leonard's sentence was
denied by the U.S. District Court of North Dakota.  We expected this case to
be a challenge because of the many procedural obstacles it involved combined
with the political nature of the Peltier case, especially in this district.
However, we had hoped for more fairness given that Judge Benson, who tried
Leonard, is no longer hearing cases.

Judge Magnison denied the motion without a hearing based upon issues of
timeliness.  A motion to reduce sentence is supposed to be filed within a
year following a conviction.  However, we argued that filing at this late
date was justified because of significant developments that occurred since
trial, citing cases in which exceptions had been made due to extraordinary
circumstances.  The court said that the significant developments in question
(government admission that it can't prove who shot agents/ballistics) had
already been litigated.  Judge Magnison refused to consider these issues
despite the clearly different character of the case, which sought a review
of sentence and not a new trial like before. Attorney Eric Seitz is
appealing the decision to the Eighth Circuit.

NOW WHAT?
We MUST obtain new evidence and demand a new trial for Leonard Peltier.  We
are confident that key evidence exists in the thousands of documents that
are withheld by the FBI and fortunately, we are moving closer to obtaining
them.

GOOD NEWS!
Thanks to the persistent letters of supporters in Massachusetts,
Representative Barney Frank wrote to the FBI insisting that the withheld
documents be released given Clinton's Executive Order requiring the
disclosure of documents after the passage of 25 years.  The FBI Office of
Public and Congressional Affairs responded by saying, "After receipt of your
letter.the FBI consulted with the National Archives and Records
Administration (NARA) to request that the investigative records pertaining
to Mr. Peltier that are 25 years or older be considered of significant
historical interest subject to declassification review.  NARA agreed and the
process of declassification review has begun.  Upon completion, the material
will be accessioned to NARA and a declassified copy will be provided to your
office.  We anticipate completion of this project by the end of the year."
Attorney Mike Kuzma, who is handling Leonard's FOIA requests, wrote to NARA
to learn when the declassification would be completed.  Mike also asked that
he be provided copies of the documents.  NARA responded, "We have been
informed that the records are still in the physical and legal custody of the
FBI.  The FBI has completed its declassification review and is currently
processing the records for transfer to NARA and their subsequent public
release.  The transfer is expected to occur in May of this year.  Following
the transfer, NARA may require additional time to prepare for the public
release of the records."  This is a very positive development for us and
strengthens our chances for obtaining new information.  Furthermore, the
documents are now protected against destruction because of their historical
classification.  The battle is not over, as we expect the documents to be
partly censored for reasons of "national security" like before.  But, we
plan to demand the full release and exposure of the documents in court.

It should also be noted that Mike Kuzma continues to pursue the documents
through the Freedom of Information Act process.  Requests have been
submitted to FBI headquarters and numerous field offices across the country.
With the exception of Portland, Oregon, all offices have reported that they
possess records.  We anticipate filing one or several suits to demand the
release of these documents in the near future.  Mike Kuzma is also working
with law students involved in the Innocence Project of Osgoode Hall and the
LPDC of Canada to obtain documents generated around the extradition.

MORE GOOD NEWS!
The civil rights complaint against the FBI has been drafted and the
finishing touches are being added now.   This case argues that the FBI
violated Leonard's Constitutional Rights by lying to the Department of
Justice, former President Clinton, the Parole Commission, and the public
with the sole intention of denying Leonard fair clemency and parole reviews,
thus costing him his long deserved freedom.  We plan to do a major press
blitz on the day the case is filed and we will need your participation.
This is our chance to undo much of the disinformation disseminated by the
FBI through the press in recent years.  Please be prepared to forward the
press release to your local media.  We will let you know when we determine
the exact date it will be filed.  Please stay tuned.

NOTE:  This case represents another opportunity to access the withheld FBI
documents through discovery.

KEEP PUSHING CONGRESS FOR INVESTIGATIONS!
Meanwhile, a window of opportunity continues to exist with the House
Committee on Government Reform.  As you know this committee is planning to
investigate cases of FBI misconduct leading to wrongful convictions.  We
must press the Reform Committee to shine its spot light on Leonard's case.
Please continue to write Representative Burton on a regular basis, and cc
your letters to your representative. A recent phone call to Rep Burton's
office indicates that he is collecting and taking notice of our letters.
Please send us copies of any response letters you receive from officials so
that we can track their positions.

LET US KNOW
Let us know if you are organizing anything for Leonard whether it be for
June 26 or any other date so that we can help by publicizing it. Do not
hesitate to contact us to share your ideas and suggestions about building
pressure and awareness for the freedom of Leonard Peltier!

Thank you.

In Solidarity,
LPDC







_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign sends this update out in hopes that folks 
will come today at 4:30pm to express solidarity with the people of Vieques!! 
  We also want to call to attention of the recent arrests of five Puerto 
Rican Women who enganged in Civil disobedience this morning!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________

Today FIVE PUERTO RICAN WOMEN were arrested for engaging in civil 
disobedience on the island of Vieques.  All five women were members of the 
Puerto Rican Independence Party (PIP). There names are:

Mar�a de Lourdes Santiago, Vicve President of the PIP,
Irma Rodr�guez, Leader of the San Juan PIP
Dra. Mayrna Rodr�guez, Leader of PIP in Ponce;
Mar�a Elena Rodr�guez, Muncipal Sentaor of the PIP in Najarinto
Maribel Arroyo, Sanb Juan PIP Militant.

and today...

Vieques Support Campaign, 4:30 PM
Protest at the Office of Federal Affairs of Puerto Rico
Located at 3 Park Avenue (Between 33RD AND 34TH ST.)
in Manhattan, New York City

Subject:Fwd: File - friends and colleagues
Message:

for new brunswick news & dialogue
>
>Hola,
>
>I urge you to invite your friends and colleagues to join the TheHubCityNJ 
>group, a free, easy-to-use E-mail group service.
>
>Information Is Power.  If your friends and colleagues wish to belong to 
>TheHubCityNJ, they may subscribe by sending an E-mail to
>
>TheHubCityNJ-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>�Gracias!
>
>Guillo
>Moderator, TheHubCityNJ
>
>
>
>PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE:
>
>To unsubscribe from this group, send an E-mail to:
>TheHubCityNJ-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>As a subscriber to the group, you can react to this message by replying to 
>this E-mail.  The whole group will be able to read ANY reply/reaction.  
>PLEASE REFRAIN FROM ANY REPLY UNLESS YOU WANT THE WHOLE GROUP TO SEE IT.  
>To communicate only with a sender, create a new message and send it to that 
>individual's E-mail address.
>
>To send messages to members of this group, simply send E-mail to:
>TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
>
>The following behavior will not be tolerated in this group:
>
>* Inappropriate Material
>* Harassment of any type
>* Profanity, Libel, Insults, Personal Attacks or Verbal/Written Abuse of 
>any kind
>* Threats of Physical Harm
>
>If you post a message in this group it must be done in a civilized and 
>respectful manner.  It is our belief that we must take the high road as a 
>community when we criticize people and issues.  Those who want to partake 
>in personal and insulting attacks are not welcomed in this group.
>
>If you wish to report a claim of the above mentioned inappropriate 
>behavior, please E-mail TheHubCityNJ-owner@yahoogroups.com
>
>If someone you know wishes to belong to TheHubCityNJ, they may subscribe by 
>sending an E-mail to:
>TheHubCityNJ-subscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>The group also permits us to share chat rooms, a calendar, files, links to 
>web sites, etc. Please visit
>http://www.yahoogroups.com/group/ TheHubCityNJ
>to see all the features.
>
>�Gracias!
>
>Guillo
>Moderator, TheHubCityNJ
>
>
>Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>

has been sent to you by cliffsmith69@....

it. Use it. Then, fill it up again.
https://www.starbucks.com/shop/reload.asp?ci=672

\----------------------------------------------------------/


Protests Greet Resumption of Navy Bombing on Vieques

April 2, 2002 

By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


Passions flared on Monday as Navy planes began their first
day of a new round of exercises at a contested firing range
on a Puerto Rican island.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/02/national/02PUER.html?ex=1018776948&ei=1&en=ed633ba677a97f56

or other creative advertising opportunities with The
New York Times on the Web, please contact
onlinesales@... or visit our online media
kit at http://www.nytimes.com/adinfo

For general information about NYTimes.com, write to 
help@....

Post ID:2625
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-03 08:12:13
Subject:Forum on Racist Profiling, April 4, 2002
Message:

FORUM ON RACIST PROFILING

THURSDAY APRIL 4TH 7:30PM
DOUGLASS COLLEGE CENTER, NJC LOUNGE (2nd FLOOR)

"The War at Home"

A Community Activist Perspective

April 4th 2002 will mark the 34th anniversary of the assassination of Martin
Luther King Jr. To commemorate this event, the Community Empowerment Project
(CEP) will hold a forum on the ongoing struggle against racist profiling in
the US and specifically in New Jersey. The featured speakers are local
Afro-American grassroots community leaders currently investigating civil
rights violations with the help of Rutgers students interning with the CEP's
Civil Rights Legal Defense Program.

Featured Speakers:

VICKIE WHITE

Chairwoman of 'Southside Pride'
(Highland Park)

Southside Pride, a grassroots community organization, is investigating
widespread violations of civil rights in Highland Park after Neo-Nazi
skinheads repeatedly attacked Afro-American youth and allegedly avoided
prosecution for months due to family connections in the local government.

LINDA ANDERSON

Chairwoman of 'About Face'
(Franklin)

About Face, a grassroots community organization, is investigating the
potential wrongful conviction of Herman Gaines, a young Afro-American father
who was convicted of manslaughter solely based on the testimony of four
witnesses allegedly coerced to give false statements by Franklin police.

Sponsored by the Douglass College Government Association, Women's Defense
Coalition and the Student Action Union.

The Civil Rights Legal Defense Program is an initiative of the Community
Empowerment Project (CEP). The CEP is a registered non-profit, non-partisan
organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and the empowerment of
local communities through progressive legal, political, cultural and social
programs.


                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2626
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-03 08:15:07
Subject:Nike Wages: Educating For Justice, April 18
Message:

On Thursday, April 18th, at 7pm in the Labor Education Center
Auditorium, Jim Keady and Leslie Kretzu of Educating for Justice will be
presenting a multi media presentation on Corporate Accountability,
specifically
Nike's exploitative labor practices in Indonesia. Jim Keady was a soccer
coach at St. Johns University until he spoke out against the university's
contracts with Nike and was fired. Leslie Kretzu, a former track star,
recently helped carry the Olympic torch across the country to Salt Lake
City.
During her leg of the tour, she ran barefoot through the icy streets of
Philadelphia to demonstrate her solidarity with Nike workers. In 2000, Jim
and
Leslie spent several weeks living in Indonesia on the same amount of money
as
that paid to Nike subcontractors.

Part of the proceeds generated by Educating for Justice's speaking
tour will go towards funding the establishment of an Education and Resource
Center in Tangerang, Indonesia. In the future, Educating For Justice will
give students the opportunity to visit and/or teach at the Education and
Research Center.

Please, also note that EFJ currently has two openings for interns in their
Belmar, NJ office.

If you would like more info about the presentation, please visit
www.nikewages.org

Or contact Christine Mingolla at 212-532-1319 or  cmingolla@....

Sponsored by the Labor Studies Department and Douglass College Government
Association.

                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org

Post ID:2627
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-03 11:28:14
Subject:Are you a Douglass student interested in making change?
Message:

If you're interested in organizing, struggling and making change around a
variety of issues, including fighting racism, standing up for student
democracy and student rights, supporting women's services, and opposing the
state budget cuts, you have an opportunity to be involved and make things
happen:

Run for Douglass College Government Association. The DCGA administers
financial allocations to student organizations, represents students to the
administration, lobbies for student issues, and has the ability to affect
university, city and state policy.

The Douglass United Ticket is a progressive ticket dedicated to a platform
of action and support of key student issues at the College. Find out more
about the ticket at http://douglassunited.pathbot.com/.

We will be holding an info session and meeting tonight at 9:30 PM in the RU
Women's Center on the third floor of the Douglass College Center. Hope to
see you there!

If you cannot attend, but are interested in running on the ticket, please
contact Charlotte at ckates@eden, or Audrey at audreya@eden.

-Charlotte

!!!!from the new brunswick peoples campaign - Win the Elected Board of Ed. 
Nov2002!!!!

defeating racist profiling & underfunded, segregated NB schools - that lack 
a democratically elected board of education - are very similar struggles. 
both are offsprings of US Imperialism's white supremacist relationship to 
oppressed nations, and both will be defeated simotaneously with the 
democratic struggle for self-determination. the new brunswick peoples 
campaign would like to reach out to CEP in an effort to build a democratic 
united front against US Imperialism that will organize locally aroud the 
issue of Peoples Democracy.

FYI
new brunswick activists struggling to win the elected board of education 
would like to make CEP aware of the court case involving ourselves v. NB 
high school principal Pierre Embrey, Community Relations for NB police agent 
Donald Bowling. activist Cliff Smith is being charged w/disrupting a public 
meeting & Joe Smith is being charged w/disrupting a public meeting & 2 
counts of simple assault. Embrey & Bowling are being charged w/assault by 
each activist. this is a very serious case for any groups or individuals 
looking to freely organize in NB without the threat of attacks from city 
officials who very livelyhoods are threatened by our organizing.

the activists case will resume april 19 @10:00am
for more information contact joe smith 732.296.7172 or 973.485.6280

>"The War at Home"
>
>A Community Activist Perspective
>
>April 4th 2002 will mark the 34th anniversary of the assassination of 
>Martin
>Luther King Jr. To commemorate this event, the Community Empowerment 
>Project
>(CEP) will hold a forum on the ongoing struggle against racist profiling in
>the US and specifically in New Jersey. The featured speakers are local
>Afro-American grassroots community leaders currently investigating civil
>rights violations with the help of Rutgers students interning with the 
>CEP's
>Civil Rights Legal Defense Program.
>
>Featured Speakers:
>
>VICKIE WHITE
>
>Chairwoman of 'Southside Pride'
>(Highland Park)
>
>Southside Pride, a grassroots community organization, is investigating
>widespread violations of civil rights in Highland Park after Neo-Nazi
>skinheads repeatedly attacked Afro-American youth and allegedly avoided
>prosecution for months due to family connections in the local government.
>
>LINDA ANDERSON
>
>Chairwoman of 'About Face'
>(Franklin)
>
>About Face, a grassroots community organization, is investigating the
>potential wrongful conviction of Herman Gaines, a young Afro-American 
>father
>who was convicted of manslaughter solely based on the testimony of four
>witnesses allegedly coerced to give false statements by Franklin police.

>Coalition and the Student Action Union.

Re: C4J MEETING SAT. APRIL 6, 2002

why march in trenton while we can win an election in newark?
should not our revolution produce the most tangible results for our efforts?

Entry found for "tangible"

	 tangible adj

1. able to be touched or perceived through the sense of touch

2. capable of being understood and evaluated, and therefore regarded as real

3. capable of being given a physical existence

n.  something that has a physical form, especially a financial asset (often 
used in the plural)

Post ID:2630
Sender:"Howard Nelson" <howardnelson@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-03 23:00:06
Subject:Re: [poprogress] dear POP & C4J
Message:

People's Campaign --

You assume one occurrence excludes the other and that one occurrence is more
important than the other for the people to be served by both occurrences.

A question you imply is: What is the hierarchy of priorities for the
greatest good for those in greatest need? How ought we to best distribute
our time, energy, and resources? Are the various life-saving bills in the
state legislature and other C4J Demands worth our support and pressuring for
greater specificity and effectiveness? How much support you ask? Good
question. When we're not marching in Trenton ought we, as individuals, be
funding, marching, educating, etc in Newark to aid in Ras' election?

 Two new C4J demands are in the areas of statewide public school education
and fair assignment of statewide government construction contracts to
minority group construction companies and hiring of minority group labor.
Are you folks on board?

Please ask Tracey to keep us posted on upcoming events and efforts. We'll
keep you advised thru this poprogress list regarding our C4J Demands and
efforts, and POP's efforts as well.

Howard

Post ID:2632

Subject:Solidarity for Leonard and DRUM!!

PRESS RELEASE FOR LEONARD PELTIER BELOW!
Friends,

Below is the press release for the lawsuit that will be filed TOMORROW on
Leonard Peltier's behalf.  Please forward it far and wide to your local
media and to other supporters.  Please be sure that the release date remains
in tact.  We do not want coverage on this before the case is filed tomorrow.
We do, however, want to give reporters a chance to write their stories today
so that it can hit the press tomorrow.  Also note that this has been
distributed to all national news sources already, so we just need to focus
on everyone's local press.  You may want to follow up with phone calls to
your paper, radio and TV stations to request they cover the story given that
a local support group or supporters exist in the area.  Let us know if you
have any questions.  THANK you for your help and support!

In Solidarity,
LPDC

PS A formatted version can be downloaded from our web site:
http://www.freepeltier.org
________________________________________________________
RELEASE DATE:  THURSDAY, APRIL 4, 2002

Contact:
Leonard Peltier Defense Committee (785) 842-5774; lpdc@...


NATIVE AMERICAN ACTIVIST FILES LAWSUIT AGAINST FBI

        Former FBI Director Louis Freeh is named as a defendant in a lawsuit
filed today by attorneys for imprisoned Native American activist, Leonard
Peltier.  Freeh, along with the FBI Agents Association and a long list of
active FBI agents, are accused of violating Peltier's Constitutional rights
by making false and unsupported statements to the public, the Department of
Justice, the United States Parole Commission, and former President Clinton.
The complaint, filed in U.S. District Court, Washington D.C., alleges that
the FBI "engaged in a systematic, and officially sanctioned campaign of
mis-information and dis-information" designed to prevent Peltier from
receiving fair clemency and parole reviews.

            The suit follows a highly controversial campaign conducted by
the FBI to stop former president Bill Clinton from issuing Peltier a grant
of executive clemency during his last days in office.  FBI agents across the
nation submitted letters to the editor, sponsored major newspaper and radio
ads, and marched by the hundreds in front of the White House to discourage
clemency.  Former FBI Director Louis Freeh wrote searing letters to Bill
Clinton and Janet Reno, to urge against Peltier's release.  The campaign,
which gained national attention, characterized Peltier as a cold-blooded
killer who brutally shot two FBI agents at point blank range.  Peltier's
attorneys and supporters assert that this characterization is not only false
but intentionally deceptive given the government's long held position that
it cannot prove who shot the agents.  Furthermore, they say it cost Peltier,
now 57 years of age and in poor health, his long deserved freedom.

            Peltier has served more than 26 years in prison for the deaths
of two FBI agents killed in a 1975 shoot-out on the Pine Ridge Indian
Reservation.  Peltier's supporters claim the FBI terrorized witnesses,
utilized false testimony and withheld a ballistic test proving Peltier's
innocence to gain his conviction.  Senior Eighth Circuit Judge Gerald
Heaney, who denied Peltier a new trial based on a legal technicality, has
since come forward to support Peltier's release, citing FBI misconduct.
Amnesty International, the Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights, Rev.
Jesse Jackson, Rigoberta Menchu Tum, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Corretta Scott
King, and scores of Native tribes are among those who consider Peltier a
political prisoner who should be freed.

(Complaint will be posted on LPDC web site on April 4: www.freepeltier.org .
Interviews with lawyer handling case and spokespeople for the LPDC can 
bearranged).


Until Freedom Is Won!
The New Peltier Justice Campaign

Leonard Peltier Defense Committee
PO Box 583
Lawrence, KS 66044
785-842-5774
www.freepeltier.org

______________________________________________________________________

Demand Accountability from the INS!

Tell McElroy to Meet the Public!

Since September 11, the INS and FBI have detained over 1,200 
immigrants,mainly of Arab or South Asian origin. And much of this is taking 
place inour own back yard.Brooklyn communities have been one of the INS' 
main targets.  Hundreds ofArab, Pakistani, and Muslim community members have 
been disappeared fromConey Island, Midwood, Bay Ridge, and other 
neighborhoods in the middle ofthe night by the FBI and INS.  Six months 
later, most of their loved onesare still being kept in the dark about their 
charges and conditions.  Andour communities are living in fear.Yet, the INS 
has not been held accountable for its actions in ourcommunities!Moreover, 
the District Director of the INS for New York, Edward McElroy, hasrefused to 
respond to repeated public requests for a town meeting.  Yet, hiscounterpart 
in New Jersey, Andrea Quarantillo, has agreed to meet the publicand begin a 
process of creating transparency.  That meeting is now beingscheduled.This 
is why the campaign to Stop the Disappearances! is asking for 
yourinvolvement to let McElroy know that our communities are seeking answers 
andthat he must be accountable to the communities he serves.****Join dozens 
of other organizations and individuals who havealready joined this effort to 
put pressure on McElroy & the INS to     stopoperating under secrecy.  Write 
a letter as an individual or     from yourorganization seeking a public 
community meeting with        Edward McElroyin 
Brooklyn.**********************

A sample letter is provided BELOW or you may choose to write your 
ownconcerns and message.  Or you can download a sample letter 
fromwww.drumnation.orgWe are collecting ALL of your letters (our goal is to 
have hundreds) byAPRIL 26th and planning to present them PUBLICALLY to 
McElroy & invite youto join�..
PLEASE MAIL 		DRUM- Desis Rising Up & Moving
YOUR LETTERS TO:	73-16 Roosevelt Ave, 2nd Fl.,Jackson Heights, NY 11372OR 
FAX TO: 	        (718) 205-3037OR EMAIL TO: 
		drum@...*******************************************

Sample Letter:

Mr. Edward McElroy
NY District DirectorImmigration and Naturalization Service
26 Federal Plaza
New York, NY

Dear Mr. McElroy,We write this letter to you as member of the community 
organization_____________, representing constituencies concerned by the mass 
detentionsof immigrants since September 11th, 2001.Over the past several 
months, we have been watching as it is brought tolight the unjust 
circumstances under which our and others' loved ones havebeen arrested and 
detained.  The families of those detained are simplyasking that due process, 
which is guaranteed for all under the United StatesConstitution, be 
respected for their loved ones.  We support them stronglyin this, and ask 
you to agree to a public meeting over these detentions inNew York.Ms. Andrea 
Quarantillo, District Director of the Newark regional INS, andMr. Jerry 
Speziale, Sheriff of Passaic County, have already agreed toparticipate in 
public meetings sponsored by DRUM, PMP and CHRI.But because a large number 
of the post-September 11 detainees come from NewYork City, and specifically 
Brooklyn, we feel it is essential that a meetingtake place there as well as 
in NJ.  This is so that the families andcommunities of the detained can 
express their concerns and ask questions.We are asking you, as the New York 
District Director of the INS, toparticipate in the forum, helping create the 
transparency so necessary for aworking democracy.Our request is a simple 
one: a public meeting to ensure accountability andjustice.  We join DRUM, 
PMP and CHRI in calling for such a meeting.  We hopethat this will be a 
first step towards re-establishing due process as afundamental right under 
the Constitution for all. Such a meeting will allowan open dialogue with 
officials who have the authority to negotiate and beaccountable to their 
constituencies. Furthermore, we would like to set theagenda before hand for 
both meetings with local community members andcommunity organizations 
serving their needs.We look forward to your cooperation and participation in 
a publicconversation.We write this letter to you in the spirit of continuing 
to work together inthe service of our families and communities.

Signed,______________________________________________________________

Post ID:2633
