PRESS RELEASE FOR LEONARD PELTIER BELOW!
Friends,

Below is the press release for the lawsuit that will be filed TOMORROW on
Leonard Peltier's behalf.  Please forward it far and wide to your local
media and to other supporters.  Please be sure that the release date remains
in tact.  We do not want coverage on this before the case is filed tomorrow.
We do, however, want to give reporters a chance to write their stories today
so that it can hit the press tomorrow.  Also note that this has been
distributed to all national news sources already, so we just need to focus
on everyone's local press.  You may want to follow up with phone calls to
your paper, radio and TV stations to request they cover the story given that
a local support group or supporters exist in the area.  Let us know if you
have any questions.  THANK you for your help and support!

In Solidarity,
LPDC

PS A formatted version can be downloaded from our web site:
http://www.freepeltier.org
________________________________________________________
RELEASE DATE:  THURSDAY, APRIL 4, 2002

Contact:
Leonard Peltier Defense Committee (785) 842-5774; lpdc@...


NATIVE AMERICAN ACTIVIST FILES LAWSUIT AGAINST FBI

        Former FBI Director Louis Freeh is named as a defendant in a lawsuit
filed today by attorneys for imprisoned Native American activist, Leonard
Peltier.  Freeh, along with the FBI Agents Association and a long list of
active FBI agents, are accused of violating Peltier's Constitutional rights
by making false and unsupported statements to the public, the Department of
Justice, the United States Parole Commission, and former President Clinton.
The complaint, filed in U.S. District Court, Washington D.C., alleges that
the FBI "engaged in a systematic, and officially sanctioned campaign of
mis-information and dis-information" designed to prevent Peltier from
receiving fair clemency and parole reviews.

            The suit follows a highly controversial campaign conducted by
the FBI to stop former president Bill Clinton from issuing Peltier a grant
of executive clemency during his last days in office.  FBI agents across the
nation submitted letters to the editor, sponsored major newspaper and radio
ads, and marched by the hundreds in front of the White House to discourage
clemency.  Former FBI Director Louis Freeh wrote searing letters to Bill
Clinton and Janet Reno, to urge against Peltier's release.  The campaign,
which gained national attention, characterized Peltier as a cold-blooded
killer who brutally shot two FBI agents at point blank range.  Peltier's
attorneys and supporters assert that this characterization is not only false
but intentionally deceptive given the government's long held position that
it cannot prove who shot the agents.  Furthermore, they say it cost Peltier,
now 57 years of age and in poor health, his long deserved freedom.

            Peltier has served more than 26 years in prison for the deaths
of two FBI agents killed in a 1975 shoot-out on the Pine Ridge Indian
Reservation.  Peltier's supporters claim the FBI terrorized witnesses,
utilized false testimony and withheld a ballistic test proving Peltier's
innocence to gain his conviction.  Senior Eighth Circuit Judge Gerald
Heaney, who denied Peltier a new trial based on a legal technicality, has
since come forward to support Peltier's release, citing FBI misconduct.
Amnesty International, the Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights, Rev.
Jesse Jackson, Rigoberta Menchu Tum, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Corretta Scott
King, and scores of Native tribes are among those who consider Peltier a
political prisoner who should be freed.

(Complaint will be posted on LPDC web site on April 4: www.freepeltier.org .
Interviews with lawyer handling case and spokespeople for the LPDC can 
bearranged).


Until Freedom Is Won!
The New Peltier Justice Campaign

Leonard Peltier Defense Committee
PO Box 583
Lawrence, KS 66044
785-842-5774
www.freepeltier.org

______________________________________________________________________

Demand Accountability from the INS!

Tell McElroy to Meet the Public!

Since September 11, the INS and FBI have detained over 1,200 
immigrants,mainly of Arab or South Asian origin. And much of this is taking 
place inour own back yard.Brooklyn communities have been one of the INS' 
main targets.  Hundreds ofArab, Pakistani, and Muslim community members have 
been disappeared fromConey Island, Midwood, Bay Ridge, and other 
neighborhoods in the middle ofthe night by the FBI and INS.  Six months 
later, most of their loved onesare still being kept in the dark about their 
charges and conditions.  Andour communities are living in fear.Yet, the INS 
has not been held accountable for its actions in ourcommunities!Moreover, 
the District Director of the INS for New York, Edward McElroy, hasrefused to 
respond to repeated public requests for a town meeting.  Yet, hiscounterpart 
in New Jersey, Andrea Quarantillo, has agreed to meet the publicand begin a 
process of creating transparency.  That meeting is now beingscheduled.This 
is why the campaign to Stop the Disappearances! is asking for 
yourinvolvement to let McElroy know that our communities are seeking answers 
andthat he must be accountable to the communities he serves.****Join dozens 
of other organizations and individuals who havealready joined this effort to 
put pressure on McElroy & the INS to     stopoperating under secrecy.  Write 
a letter as an individual or     from yourorganization seeking a public 
community meeting with        Edward McElroyin 
Brooklyn.**********************

A sample letter is provided BELOW or you may choose to write your 
ownconcerns and message.  Or you can download a sample letter 
fromwww.drumnation.orgWe are collecting ALL of your letters (our goal is to 
have hundreds) byAPRIL 26th and planning to present them PUBLICALLY to 
McElroy & invite youto join�..
PLEASE MAIL 		DRUM- Desis Rising Up & Moving
YOUR LETTERS TO:	73-16 Roosevelt Ave, 2nd Fl.,Jackson Heights, NY 11372OR 
FAX TO: 	        (718) 205-3037OR EMAIL TO: 
		drum@...*******************************************

Sample Letter:

Mr. Edward McElroy
NY District DirectorImmigration and Naturalization Service
26 Federal Plaza
New York, NY

Dear Mr. McElroy,We write this letter to you as member of the community 
organization_____________, representing constituencies concerned by the mass 
detentionsof immigrants since September 11th, 2001.Over the past several 
months, we have been watching as it is brought tolight the unjust 
circumstances under which our and others' loved ones havebeen arrested and 
detained.  The families of those detained are simplyasking that due process, 
which is guaranteed for all under the United StatesConstitution, be 
respected for their loved ones.  We support them stronglyin this, and ask 
you to agree to a public meeting over these detentions inNew York.Ms. Andrea 
Quarantillo, District Director of the Newark regional INS, andMr. Jerry 
Speziale, Sheriff of Passaic County, have already agreed toparticipate in 
public meetings sponsored by DRUM, PMP and CHRI.But because a large number 
of the post-September 11 detainees come from NewYork City, and specifically 
Brooklyn, we feel it is essential that a meetingtake place there as well as 
in NJ.  This is so that the families andcommunities of the detained can 
express their concerns and ask questions.We are asking you, as the New York 
District Director of the INS, toparticipate in the forum, helping create the 
transparency so necessary for aworking democracy.Our request is a simple 
one: a public meeting to ensure accountability andjustice.  We join DRUM, 
PMP and CHRI in calling for such a meeting.  We hopethat this will be a 
first step towards re-establishing due process as afundamental right under 
the Constitution for all. Such a meeting will allowan open dialogue with 
officials who have the authority to negotiate and beaccountable to their 
constituencies. Furthermore, we would like to set theagenda before hand for 
both meetings with local community members andcommunity organizations 
serving their needs.We look forward to your cooperation and participation in 
a publicconversation.We write this letter to you in the spirit of continuing 
to work together inthe service of our families and communities.

Signed,______________________________________________________________

The campaign to STOP THE DISAPPEARANCES!was launched on Martin Luther King 
Day, January 21st and is seeking justiceand due process for detainees.  The 
campaign is led by DESIS RISING UP ANDMOVING (DRUM), 718-205-3036, 
www.drumnation.org,drum@...;COALITION FOR THE HUMAN RIGHTS OF 
IMMIGRANTS (CHRI), 212-254-2591,www.itapnet.org/chri, chri@...; 
PRISON MORATORIUM PROJECT (PMP)646-486-6715 education@..., 
www.nomoreprisons.orgThe campaign is directly accountable to DRUM's 
constituency of families ofdetainees & over a hundred detainees in NY and 
NJ.  To see our demands, goto www.drumnation.org

******************************DRUM -Desis Rising Up & MovingFAMILIES NEED 
YOUR HELPto keep fighting to end the INS detention system.  Donate to the 
EmergencyFamily & Legal Fund with a check written to "The Brecht Forum" with 
"DRUMFamily Fund" written in memo and mail to:   DRUM, 73-16 Roosevelt Ave, 
2ndFl,Jackson Heights, NY 11372718-205-3036 / 
info@...***********************

BASTA DE TERRORISMO - FUERA LA MARINA DE LOS EEUU  DE VIEQUES, PR!

call on all women and men of consciousness to denounce and protest the US 
Navy's current military manuevers in Vieques, Puerto Rico.

Come to stand in solidarity with the people of Vieques, PR in their demand 
that their land be demilitarized, decontaminated, devolved and developed 
justly and sustainably.  Come to support and honor the valor and sacrifice 
of Mirna Rodr�guez, Maribel Arroyo, Irma Rodr�guez, Mariela Negr�n, y Mar�a 
de Lourdes Santiago, the five compa�eras arrested 4/1/02 for struggling for 
a Free Vieques.

de los EEUU en Vieques, Puerto Rico.  Vengan en solidaridad con el pueblo de 
Vieques, PR a exigir la desmilitarizaci�n, descontaminaci�n, devoluci�n y 
desarrollo justo y sostenible de sus tierras.  Vengan en apoyo y aprecio al 
valor y sacrificio de Mirna Rodr�guez, Maribel Arroyo, Irma Rodr�guez, 
Mariela Negr�n, y Mar�a de Lourdes Santiago, las cinco compa�eras arrestadas

Post ID:2636
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-05 15:39:20
Subject:ANTONIO NEEDS YOU!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is sending out this email to inform the 
international community that one of the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, 
ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON,  will be released from prison on MONDAY MAY 20TH, 
2002!!

Antonio is being forced into parole again, much like the last time about 3-5 
years ago.  Antonio refuses to sign on to any parole conditions and has 
publically expressed the fact that he will not be meeting with parole or 
reporting in to any parole officials.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all supporters and allies to 
help us bring Antonio here to New York and home to Puerto Rico.  We also 
want to generate some money to help him travel, buy new clothes and other 
necessities!! In order to do all of this we need MONEY!!

PROLIBERTAD IS TRYING TO RAISE $1000 BETWEEN NOW AND MAY 20TH!!

PLEASE DONTATE GENEROUSLY TO THE PROLIBERTAD FREEDOM CAMPAIGN EFFORT TO HELP 
ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!

Please make your tax deductible donations to:

IFCO/ProLibertad for Antonio Camacho Negron
402 w145th St.
New York, NY 10031

For more info. on ProLibertad or on Antonio's release please contact 
ProLibertad@... or call BX 718-601-4751, NY 212-927-9065, New Jersey 
201-435-3244
________________________________________________________________________
BE ON THE LOOK OUT FOR ANOTHER PROLIBERTAD EMAIL  WITH THE TIME, DATE AND 
PLACE OF OUR COMMUNITY RECEPTION FOR ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!
________________________________________________________________________


ANTONIO COMACHO NEGRON was born in Yauco, Puerto Rico in 1945. He was a 
coffee farmer like generations of his family. Antonio studied psychology at 
the University of Puerto Rico and law at the Interamerican University for 
2-years. He worked as a therapist with the Department of Services Against 
Addiction. At the time of his arrest, 1986, he was working as a mechanic and 
was the sole source of income for his family. Antonio Camacho Negrn was 
sentenced to 15-years for allegedly participating in a "conspiracy and 
inter-state transportation of money" in the Wells Fargo robbery. He has 
three sons and a daughter who live in Puerto Rico. Antonio was paroled 
briefly in 1998 and was re-arrested for refusing to accept unjust 
conditions. He was not included in President Clinton's 1999 clemency offer 
(see Related Resources section below for more info). He is currently in 
prison in White Deer, Pennsylvania.


_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

years ago.  Antonio refuses to sign on to any parole conditions and has 
publically expressed the fact that he will not be meeting with parole or

want to generate some money to help him travel, buy new clothes and other

PLACE OF OUR COMMUNITY RECEPTION FOR ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!

ANTONIO COMACHO NEGRON was born in Yauco, Puerto Rico in 1945. He was a 
coffee farmer like generations of his family. Antonio studied psychology at 
the University of Puerto Rico and law at the Interamerican University for 
2-years. He worked as a therapist with the Department of Services Against 
Addiction. At the time of his arrest, 1986, he was working as a mechanic and 
was the sole source of income for his family. Antonio Camacho Negrn was 
sentenced to 15-years for allegedly participating in a "conspiracy and 
inter-state transportation of money" in the Wells Fargo robbery. He has 
three sons and a daughter who live in Puerto Rico. Antonio was paroled 
briefly in 1998 and was re-arrested for refusing to accept unjust 
conditions. He was not included in President Clinton's 1999 clemency offer 
(see Related Resources section below for more info). He is currently in 
prison in White Deer, Pennsylvania.

Post ID:2639
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-07 16:26:29
Subject:Capital Punishment and Women's Lives
Message:

The Rutgers University Women's Center will host a roundtable discussion on
"Capital Punishment and Women's Lives" tomorrow, Monday, April 8, at 7 PM in
the Women's Center on the third floor of the Douglass College Center. ACLU
Women's Rights Project attorney Namita Luthra will lead the discussion with
students. All are welcome to attend!

For more information, see http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/

Sponsored by the Women's Defense Coalition.

-Charlotte
                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2640
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-08 04:05:19
Subject:Confronting the Silence: Domestic Violence, the State, and South Asian American Women
Message:

A great event for the week of Take Back the Night...

  "Confronting the Silence: Domestic Violence, the State, and South Asian
American Women" 

   Featuring Guest Speaker: SHAMITA DAS DASGUPTA 

Date: Tuesday, April 9th 2002
Time: 6:00pm-7:30pm (reception to follow)
Location: Yorba Lounge, Tillet Hall--Livingston Campus, 
Rutgers University 

  Shamita Das Dasgupta was formerly a professor at Rutgers University, and
has been an active participant in the women's movement since the early
seventies. She is the editor of "A Patchwork Shawl: Chronicles of South
Asian Women Living in America," and is one of the founding members of
Manavi, as New Brunswick-based non profit organization for women who trace
their cultural heritage to Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri
Lanka. Manavi was the first organization in the US to focus on violence
against women in the South Asian community, and provides supportive
services to battered women. Manavi is committed to the empowerment of
South Asian women and thereby, dedicates its major efforts to facilitating
womens' quest for self-reliance and autonomy everywhere. 


For More Info, Contact the Asian American Cultural Center at
(732) 445-8042

                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2645
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-08 10:46:53
Subject:Pedro Colon Almenas CD Brigade!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is proud to forward this press release from 
the Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores/MST, who have sent in a civil 
disobedience brigade into the restricted bombing range in Vieques.  This 
brigade was dedicated to our newest Puerto Rican Political Prisoner, Pedro 
Colon Almenas.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
Http://www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores (MST)
Apartado 22699
Estaci�n UPR
San Juan, PR 00931-2699
(787) 771-4921

Monday April 8th, 2002

Press Release

New Brigade of Civil Disobedients bamboozle U.S. Navy!!

Yesterday, Sunday April 7th, 2002 a brigade of civil disobedients, organized 
by el Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores/MST (Workers' Socialist 
Movement), penetrated the restricted bombing range in Vieques, bamboozling 
and defying the US Navy's increased security presence and precautions.

This brigade was dedicated to Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Pedro Colon 
Almenas, who has been unjustly incarcerated in Puerto Rico for being an 
anti-military activist.

The MST understands that the only way to remove the US Navy from Vieques is 
by confronting them using Civil disobedience.  The MST recognizes that the 
Puerto Rican Governor Sila Calderon and the Puerto Rican Police 
Superintendent are accomplices in the abuse against the people of Vieques 
this weekend, who were protesting and expressing their right of free speech.

Much like past civil disobedience brigades sent in by the MST, this brigade 
is in the restricted bombing range and will be disrupting the bombing 
practices.  They will deter the bombing practices and leave the range with 
out being arrested.

Brigade members are:

� Antonio Hern�ndez � A Teacher in San Sebastian
� Francisco B�ez � Retired teacher from Utaudo
� Humberto N��ez � Teacher from Rio Piedras
� Juan Alverio � Employee of the Dept. of Education in Juncos
� Andy Rivera � Retired Telecommunications Worker from Rio Piedras

Once again, we will hold the US Navy/military officials responsible for any 
pain/damage they cause the civil disobedients.

Luis Angel Torres
Spokesperson(787) 415-4286




_________________________________________________________________
Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2646
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-08 10:49:49
Subject:Pedro Colon Almenas CD Brigade!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is proud to forward this press release from 
the Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores/MST, who have sent in a civil 
disobedience brigade into the restricted bombing range in Vieques.  This 
brigade was dedicated to our newest Puerto Rican Political Prisoner, Pedro 
Colon Almenas.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
Http://www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores (MST)
Apartado 22699
Estaci�n UPR
San Juan, PR 00931-2699
(787) 771-4921

Monday April 8th, 2002

Press Release

New Brigade of Civil Disobedients bamboozle U.S. Navy!!

Yesterday, Sunday April 7th, 2002 a brigade of civil disobedients, organized 
by el Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores/MST (Workers' Socialist 
Movement), penetrated the restricted bombing range in Vieques, bamboozling 
and defying the US Navy's increased security presence and precautions.

This brigade was dedicated to Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Pedro Colon 
Almenas, who has been unjustly incarcerated in Puerto Rico for being an 
anti-military activist.

The MST understands that the only way to remove the US Navy from Vieques is 
by confronting them using Civil disobedience.  The MST recognizes that the 
Puerto Rican Governor Sila Calderon and the Puerto Rican Police 
Superintendent are accomplices in the abuse against the people of Vieques 
this weekend, who were protesting and expressing their right of free speech.

Much like past civil disobedience brigades sent in by the MST, this brigade 
is in the restricted bombing range and will be disrupting the bombing 
practices.  They will deter the bombing practices and leave the range with 
out being arrested.

Brigade members are:

� Antonio Hern�ndez � A Teacher in San Sebastian
� Francisco B�ez � Retired teacher from Utaudo
� Humberto N��ez � Teacher from Rio Piedras
� Juan Alverio � Employee of the Dept. of Education in Juncos
� Andy Rivera � Retired Telecommunications Worker from Rio Piedras

Once again, we will hold the US Navy/military officials responsible for any 
pain/damage they cause the civil disobedients.

Luis Angel Torres
Spokesperson(787) 415-4286

Post ID:2647
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-08 19:10:05
Subject:Vieques Vigil April 9th!!
Message:

Women for Peace and Justice for Vieques, P.R.
Mujeres por Paz y Justicia en Vieuqes, Puerto Rico

MEDIA ADVISORY � MEDIA ADVISORY  � MEDIA ADVISORY �

What: Protest & Candlelight Vigil for Peace in Vieques
When: Tuesday, April 9, 2002 � 5:00-8:00PM
Where: Recruiting Center in Times Square
CONTACT: Carmen A. D�vila
718-295-5220
prdavila@...

In the very delicate and tense times that we�re currently facing worldwide 
we want to extend our solidarity with the people and the countries whose 
right to live a peaceful life has been violated and also reaffirm our 
commitment to the struggle of Vieques. Not one more bomb!

In response to the this current cycle of military maneuvers in the island of 
Vieques, P.R., a protest and candlelight vigil will be held in front of the 
Recruiting Center in Times Square next Tuesday April 9, from 5:00PM to 
8:00PM. By means of a referendum the people of Vieques had already decided 
against the bombings. Together with them we demand that their land be 
demilitarized, decontaminated, devolved, and developed in a just and 
sustainable manner.

Everyone is invited to be part of this event. Representatives from various 
communities and movements will be joining us including la Iglesia San Romero 
de las Am�ricas, ProLibertad, the Puerto Rican Independence Party � NY 
chapter, the Vieques Support Campaign, the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party � 
NY chapter, and others.  A number of activities are been planned for the 
event.

End terrorism everywhere!
U.S. Navy out of Vieques, Puerto Rico Now!

�###�

Post ID:2649
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-09 04:10:38
Subject:Report from occupied Palestine, Tonight, 8 PM
Message:

Jim Davis, a Rutgers University graduate student who worked for months with
the International Solidarity Movement in occupied Palestine, working to
build nonviolent resistance and community programs, has just returned from
Ramallah after being deported by the Israeli government! He will discuss
what he saw, the experience of the Palestinian people and their struggle,
the new Israeli onslaught and the possibilities for organizing in
solidarity. Jim has incredible first-hand knowledge of the situation in the
Middle East and a great deal to share with the community!

TONIGHT--April 9, 2002! 8:00 PM, Rutgers University Women's Center; Third
Floor, Douglass College Center, New Brunswick, NJ.

For more information, contact Charlotte Kates/ ckates@...
/(732)373-6827

Please forward widely!!!


                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

has been sent to you by can_bush@....

Newark Relives Day of Machine in Mayor's Race

April 9, 2002 

By ANDREW JACOBS


Anyone who thinks the days of the old-style political
machines are gone has not been following the mayor's race
in Newark.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/09/nyregion/09NEWA.html?ex=1019372226&ei=1&en=7464fa73208c91dd

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2651
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-09 16:43:43
Subject:Brigade member Arrested!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urging folks to read and forward this 
update on the brave Civil Disobedients inn Vieques.  To remind folks this 
Brigade has been dedicated to Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Pedro Colon 
Almenas!!
______________________________________________________________________

Movimiento Socialista de Trabajadores (MST)
APARTADO 22699, ESTACI�N U.P.R.
SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO 00931-2699
Tel�fono 415-4286

Tuesday April 9th, 2002

Press Release

Civil Disobedient Arrested in Bombing Range in Vieques!!

At 7am this morning, Rafael Feliciano, a teacher, was arrested in the US 
Navy Bombing Range in Vieques.  He was able to communicate with others to 
let them know he was arrested, while he was seperated from the rest of the 
Brigade, that was organized by El Movimiento Socialista 
Trabajadores/Workers' Socialist Movement.

This group was able to infiltrate the bombing range at night on Saturday 
April 6th with the help of El Colective Cayo La Yayi, an organization from 
Vieques.  When he bombings recommenced on Monday April 8th, the brigade made 
their presence known and was able to halt the bombing practices.  Contrary 
to what the Navy alleged, we noticed from the civilian areas that the 
weather in Vieques during the supposed bombing time was fine and there was 
no reason why they couldn't practice.  In fact, we could hear Military 
Helicopters flying around until 2pm in the afternoon.


We are all very proud of the work that the comrades have been doing putting 
thier life and freedom on the line for peace in Vieques.  We hold the US 
Navy and the United States government responsible for any and ll harm that 
might befall the members of the Brigade.  This brigade will remanin the 
bombing range until the bombings are cancelled.

The brigade members are:
*Rafael Feliciano - Maestro
*Andy Rivera � Trabajador telef�nico retirado
*Johnny Alverio - Prensista
*Francisco Ba�z - Maestro retirado
*Humberto Nu�ez � Maestro

Luis �ngel Torres, Portavoz

Tuesday April 9th, 2002

Press Release

Civil Disobedient Arrested in Bombing Range in Vieques!!

At 7am this morning, Rafael Feliciano, a teacher, was arrested in the US

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2653
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-09 21:18:17
Subject:happy birthday, Paul Robeson. 9 April
Message:

"The Real Reason Behind Robeson's Persecution"

( W.E.B. DuBois, From the 'National Guardian', April 7, 1958)

The persecution of Paul Robeson by the government and people of the United 
States during the last nine years has been one of the most contemptible 
happenings in modern history.

Robeson has done nothing to hurt or defame this nation.  He is, as all know, 
one of the most charming, charitable and loving of men.  There is no person 
on earth who ever heard Robeson slander or even attack the land of his 
birth.  Yet he had reason to despise America.

He was a black man; the son of black folk whom Americans had stolen and 
enslaved.  Even after his people's hard-won and justly earned freedom.  
America made their lot as near a hell on earth as was possible.  They 
discouraged, starved and insulted them.  They sneered at helpless black 
children.

Someone once said that the best punishment for Hitler would be to paint him 
black and send him to the United States.  This was no joke.  To struggle up 
as a black boy in America; to meet jeers and blows; to meet insult with 
silence and discrimination with a smile; to sit with fellow students who 
hated you and work and play for the honor of a college that disowned 
you--all this was America for Paul Robeson.

Yet he fought the good fight; "He was despised and rejected of men; a man of 
sorrows and acquainted with grief and we hid as it were our faces from Him; 
He was despised and we esteemed Him not."

Why?  Why?  Not because he attacked this country.  Search Britain and 
France, the Soviet Union and Scandinavia for a word of his against America.  
What then was his crime?

It was that while he did not rail at America he did praise the Soviet Union; 
and he did that because it treated him like a man and not a dog; because he 
and his family for the first time in life were welcomed like human beings 
and he was honored like a great man.

The children of Russia clung to him, the women kissed him; the workers 
greeted him; the state named mountains after him.  He loved their homage.  
His eyes were filled with tears and his heart with thanks.  Never before had 
he received such treatment.

In America he was a "nigger"; in Britain he was tolerated; in France he was 
cheered; in the Soviet Union he was loved for the great artist that he is.  
He loved the Soviet Union in turn.  He believed that every black man with 
blood in his veins would with him love the nation which first outlawed the 
color line.

I saw him when he voiced this.  It was in Paris in 1949 at the greatest 
rally for world peace this world ever witnessed.  Two thousand persons from 
all the world filled the Salle Pleyel from floor to rafters.  Robeson 
hurried in, magnificent in height and breadth, weary from circling Europe 
with song.  The audience rose to a man and the walls thundered.  Robeson 
said that his people wanted peace and "would never fight the Soviet Union."  
I joined with the thousands in wild acclaim.

					In Babylon, dark Babylon,

the modern breed of newspaper prostitute "who take the wage of shame" seized 
the chance to

					grovel to their master's mood
					the blood upon their pens
					assigns their souls to servitude
					Yea and the souls of men.

This, for America, was Robeson's crime.  He might hate anybody.  He might 
join in murder around the world.  He might lie and steal.  But for him to 
declare that he loved the Soviet Union and would not join in war against 
it--that was the highest crime that the United States recognized.

For that, they slandered Robeson; they tried to kill him at Peekskill; they 
prevented him from hiring halls in which to sing; they prevented him from 
travel and refused him a passport.  His college lied about him and 
dishonored him.

Above all, his own people, American Negroes, joined in hounding one of their 
greatest artists--not all, but some like those who wrote of Negro musicians 
and deliberately omitted Robeson's name--Robeson who more than any living 
man has spread the pure Negro folk song over the civilized world.

Yet has Paul Robeson kept his soul and stood his ground.  Stil he loves and 
honors the Soviet Union.  Still he has hope for America.  Still he asserts 
his faith in God.  But we--what can we say or do but hang our heads in 
endless shame?

As we celebrate the sixtieth birthday of Paul Robeson from Moscow to New 
Dehli, New York to California and Accra to Johannesburg, we can all take our 
stand and sing with him:

					Out of the night that covers me
					black as the pit from pole to pole,
					I thank whatever gods may be
					For my unconquerable soul.






unite the many, defeat the few!


_________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp.

Post ID:2654
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-10 10:05:03
Subject:Take Back the Night Art Show TONIGHT
Message:

Take Back the Night will hold its first student art show tonight, honoring
and celebrating art of reclamation and strength. Artists Irma Cannavo,
Ingrid Dahl, Marion Fleming, Beth Goldberg, Toney Jackson, Rachel
Lichtenfeld, Eryn Loeb, Rain, Jaymie Stein, Dave Trawin and Marie Varghese
will be exhibiting their work between 7 pm and 10 pm at Trayes Hall A in the
Douglass College Center this evening, Wednesday, April 10.

All are invited to attend!

Please forward widely!

-Charlotte
For more information, contact Charlotte/ 373-6827/ ckates@...

  ckates@... ** ckates@...

Post ID:2655
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-10 13:23:26
Subject:Support Dr. Maria Luisa Acosta
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges all of our supporters to read his 
email and forward it out to all listserves.  Please  write in to the 
Nicaraguan government as well.

The ProLibertad Freedom Camapaign
ProLibertad@...
Http://www.ProLibertad.org
Manhattan 212-927-9065
Bronx 718-601-4751
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Tuesday, April 9, 2002

Dear Friends and Supporters of Nicaragua:

With sadness and a great sense of moral outrage we report that Francisco 
Jos� Garc�a Valle, esteemed professor at the University of the Autonomous 
Regions  of the Caribbean Coast of Nicaragua and husband of Dr. Mar�a Luisa 
Acosta, internationally renown indigenous human rights lawyer was 
assassinated in his home on Monday night.

At the time of his murder, his wife was meeting with the IFCO/Pastors for 
Peace Central American Caravan to Chiapas, Honduras and Nicaragua, which had 
been in the region for the last week and a half.  Maria, who has received 
threats to her physical safety in the past because of her work advocating on 
behalf of indigenous communities fighting for their land and other basic 
human rights, was briefing the caravan on an important case that she is 
currently working on.  Had she not been away from her home meeting with the 
caravan, she could have met with the same fate as her husband.

Francisco Jose was found bound and gagged, shot in his heart.  A police 
investigation is under way, however at this time, there is no information 
available about who is responsible for this heinous act.

The caravan members were able to accompany Attorney Acosta today, but we 
remain extremely concerned about her continued safety given this violent 
attack against her immediate family.  The caravan held a press conference 
Tuesday afternoon in Managua to call for the immediate apprehension of the 
assassins and for the guaranteed protection of Attorney Acosta and her 
family.

IFCO/Pastors for Peace is urgently requesting that you communicate your 
concern to Nicaraguan President Enrique Bola�os, specifically calling to:

1.  Express your  outrage at the senseless murder of Francisco Jos� Garc�a 
Valle and concern for the security of Maria Acosta and her family, who have 
been at the forefront of the struggle for indigenous rights in the region.
2.  Demand that the security of Maria Acosta and her family be ensured by 
the government of Nicaragua and that a rigorous, stepped up investigation 
into the murder begin NOW.
3.  Demand that the assassins be immediately apprehended and brought to 
justice.

Please address your letters to President Enrique Bola�os to:
The Nicaraguan Ambassador
The Republic of Nicaragua
1627 New Hampshire Avenue, NW
Washington DC 20009
Telephone: (202) 9396570
Fax: (202) 939-6574
More information as to where to send messages of condolence and solidarity, 
as well as future actions to take, will be available shortly.
IFCO/Pastors for Peace
402 W 145th Street, New York City, NY 10031
212-926-5757; fax: 212-926-5842; email: ifco@...;
web: http://www.ifconews.org

IFCO/Pastors for Peace
402 W 145th Street, New York City, NY 10031
212-926-5757; fax: 212-926-5842; email: ifco@...;
web: http://www.ifconews.org



_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

Subject:1st List of Vieques Political Prisoners!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to write to our Vieques 
Political Prisoners and send them your regards and solidarity!!  Gracias to 
our comrades from Mayaguezanos con Vieques for this preliminary list.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
Http://www.ProLibertad.org

Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244

Please write to our Vieques prisoners.

The address is:


MDC Guaynabo
PO Box 2147
San Juan, Puerto Rico  00922-2147

Please include name and prison number.
(Protesters arrested in Vieques)

April 1st, 2002
1. Mar�a de Lourdes Santiago             21687-069 (3C)
2. Myrna Rodr�guez Lugo                  21688-069 (3C)
3. Maribel Arroyo Rodr�guez              21689-069 (3C)
4. Mar�a Elena Negron Santiago           21690-069 (3C)
5. Irma Rodr�guez                        21691-069 (3C)

April 4th, 2002
1. Juan Ram�n Cruz                         21692-069 (1C)
2. Violeta Vega R�os                       21693-069 (3C)
3. Emma V�lez Hern�ndez                    21694-069 (3C)
4. Petra Barreras del R�o                  21695-069 (3C)

April 5th, 2002
*1.    Luis Silva Gonz�lez                 25003-069 (1C)
*2.    Miguel S�nchez Rivera               25004-069 (1C)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2660
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-11 02:02:04
Subject:Silent Vigil for Palestine; Brower Commons, Rutgers; Thursday, 4 PM
Message:

Thursday, April 11, at 4:00 PM, a silent vigil will be held in solidarity
with Palestinians at Brower Commons, College Avenue Campus, Rutgers
University.

While the occupied territories are under renewed assault, it is up to us to
take a stand, across the country and around the world, and tell our
government and the Israeli government that this is *not acceptable*, and
that there is a strong force of solidarity present for Palestinians.

Even if you can come for 5 minutes, come. It can make a difference!

-Charlotte
(373-6827/ckates@...)
                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2661
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-11 02:59:25
Subject:Women Unite! Take Back the Night!
Message:

The annual Take Back the Night rally and march against gender violence,
domestic abuse, sexual assault and gender oppression will take place
Thursday, April 11.

The women's rally will begin at 7:00 PM at Voorhees Chapel on Douglass
College campus, and include a number of student and community speakers,
performers, poets and musicians, as well as keynote speaker Kate Bornstein,
transgender activist.

From Voorhees, women will march down George Street to the College Avenue
Campus at approximately 9:30 PM, symbolically taking back the night in New
Brunswick and at Rutgers.

The women's march will join men at Brower Commons at 10:00 PM for a co-ed
speakout and rally with open mic, where all are welcome to share their
stories and experiences, speak and march.

The Middlesex County Rape Crisis Center will display an exhibit on domestic
violence, as well as providing counselors for the Brower Commons open mic.
All are welcome and encouraged to attend!

                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2664
Sender:Richard Rabinowitz <rickyrab@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-11 22:53:41
Subject:Don't just take back the night... keep it! here's how
Message:

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 01:09:02 
From: Jaclyn
To: the folks at RU
Subject: Advice on violence-free dating

      When it comes to dating, there seem to be many contradictions in
"the rules."  In my opinion, most circumstances require different actions
and reactions, and therefore can't be part of a clear dating game.  You
need to understand the person, the situation, and then decide how to act
based on your best judgement.   There is one charastic of most women that
may help you.  In fact, you will realize that men and women are the same
in this way.  For example, be yourself and don't pretend to be anyone
else, but DO NOT act too forward and eager by being overly-nice and
smothering.  You would not want a girl who called you all the time and
followed you around.  Both men and women (as much as it seems stupid)
will be more interested in someone who is harder to get.  Another
suggestion regarding looking for a girlfriend is not to go for a girl
solely because you find her attractive.  Make sure she is smart and you
like her personality.  The best relationships are often found through
friendships.  However, be careful, friendships can also be ruined in this
way.  There are ways to tell if someone is interested in you.  Trust your
instincts.  Think about the way a girl looks at you and the body
language.  Regarding asking a girl out: go for it -as long as you have
talked to her for a little while.  Keep in mind though, most guys get
"shot down" 99% of the time.  DO NOT loose confidence if that happens a
lot.  That happens A LOT to every guy!  The best advise I can give you is
to always be yourself, but do not open your soul until the girl deserves
to be so close to you.  You will find someone who is right for you, but
relationships are never easy.  Even when you love someone there are
fights.  Furthermore, you know how much your parents can piss you off? 
A woman you love can and will piss you off even more!  This happens when
you care so much about a person.  Believe me, no one can make me more mad
than Ian.  Be prepared to hold your temper.  Staying in love is constant
work.  Make sure you are confident and sure of yourself before entering a
relationship.  People make a mistake when they try to understand who they
are and gain confidence through someone else.  Adding another person
makes some things in life easier and other things much harder.  Look for
someone to have fun with and then see what happens!  A great woman will
brighten your life-most of the time- and you will be a wonderful gift to
her life. 

            Sorry about the spelling.  I hope I said a few interesting
things.


                                 Wish you good luck,
						
						 Jaclyn

________________________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2665
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-11 23:12:27
Subject:Black Panther Reunion/Conference
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign cannot stress enough the monumental 
importance of this conference/reunion.  Please read and foward this 
information out.  Please make plans to attend, an activity such as this 
cannot be missed!!

FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISOENRS!!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

It'sAbout Time
Committee to Celebrate the Founding of the
Black Panther Party
PO Box 221100
Sacramento CA 95822
(916) 455-0908

Jonina Abron
Safiya Bukhari
Clark (Santa Rita) Bailey
Kathleen Cleaver
Nzinga Conway
Emory Douglas
Claudia Grayson (Sister Sheba)
William (Billy X) Jennings
Akua Njeri (Deborah Johnson)
Talibah Shakir Gail Shaw

April 2, 2002
PRESS RELEASE

October 2001 marked the 35th Anniversary of the founding of
the Black Panther Party for Self Defense (BPP). As a result
of the events of September 11th, the BPP Reunion and
Conference originally planned to take place in October was
postponed and has been rescheduled for April 18th through 20th,
2002. Although the origins of the BPP were in Oakland, CA,
and previous conferences have been held in California, the
Black Panther Party had over 48 offices around the country
and many of our major offices were on the east coast. This
year's celebration will be held in Washington DC to recognize
the contributions of our east coast comrades. This event will
take place at the University of the District of Columbia, in
Washington DC. Previous registrations and advertising will
be honored.

The Conference will feature panel discussions on reparations
for the descendants of African slaves, political prisoners and
Cointelpro (the FBI's illegal program to disrupt progressive
political groups and destroy the BPP). The conference will
feature workshops designed to formulate strategies to obtain
freedom for political prisoners, combat police brutality,
protect civil rights, build solidarity in the movement, and
remunerate the victims of Cointelpro. There will also be
workshops on women in the BPP, the difference between the
BPP and the New BPP, and a number of workshops focusing on
Youth. There will be some closed sessions dealing with issues
pertinent to former Panthers.

Historic photo displays will be open the public and will include
over 60 photographs covering the early development of the Black
Panther Party through 1975. There will also be an exhibit of the
Black Panther Party Newspaper which at one time produced more
than 150,000 copies a week, and an exhibit of the New York Panther
Paper "Right On" There will be an ongoing film-video festival during
the entire conference with many topical films regarding the history
of the black Panther Party, political prisoners, Cointelpro and the
movement in general. Saturday evening, April 20, there will be a
buffet dinner reception, an opportunity to socialize and visit with
old friends and comrades.

This is an opportunity for older, more experienced activists to share
their knowledge and experience with young, enthusiastic activists of
today. It is also an opportunity for isolated activists in related fields
to come together to share creative and practical resources in the
fight for social justice.

We invite all former Panthers, community workers and current and
former activists in the cause of social justice to attend. For more
information and to download a registration form, please visit our
website: itsabouttimebpp.com
For more info: It's About Time, PO Box 221100, Sacramento, CA 95822
Phone: (916) 455-0908, e-mail: itsabouttime3@...
The It's About Time Committee is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation.
Tax deductible donations can be made to help sponsor the Reunion and
Conference, to support publication of our newsletter or for Books
Behind Bars, a program that sends reading materials to prisoners
throughout the country.

Workshops - 35th year Reunion Conference

Building Solidarity - Facilitated by Elbert "Big Man" Howard
A discussion on international influence and support for the BPP and
the importance of building alliances with other groups

Differences between the Black Panther Party and the so-called
new black panther party - Facilitated by JoNina Abron and Ron Scott

Marxist - Leninist Theory and the Black Panther Party - Facilitated
by Cappy Pinderhughes

Cointelpro - Facilitated by Roz Payne
A discussion with documentation of the FBI's illegal operation to
discredit and destroy progressive organizations, especially the Black
Panther Party

Reparations - Facilitated by N'COBRA
Several workshops covering all various aspects of the Reparations movement

Police Brutality and the Protection of Civil Liberties - Facilitated by
members of Oct. 22 and ACLU

Women in the Struggle - Facilitated by Rosemary Mealy and others
Several workshops dealing with women's role in and contributions to the
movement

Mumia Abu-Jamal - Facilitated by Pam Africa and Mumia's attorney

Economics - Facilitated by William Brown and Stretch Peterson
A discussion of building economic stability in the community

Angola 3 Update - Facilitated by Robert King Wilkerson and Althea
Francois

Labor Organizing - Facilitated by Cleo Silvers
A look at various aspects of organizing labor today

Organizing Youth - Facilitated by Khalil Shayid, Ameejill Jackson and
Leslie Jones - Multiple workshops dealing with many aspects of
empowering youth in the struggle including a Youth - Elders Panel

The Historical Legacy of George Jackson and the Prison Movement -
Facilitated by Dr. Lynch, Dorsey Nunn and David Johnson


_________________________________________________________________
Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

It'sAbout Time

Black Panther Party

Talibah Shakir Gail Shaw

April 2, 2002
PRESS RELEASE

October 2001 marked the 35th Anniversary of the founding of
the Black Panther Party for Self Defense (BPP). As a result
of the events of September 11th, the BPP Reunion and
Conference originally planned to take place in October was
postponed and has been rescheduled for April 18th through 20th,
2002. Although the origins of the BPP were in Oakland, CA,
and previous conferences have been held in California, the
Black Panther Party had over 48 offices around the country
and many of our major offices were on the east coast. This
year's celebration will be held in Washington DC to recognize
the contributions of our east coast comrades. This event will
take place at the University of the District of Columbia, in
Washington DC. Previous registrations and advertising will
be honored.

The Conference will feature panel discussions on reparations
for the descendants of African slaves, political prisoners and
Cointelpro (the FBI's illegal program to disrupt progressive
political groups and destroy the BPP). The conference will
feature workshops designed to formulate strategies to obtain
freedom for political prisoners, combat police brutality,
protect civil rights, build solidarity in the movement, and
remunerate the victims of Cointelpro. There will also be
workshops on women in the BPP, the difference between the
BPP and the New BPP, and a number of workshops focusing on
Youth. There will be some closed sessions dealing with issues
pertinent to former Panthers.

Historic photo displays will be open the public and will include
over 60 photographs covering the early development of the Black
Panther Party through 1975. There will also be an exhibit of the
Black Panther Party Newspaper which at one time produced more
than 150,000 copies a week, and an exhibit of the New York Panther
Paper "Right On" There will be an ongoing film-video festival during
the entire conference with many topical films regarding the history
of the black Panther Party, political prisoners, Cointelpro and the
movement in general. Saturday evening, April 20, there will be a
buffet dinner reception, an opportunity to socialize and visit with
old friends and comrades.

This is an opportunity for older, more experienced activists to share
their knowledge and experience with young, enthusiastic activists of
today. It is also an opportunity for isolated activists in related fields
to come together to share creative and practical resources in the
fight for social justice.

We invite all former Panthers, community workers and current and
former activists in the cause of social justice to attend. For more
information and to download a registration form, please visit our
website: itsabouttimebpp.com
For more info: It's About Time, PO Box 221100, Sacramento, CA 95822
Phone: (916) 455-0908, e-mail: itsabouttime3@...
The It's About Time Committee is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation.
Tax deductible donations can be made to help sponsor the Reunion and
Conference, to support publication of our newsletter or for Books
Behind Bars, a program that sends reading materials to prisoners
throughout the country.

Workshops - 35th year Reunion Conference

Building Solidarity - Facilitated by Elbert "Big Man" Howard
A discussion on international influence and support for the BPP and
the importance of building alliances with other groups

Differences between the Black Panther Party and the so-called
new black panther party - Facilitated by JoNina Abron and Ron Scott

Panther Party

members of Oct. 22 and ACLU

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2667
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-13 01:11:15
Subject:More on Vieques Political Prisoners!!
Message:

Vieques protesters sentenced; trespasses not 'justified'

By MANUEL ERNESTO RIVERA
Associated Press

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (April 10, 2002 10:48 p.m. EDT) - Five
members of Puerto Rico's pro-independence party were sentenced
to 30 days in a federal detention center Wednesday for breaking
into U.S. Navy property to protest bombing exercises on Vieques
island.

The five women were detained after breaking though Navy fences
on April 1, when Navy planes resumed dropping inert bombs
on the island's firing range after a pause of several months.

The five did not mount defenses to their trespassing charges
because they say they don't recognize the federal court's
authority in the U.S. territory.

"Vieques is the most open and painful wound of our country,"
Maria de Lourdes Santiago, leader of the five and vice president
of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, said before her sentencing.
She said the situation illustrates "what it means to live
in a country where others rule."

The five - also including Irma Rodriguez, Maria Elena Negron,
Mirna Rodriguez and Maribel Arroyo - will receive credit
for time already served in jail.

Handing down the sentences, Judge Salvador Casellas said
he respected the defendants' ideology, but "in my opinion
the acts of civil disobedience that have occurred in Vieques
at this moment aren't justified."

He said that because the United States is at war, Puerto
Ricans as U.S. citizens have "a responsibility" to support
national defense.

The judge also denied bail on Wednesday for five members
of the Socialist Movement group who were detained on Navy
lands this week, ordering them held until their trials are
scheduled.

Opponents of the Navy exercises say they harm the environment
and the health of Vieques' 9,100 residents. The Navy denies
that claim.

Although the protests have been muted since the Sept. 11
terrorist attacks, small bands of demonstrators have held
protests during the current round of exercises, which could
last up to three weeks. On Wednesday, no new arrests were
reported as U.S. warplanes dropped inert bombs on the firing
range.

Puerto Rico's small pro-independence party makes up only
one part of the opposition to Vieques training. Gov. Sila
Calderon, who supports the island's current commonwealth
status, also says the Navy should halt exercises.

Since maneuvers began April 1 on the outlying island, more
than a dozen people have been detained. The Navy says 13
sailors and Marines have been injured by protesters throwing
rocks and other objects. The demonstrators say their protests
have been peaceful.

President Bush says the Navy will leave by 2003. The Navy
says it is looking for alternative training sites.
---------------------------------------------------------------
This article is protected by copyright and should
not be printed or distributed for anything except
personal use.

You can find this story on the web at:
http://www.nandotimes.com/nation/story/355022p-2891390c.html

_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: 
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

Message:

Vieques protesters sentenced; trespasses not 'justified'

By MANUEL ERNESTO RIVERA
Associated Press

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (April 10, 2002 10:48 p.m. EDT) - Five

"Vieques is the most open and painful wound of our country,"

The judge also denied bail on Wednesday for five members
of the Socialist Movement group who were detained on Navy
lands this week, ordering them held until their trials are
scheduled.

and the health of Vieques' 9,100 residents. The Navy denies
that claim.

Although the protests have been muted since the Sept. 11
terrorist attacks, small bands of demonstrators have held
protests during the current round of exercises, which could

range.

one part of the opposition to Vieques training. Gov. Sila
Calderon, who supports the island's current commonwealth
status, also says the Navy should halt exercises.

Since maneuvers began April 1 on the outlying island, more
than a dozen people have been detained. The Navy says 13
sailors and Marines have been injured by protesters throwing
rocks and other objects. The demonstrators say their protests
have been peaceful.

President Bush says the Navy will leave by 2003. The Navy
says it is looking for alternative training sites.
---------------------------------------------------------------
This article is protected by copyright and should
not be printed or distributed for anything except
personal use.

You can find this story on the web at:
http://www.nandotimes.com/nation/story/355022p-2891390c.html

Post ID:2671
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-15 21:19:27
Subject:elected school board activists' trial 10am, fri apr19
Message:

2 witness statements:

To whom it may concern:

I was sitting in the auditorium at New Brunswick High School waiting for the 
Board members to return from their private session.  I heard a voice saying, 
"Please, don't touch me."  I turned toward the back of the auditorium, I saw 
Cliff Smith standing in the aisle with his hands behind his back clasped 
together.  Surrounding him were security guards saying to Cliff, "You have 
to leave the building."  The security guards were pushing him towards the 
door.  Cliff kept saying, "Please, don't touch me."  I saw the security 
guards slam Cliff Smith against the entrance door of the auditorium and 
pushed him outside the door.  His hands were still clasped behind his back.  
At that moment the Board returned to the auditorium.  I heard a disturbance 
in the hallway.  I saw Mrs. Moody, NBHS attendence officer, walk down the 
aisle of the auditorium toward the stage.  She returned with Mr. Embrey, the 
principal of NBHS. They walked outside of the auditorium toward the voices.

Beverly Marshall
President, New Brunswick Apartments Tenants' Association


To whom it may concern:

In honor so that the truth comes to light, I would like to testify my 
rendition of what I was a witness to of events that occured on the night of 
January 15th circa the time of 7:15 pm at New Brunswick High School.

Having a clear view as I sat within the central seating section of the 
institution's auditorium in attendance of a public meeting held by the New 
Brunswick Board of Education, on this night, I witnessed Cliff Smith, an 
individual that I have seen at several of these meetings within the same 
setting and have grown to hold conversations of a delicate educational 
nature, held a fervor converation with one Mr. Pierre Embrey, principal of 
the institution to which my daughters attend.  The conversation escalated 
due to the fact that Mr. Cliff Smith was passing out literature with the 
school's results of state mandatory examination.  I was able to observe that 
Mr. Embrey had in his hands papers, which he tried to give to Mr. Cliff 
Smith and Mr. Smith rose his hands high in the air as Mr. Embrey forced them 
upon his person and down his shirt.  Mr. Embrey told Mr. Smith to leave and 
forced him out of the auditorium using the aid of security guards although 
he did not resist.  After he was thrown out of the auditorium all we saw 
heard him exclaim was the fact that he was in a public meeting.

Next Mr. Embrey and Donald Bowling proceeded to take out Mr. Smith's brother 
Joe Smith out of the auditorium with brute force and throwing him up against 
the wall.  While Mr. Donald Bowling held him crucified up against the wall 
and repeatedly proceeded to push him repeatedly which caused him to hit his 
head several times against the wall.  Then Mr. Joe Smith was thrown to the 
ground and held had his neck under massive pressure from the force applied 
to it by Mr. Embrey's knee as evident from the screaming exhibited by Mr. 
Joe Smith.  Mr. Embrey then went into Mr. Joe Smith's pocket and retrieved a 
cellular phone stating would confiscate it because Mr. Joe Smith had been 
making bomb threats to the school.  Mr. Smign said it was his personal phone 
and that Embrey had no right to take it.  The police arrived and Mr. Joe 
Smith left with the authorities without contest.

I hold everything written in this letter to be the truth and self-evident.  
I cannot certify any previous actions by the Smiths that would have provoked 
this event.  However, their behavior was nothing but passive while Mr. 
Embrey and Mr. Donald Bowling exhibited in my opinion what would be an abuse 
of authority through aggressive behavior with loose cannon composure.

Attentively,

Ivan Salazar
President, Bilingual Parents' Association of New Brunswick






unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2672
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-15 23:08:24
Subject:For ALL Douglass College Students--DCGA Elections 4/16-17--VOTE!
Message:

Douglass College Government Association elections will be held in the
Douglass College Center on Tuesday, April 16 and Wednesday, April 17. The
DCGA, the democratically-elected, student-controlled student government
organization of Douglass College, has the power to represent students to
administrators at the College and the University, carry student voices to
the state and the nation, organize students for action, and provide funding
and allocations to all student organizations.

As such, progressive members of DCGA have committed to running on a
ticket--the DOUGLASS UNITED ticket--dedicated to organizing and acting to
win student democracy at the University and real democracy within the city
of New Brunswick. We are dedicated to a twelve-point platform:
1. Defend Cultural Studies and Academics--Fight the Budget Cuts!
2. Stand Against Tuition Hikes
3. Increase and improve Cultural Programs and Centers
4. Justice in Funding and Allocations
5. Smash Oppression
6. Support and Value the Traditions of Douglass
7. Fight for Student Democracy
8. Sponsor Live Programs and Parties
9. Better General Services
10. Improve Recruitment and Retention
11.Unite Campus and Community
12. Support Women's Services

We are running a full slate of candidates in the DCGA elections, for all
positions--every Douglass United candidate will have "Douglass United"
printed by her name on election ballots! If you are interested in supporting
a campaign for justice and ensuring that student government is strongly
representative of student concerns and struggle, VOTE DOUGLASS UNITED!

For more information, see our website at http://douglassunited.pathbot.com/

-Charlotte

                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:2675
Sender:can_bush@...
Post Date/Time:2002-04-18 16:14:26
Subject:NYTimes.com Article: Private Groups Get 42 Schools in Philadelphia
Message:

This article from NYTimes.com 
has been sent to you by can_bush@....


defend public education!
win the NB Elected Board of Education 2002!!

can_bush@...

/-------------------- advertisement -----------------------\


Enjoy new investment freedom!

Get the tools you need to successfully manage your portfolio
from Harrisdirect.  Start with award-winning research.  Then
add access to round-the-clock customer service from
Series-7 trained representatives.  Open an account today and
receive a $100 credit!

http://www.harrisdirect.com/b4.htm?OINYT100C

\----------------------------------------------------------/


Private Groups Get 42 Schools in Philadelphia

April 18, 2002 

By JACQUES STEINBERG


 

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 - In what is believed to be the
largest experiment in privatization mounted by an American
school district, a state panel charged with improving the
Philadelphia public school system voted tonight to transfer
control of 42 failing city schools to seven outside
managers, including Edison Schools Inc. and two
universities. 

The three members of the School Reform Commission appointed
by Gov. Mark Schweiker voted for the plan, while the two
members appointed by Mayor John F. Street voted against it.
The vote capped a fiery three-hour meeting in which the two
sides had split over whether Edison, the nation's largest
for-profit operator of public schools, had the capacity and
know-how to improve the 20 schools that it was assigned. 

"I want this reform to succeed," Michael Masch, a vice
president at the University of Pennsylvania and one of the
mayor's two appointees to the panel, said at one point in
the debate. "I am gravely concerned that the magnitude of
the change being proposed is imprudent." 

Moments later, James P. Gallagher, the president of
Philadelphia University and one of the governor's three
appointees, said, "We should push the envelope and be as
aggressive as possible." 

The panel's vote today represents a milestone in the
decade-long growth of the movement to turn troubled public
schools over to private operators. There is no better index
of the impact of this effort than Edison's own expansion:
over the last six years, it has gone from operating a
handful of public schools to more than 130 in 22 states,
with a combined student population that is larger than all
but a few dozen urban districts. 

All told, the Philadelphia panel voted to assign an outside
manager to one of every six schools in the city. In
addition to Edison, the other organizations involved
include two colleges that are in Philadelphia: Temple
University, which was assigned five schools, and the
University of Pennsylvania, which received three schools. 

The panel also tapped four other companies with various
degrees of school administrative experience, though each
was smaller than Edison. They are Chancellor Beacon
Academies Inc., a for-profit company based in Florida that
operates public and private schools (assigned five
schools); Foundations Inc., a nonprofit organization in
Philadelphia that offers after-school programs (four
schools); Victory Schools Inc., a New York-based company
that opened the state's first charter school (three
schools); and Universal Companies, a new venture begun by
the record producer Kenny Gamble (two schools). 

How much responsibility those managers would be given in
the schools that they have been assigned remains to be
negotiated with the state panel, as well as with the
teachers' union and the parents in those schools. But panel
officials said that, in many instances, the outsiders would
likely make sweeping changes in school curriculum, as well
as seek to replace school administrators and many of the
teachers. 

After the meeting, Jerry Jordan, a vice president of the
Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, said he regretted that
the panel had said so little about how the schools would be
redesigned by the outsiders. 

"They didn't spell anything out," Mr. Jordan said. "It's
like, `Let's see what works.' It shows a total lack of
respect." 

After the roll was called, several dozen student
protesters, who have long argued that it was undemocratic
for a for-profit company to operate a public school,
chanted, "Shame!" and "I am not for sale!" 

Beginning at daybreak, those same protesters had succeeded
in shutting down the system's Art Deco administrative
building on Benjamin Franklin Parkway by forming a
barricade at the entrance. Neither police officers nor the
building's 350 employees were willing to cross the line. As
a result, the meeting, which had been scheduled for 1 p.m.
at district headquarters, was delayed for two hours then
was moved to the city's African American Museum, nearly a
mile away. 

Today's developments were the most significant here since
late December, when Mr. Schweiker, a Republican, assumed
control of the city school system, which had been operated
by a board of education appointed entirely by Mr. Street, a
Democrat. At the time, Mr. Schweiker said that only a bold
approach could save a system in which more than half of the
nearly 200,000 students had failed to achieve minimum
proficiency on state reading and math tests. 

The governor had also made clear at the time that he wanted
Edison, which operates more than 130 public schools in 22
states, to play a major role in Philadelphia. Though the 20
schools that the company was awarded today was more than
double the number it manages in any other district, the
assignment was far more modest than the 60 Philadelphia
schools that it said it was capable of managing. 

Indeed, the governor had once argued that Edison should
assume control of the system's central administration.
Later, he retreated in the face of opposition from many
parents and students, as well as the teachers' union and
other labor groups representing school employees. They
questioned Edison's academic and financial record. 

At a news conference, James P. Nevels, the panel's
chairman, said of Edison's role, "Things have not turned
out as one would have expected." 

Still, a majority of the panel members managed to pass a
school reform plan in Philadelphia today that was more
ambitious than those mounted in any other district. 

The largest such plan previously was believed to have been
in Hartford, where all 32 schools in the district were
given over to the company Education Alternatives Inc. for
less than two years in the mid-1990's. But largely because
the Hartford experience failed relatively quickly, other
districts have usually embarked on more modest experiments,
with Edison now operating nine schools in Chester-Upland,
Pa., outside Philadelphia, and seven in Clark County, Nev.,
the Las Vegas district. 

In addition to the 42 schools that the Philadelphia panel
assigned to outside managers, it also ordered that 28 other
schools undergo substantial reorganization, with some
becoming more independent charter schools but most
remaining within direct control of the district. In the
cases of the schools identified today for private
intervention, the panel reserved the right to revoke a
contract in instances where the schools fail to improve.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/18/education/18EDIS.html?ex=1020160865&ei=1&en=e77782e7193f0b6e



HOW TO ADVERTISE
---------------------------------
For information on advertising in e-mail newsletters 
or other creative advertising opportunities with The 
New York Times on the Web, please contact
onlinesales@... or visit our online media 
kit at http://www.nytimes.com/adinfo

For general information about NYTimes.com, write to 
help@....  

Copyright 2002 The New York Times Company

Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-19 12:26:44
Subject:Fw: http://faar.pathbot.com - Register today!
Message:


> hey, there, ladies.  please forward like mad and
> register yrself for this kick-ass event.  i'd love to
> see you there.
>
> CALLING ALL FEMINISTS, ACTIVISTS,
> ACADEMICS, FREAKS AND MUSIC FANS!
>
> F.A.A.R. presents. . .
>
> **************************
> * A MATCH MADE IN HELL!  *
> * A Critical Conference  *
> * for Feminist Activists *
> **************************
>
> *when*
> Saturday, April 27, 2002
> 9:00AM - midnight(ish)
>
> *where*
> Womens Scholarship and Leadership Complex
> Ruth Dill Johnson Crockett Building
> 162 Ryders Lane
> Douglass Campus @ Rutgers University
> New Brunswick, NJ 08901
>
> *featuring*
> workshops, panels, arts & crafts, and a
> spectacular performance! and the whole
> event is TOTALLY FREE OF CHARGE!
>
> *for more info*
> visit http://faar.pathbot.com to register.
> or scroll down for the long and juicy details!
>
> *made possible by*
> Womens Defense Coalition, Rutgers University
> Womens Center, LLEGO, LABIA, DCGA, Womens
> and Gender Studies Department, our pioneering
> feminist foremothers and you!
>
> ************************************************
> ************************************************
> FAAR Mission Statement
>
> This action-oriented feminist conference is
> brought to you, with love and free of charge, by
> FAAR (Feminist Activists/ Academics at Rutgers)
> Through a variety of mediums, including but not
> limited to: workshops, panels, a keynote speaker,
> an activist do-it-yourself room, and a nighttime
> variety show, we will point to the myriad ways
> that feminist theory successfully enhances,
> shapes, and directs our feminist street activism.
> Simultaneously, we strive to address the failures
> of academic theory to be accountable to wimmins
> everyday lives.  As activists/academics, we hope
> to offer our attendees hands-on opportunities for
> actions and dialogues that fuse theory & practice.
> Paying close attention to the various sites of
> theory making and activism, we will equip
> participants with the necessary tools to sketch
> out responsible hybrid blueprints.
>
> *SHEDULE OF EVENTS*
>
> 9:00am
> Free Registration and Continental Breakfast
>
> 9:30am - 10:40am    SESSION ONE
> Cultural/Locational Mapping: a physical exercise
> influenced by Jan Cohen-Cruz, Cultural Mapping
> is aimed at exploring and utilizing our multiple
> locations as critical activists.  Combining
> accountability, self-awareness, and hands-on
> practice, this fun session fully welcomes and
> initiates participants into our conference.
>
> 11:00am - 12:15pm    KEYNOTE ADDRESS
> Professor Ellen Messer-Davidow, University of
> Minnesota, will present, Academic Knowledge
> and Social Activism? sharing her work on the
> production of knowledge and its connection to
> social movements and change, to encourage
> responsible, effective activisms and theory.
>
> 12:30pm - 1:50pm   SESSION TWO (your choice of:)
>
> * Theory in Action: This artistically inclined
> workshop will begin with a roundtable discussion
> by performance artist Susana Cook, high school art
> teacher and visual artist Kiera Nagle, and high
> school filmmaker Lucy MacKinnon, discussing the
> activist possibilities of their artistic mediums.
> Attendees will then develop an action plan with
> their artistic medium of choice.
>
> * Urgency and Agency: a roundtable discussion
> featuring New Brunswicks Womens Center for
> Global Leadership policy advocate/activist Lisa
> Clarke and American University-based punk rock
> activist/academic/feminist/dyke Susan Glen,
> focusing on the immediate need for informed,
> powerful, system-reconfiguring critical feminist
> writing. Moderated by Cheryl Clarke, former
> editor of the lesbian journal Conditions,
> contributor to This Bridge Called My Back, and
> Director of Diverse Community Affairs.
>
> 2pm - 4:30pm   BREAK TIME!
> Eat some lunch, enjoy RU Ag-Field Day or the NJ
> Folk Festival (right across the street!) or hang
> out in the DIY room to work on a project, network
> with other activists, and plan revolutions!
>
> 4:30pm - 5:50pm   SESSION THREE  (choose one:)
>
> * Activist Training: Want to make your activism
> more critical? Want to develop your activist
> skills? Want to be more informed by feminist
> theory?  This is the place to be. Join Rutgers
> professor and long-time feminist activist Drucilla
> Cornell, to bring more theory into the streets!
>
> * Theory-Making Training:  Singer/songwriter/
> critical activist/anarchist (and graduate school
> drop-out!) Jolie Rickman leads this workshop for
> academics and critical writers wishing to develop
> their activist skills. Want to break out of the
> ivory tower?  Be here.  Judith Butler: beware!
>
>
> OPEN ALL DAY!!  DIY (Do-It-Yourself) Activist Room
> For all you crafty grrrls.  Make homemade reusable
> menstrual pads, punk rock feminist patches and
> buttons, or a new skirt in *any* size!
>
> 6:00 - 8:00pm   DINNER & ACTIVISM
> Pizza and drinks are free for all registered
> participants, so be sure to register in advance.
> During this time, there will be a workshop
> facilitated by the Street Harassment Project.
>
> 8:00pm    NIGHTTIME VARIETY SHOW-- WIMMIN ROCK
> Free for all registered participants, this show
> is going to rock your world! You'll rarely see
> such a diverse line-up of feminist talent: queer
> new wave punkers the Crowns on 45, performance
> artists The Mahina Movement, singer/songwriter
> Cathie Martino, classical Indian dance, hardcore
> emo grrrl band Morgan Storm, anarchist/activist/
> musician Jolie Rickman, feminist punk-folk singer
> Gina Young, drag kings Shordan Easy & Shtik Rik,
> indigenous performance artists Colorado Sisters,
> an excerpt from the Vagina Monologues, and MORE!
>
> ** REGISTRATION INFORMATION **
>
> Email: amatchmadeinhell@...
> (Marisa, Valsala, Carolina and Lizzy)
>

> Elizabeth M. Spohr, Rutgers
> 27731 DPO Way
> New Brunswick, NJ 08901

> 1) full name
> 2) contact information
>    (email is preferred but phone is okay too)
> 3) dietary restrictions
>    (i.e. vegan, vegetarian, diabetic)
> 4) overnight housing needs
> 5) childcare needs
> 6) any other accommodation needs
>    (i.e. disability access, interpreters)
>
> You can, of course, register on-site the day of.

> http://womens-studies.rutgers.edu/home/directions.html

> When you get off the train go downstairs to the
> nearby corner of George Street and Somerset Street,
> and then follow campus bus directions.
