Post ID:2678
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-20 11:29:51
Subject:Vieques Leader Sentenced!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urgently asking folks to read this and 
forward out the recent repressive activities that the Pro-Navy and 
Pro-Colonial forces have committed.  PLEASE READ THE SUMMARY BELOW!!


FREE THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS!!
FREE THE VIEQUES POLITICAL PRISONERS!!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Robert Rabin, one of the key leaders of the peace
movement in Vieques, was given an unconscionably lengthy jail
sentence of six (6) months yesterday by magistrate judge Gustavo
Gelpi of the federal district court in Puerto Rico.  Gelpi also
sentenced attorney Hiram Lozada P�rez, President of the Civil Rights
Commission of the Puerto Rican Bar Association, to four (4) months in
jail, and sentenced Iv�n El�as Rodr�guez and Oscar Charriez to one
hundred days in jail.  Gelpi additionally imposed fines on them.
Their crimes? A misdemeanor for trespassing by entering the bombing
range in Vieques. As he has done with other protesters, Gelpi's
sentencing went beyond what the prosecutors recommended.  Other key
leaders of the Vieques peace movement have also received absurdly
lengthy prison sentences, for example, Vieques Mayor Damaso Serrano
(4 months), Vieques Fishermen Association's President Carlos Zenon (6
months), and others.]

movement in Vieques, was given an unconscionably lengthy jail
sentence of six (6) months yesterday by magistrate judge Gustavo
Gelpi of the federal district court in Puerto Rico.  Gelpi also
sentenced attorney Hiram Lozada P�rez, President of the Civil Rights
Commission of the Puerto Rican Bar Association, to four (4) months in

hundred days in jail.  Gelpi additionally imposed fines on them.

range in Vieques. As he has done with other protesters, Gelpi's

Post ID:2681
Sender:"can_bush@... and NJ.com"<can_bush@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-20 19:13:44
Subject:Check out this page on NJ.com
Message:

Dear organizer:

joesmith (can_bush@...) thought you would be interested in this item from NJ.com.

http://www.nj.com/news/ledger/essex/index.ssf?/base/news-0/1019216238157251.xml

Post ID:2683
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-21 11:01:19
Subject:Antonio Camacho Negron Released-May 20th!!
Message:

Please contact ProLibertad@... if you are interested in endorsing 
and MOBILIZING for this very special reception!!
___________________________________________________________________
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign invites all of our supporters and allies to 
a very special reception for our brother Antonio Camacho Negron!!

Whenever one of our Political Prisoners is set free it is an international 
victory against imperialism, racism, repression and must be celebrated!!

On Monday May 20th, Antonio Camacho Negron will be released from FCI 
Allenwood and will be coming to New York for one night.

We invite you to a reception at St. Mary's Episcopal Church at 6:30pm, we 
ask folks to come and show their solidarity with Antonio and with the Puerto 
Rican Liberation struggle!!

WE WILL HAVE DELICIOUS PUERTO RICAN FOOD, FUN, LIVE MUSIC, DANCING, AND 
PERFORMANCES BY THE WELFARE POETS, MARIPOSA AND MORE...

Monday May 20th, 2002 at 6:30pm
St. Mary's Episcopal Church
521 w126th St. (between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)
Take the 1 or 9 train to 125th St. and Broadway

***** We are asking all political organizations and campaigns to endorse 
this activity and help us MOBILIZE for this monumental event!!  To become an 
endorser please email ProLibertad@... ******

*****We are also trying to raise funds for Antonio's expenses and travel 
costs.  If you are interested in donating to Antonio Please make your tax 
dedcutible donation to:

IFCO/ProLibertad for Antonio Camacho Negron
402 w145th St., NY, NY 10031

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
______________________________________________________________________
BELOW IS A STATEMENT WRITTEN BY ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON ON HIS RELEASE
______________________________________________________________________
Dear Compatriots:

This afternoon I do not find myself physically close to all of you, but my 
heart, my thoughts and my words are with you during this commemoration of 
the birth of Juan Antonio Corretjer.  Because I have sent a written message, 
  I will be brief.

As all of you know, I have rejected, time and again, every attempt by the 
government of the United States to criminalize our legitimate right to 
struggle for our independence by the recognized avenues afforded us
by our high moral standards, history and international law.

I have repeatedly denounced colonialism and a conditional freedom and 
consistent with this I have also rejected the conditional freedom that the 
United States government has sought to impose upon me in the
same manner in which I reject the conditional freedom under which our Puerto 
Rican homeland suffers.

On May 9th two-thirds of my sentence will be done.  According to the laws of 
the empire my release is mandatory.  Because I continue to reject any type 
of conditions for this supposed freedom, the government of the United States 
will hold me until May 20th with the purpose of having me report to the 
Federal Building in Puerto Rico.  I completely reject that condition.

I invite you to join me in front of the Federal Building (in Puerto Rico) on 
May 22nd at noon, not to sign for my freedom, but to reaffirm our freedom 
and our Puertoricanness.

Compatriots:

The independence of our homeland will not be a gift that is granted to us by 
the Congress of the  United States:  The independence of our homeland must 
be taken, we must win it.

Empires are not deities, they are structures lead by men and women.  They 
are omnipotent while there exist men and women that because of ignorance, 
opportunism or cowardice, surrender their souls and are
indifferent to its injustices and harm.

Don Pedro said:   "We do not have the arms to deal a blow to their naval 
forces, but we have the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in 
the eyes of the world."

Many constantly repeat these words, but they are not empty words.  In this 
concept lies the key to our independence.

We who believe in the independence of our country, who grasp the urgency of 
becoming a free and sovereign nation have to bury defeatism and develop the 
aunthentic support of the majority.

We can not content ourselves with exercising some influences or to establish 
some goals.  Even less should we find satisfaciton in the electoral carnival 
that takes place every four years - suicidal faith in elections and our 
participatory collaboration in them - have robbed our people of the natural 
tendency to be free.

The present conditions favor us and call for us to become a minority for 
change; a minority is a force for transformation. A minority will be an 
authentic support of the majority.

The Sovereignty, dignity and liberty of our people cannot be conditioned by 
fear, by myopic interests, opportunism or ignorance, even if it comes from 
the majority.  The banners of freedom, sovereignty and dignity of the people 
have never first been championed by the broad masses.  It has always been a 
minority that through its example of persistance, love, sacrifice and 
courage, has brought the masses to embrace these ideals.

Independentistas, are not a majority but we are the legitimate 
representatives of the freedom and dignity of our homeland.  More than a 
duty we have to ourselves, it is our responsibility to the men and women who 
have given their lives or have dedicated them to this sacred ideal.  More 
so, it is our responsibility to future generations and to humanity itself.

To struggle for independence is to struggle for the highest universal values 
of justice, dignity, sovereignty and liberty.  And while there exists even 
one colony in the world, these values will be contested. Humanity has paid a 
very dear price for these and will can not and will not betray them.

Let us remember our compatriots!

" We do not have the arms to deal a blow to the naval forces, but we have 
the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in the eyes of the 
world."

This is their achilles heal.
This is our challenge.

Thank you all.

Antonio Camacho Negron
#03587-069
P.O. Box 2000
White Deer, PA 17887







_________________________________________________________________
Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

BELOW IS A STATEMENT WRITTEN BY ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON ON HIS RELEASE
______________________________________________________________________
Dear Compatriots:

This afternoon I do not find myself physically close to all of you, but my 
heart, my thoughts and my words are with you during this commemoration of 
the birth of Juan Antonio Corretjer.  Because I have sent a written message, 
  I will be brief.

As all of you know, I have rejected, time and again, every attempt by the 
government of the United States to criminalize our legitimate right to 
struggle for our independence by the recognized avenues afforded us
by our high moral standards, history and international law.

I have repeatedly denounced colonialism and a conditional freedom and 
consistent with this I have also rejected the conditional freedom that the 
United States government has sought to impose upon me in the
same manner in which I reject the conditional freedom under which our Puerto 
Rican homeland suffers.

On May 9th two-thirds of my sentence will be done.  According to the laws of 
the empire my release is mandatory.  Because I continue to reject any type 
of conditions for this supposed freedom, the government of the United States 
will hold me until May 20th with the purpose of having me report to the 
Federal Building in Puerto Rico.  I completely reject that condition.

I invite you to join me in front of the Federal Building (in Puerto Rico) on 
May 22nd at noon, not to sign for my freedom, but to reaffirm our freedom 
and our Puertoricanness.

Compatriots:

The independence of our homeland will not be a gift that is granted to us by 
the Congress of the  United States:  The independence of our homeland must 
be taken, we must win it.

Empires are not deities, they are structures lead by men and women.  They 
are omnipotent while there exist men and women that because of ignorance, 
opportunism or cowardice, surrender their souls and are
indifferent to its injustices and harm.

Don Pedro said:   "We do not have the arms to deal a blow to their naval 
forces, but we have the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in 
the eyes of the world."

Many constantly repeat these words, but they are not empty words.  In this 
concept lies the key to our independence.

We who believe in the independence of our country, who grasp the urgency of 
becoming a free and sovereign nation have to bury defeatism and develop the 
aunthentic support of the majority.

We can not content ourselves with exercising some influences or to establish 
some goals.  Even less should we find satisfaciton in the electoral carnival 
that takes place every four years - suicidal faith in elections and our 
participatory collaboration in them - have robbed our people of the natural 
tendency to be free.

The present conditions favor us and call for us to become a minority for 
change; a minority is a force for transformation. A minority will be an 
authentic support of the majority.

The Sovereignty, dignity and liberty of our people cannot be conditioned by 
fear, by myopic interests, opportunism or ignorance, even if it comes from 
the majority.  The banners of freedom, sovereignty and dignity of the people 
have never first been championed by the broad masses.  It has always been a 
minority that through its example of persistance, love, sacrifice and 
courage, has brought the masses to embrace these ideals.

Independentistas, are not a majority but we are the legitimate 
representatives of the freedom and dignity of our homeland.  More than a 
duty we have to ourselves, it is our responsibility to the men and women who 
have given their lives or have dedicated them to this sacred ideal.  More 
so, it is our responsibility to future generations and to humanity itself.

To struggle for independence is to struggle for the highest universal values 
of justice, dignity, sovereignty and liberty.  And while there exists even 
one colony in the world, these values will be contested. Humanity has paid a 
very dear price for these and will can not and will not betray them.

Let us remember our compatriots!

" We do not have the arms to deal a blow to the naval forces, but we have 
the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in the eyes of the 
world."

This is their achilles heal.
This is our challenge.

Thank you all.

Antonio Camacho Negron
#03587-069
P.O. Box 2000
White Deer, PA 17887

BELOW IS A STATEMENT WRITTEN BY ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON ON HIS RELEASE
______________________________________________________________________
Dear Compatriots:

This afternoon I do not find myself physically close to all of you, but my 
heart, my thoughts and my words are with you during this commemoration of 
the birth of Juan Antonio Corretjer.  Because I have sent a written message, 
  I will be brief.

As all of you know, I have rejected, time and again, every attempt by the 
government of the United States to criminalize our legitimate right to 
struggle for our independence by the recognized avenues afforded us
by our high moral standards, history and international law.

I have repeatedly denounced colonialism and a conditional freedom and 
consistent with this I have also rejected the conditional freedom that the 
United States government has sought to impose upon me in the
same manner in which I reject the conditional freedom under which our Puerto 
Rican homeland suffers.

On May 9th two-thirds of my sentence will be done.  According to the laws of 
the empire my release is mandatory.  Because I continue to reject any type 
of conditions for this supposed freedom, the government of the United States 
will hold me until May 20th with the purpose of having me report to the 
Federal Building in Puerto Rico.  I completely reject that condition.

I invite you to join me in front of the Federal Building (in Puerto Rico) on 
May 22nd at noon, not to sign for my freedom, but to reaffirm our freedom 
and our Puertoricanness.

Compatriots:

The independence of our homeland will not be a gift that is granted to us by 
the Congress of the  United States:  The independence of our homeland must 
be taken, we must win it.

Empires are not deities, they are structures lead by men and women.  They 
are omnipotent while there exist men and women that because of ignorance, 
opportunism or cowardice, surrender their souls and are
indifferent to its injustices and harm.

Don Pedro said:   "We do not have the arms to deal a blow to their naval 
forces, but we have the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in 
the eyes of the world."

Many constantly repeat these words, but they are not empty words.  In this 
concept lies the key to our independence.

We who believe in the independence of our country, who grasp the urgency of 
becoming a free and sovereign nation have to bury defeatism and develop the 
aunthentic support of the majority.

We can not content ourselves with exercising some influences or to establish 
some goals.  Even less should we find satisfaciton in the electoral carnival 
that takes place every four years - suicidal faith in elections and our 
participatory collaboration in them - have robbed our people of the natural 
tendency to be free.

The present conditions favor us and call for us to become a minority for 
change; a minority is a force for transformation. A minority will be an 
authentic support of the majority.

The Sovereignty, dignity and liberty of our people cannot be conditioned by 
fear, by myopic interests, opportunism or ignorance, even if it comes from 
the majority.  The banners of freedom, sovereignty and dignity of the people 
have never first been championed by the broad masses.  It has always been a 
minority that through its example of persistance, love, sacrifice and 
courage, has brought the masses to embrace these ideals.

Independentistas, are not a majority but we are the legitimate 
representatives of the freedom and dignity of our homeland.  More than a 
duty we have to ourselves, it is our responsibility to the men and women who 
have given their lives or have dedicated them to this sacred ideal.  More 
so, it is our responsibility to future generations and to humanity itself.

To struggle for independence is to struggle for the highest universal values 
of justice, dignity, sovereignty and liberty.  And while there exists even 
one colony in the world, these values will be contested. Humanity has paid a 
very dear price for these and will can not and will not betray them.

Let us remember our compatriots!

" We do not have the arms to deal a blow to the naval forces, but we have 
the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in the eyes of the 
world."

This is their achilles heal.
This is our challenge.

Thank you all.

Antonio Camacho Negron
#03587-069
P.O. Box 2000
White Deer, PA 17887

Post ID:2688
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 09:45:52
Subject:POP proposal
Message:

to POP,
on behalf of the new brunswick peoples campaign, i must state that we are 
very disappointed with the lack of POP's involvement in newark's may 14 
election.

one would think that an organization with such "Progressive" positions would 
jump at the chance to work to elect ras baraka. there will be earl faisons 
until the cows come home unless we organize these communities to win 
political power. all those rallies become meaningless without political 
direction. political direction exists in the baraka campaign for council 
At-Large, but yet POP is satisfied with just the rally/march/lobbying?

yes we know, we have seen hamm here & hamm there at baraka events - but hamm 
is not POP & POP is not there.

how can POP demand community police control boards for newark, but not 
actively support the candidate that CAN WIN & will draft up this 
legislation? why is POP going to lobby trenton about police misconduct &tc., 
when those positions can be implemented here in newark?

nbpc proposes that POP immediately put all resources toward electing ras 
baraka on may 14. push back the trenton lobby date of may 15 and do the much 
needed work to elect ras baraka. this is a formal proposal, there is still 
time -
tic...

i remember in '98 hungerford/henson was a point person of the baraka 
campaign, among many other activities he brought me lunch on election day 
from baraka headquaters and drove me to diffent polling sites. now we see an 
organization from new brunswick put forward a better effort to elect ras 
baraka than POP? what should people think about this?

joe smith
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Post ID:2689
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 09:49:52
Subject:Fwd:"SOMEBODY BLEW UP AMERICA" BY AMIRI BARAKA
Message:

EXCERPT FROM  SOMEbody blew UP america  - amiri baraka

SOMEBODY
BLEW UP
AMERICA

(All thinking people
oppose terrorism
both domestic
& international...
But one should not
be used
To cover the other)

Who killed Rosa Luxembourg, Liebneckt
Who murdered the Rosenbergs
And all the good people iced,
tortured, assassinated, vanished

                   Who got rich from Algeria, Libya, Haiti
                          Iran, Iraq, Saudi, Kuwait, Lebanon,
                               Syria, Epypt, Jordan, Palestine,

Who cut off peoples hands in the Congo
Who invented Aids Who put the germs
In the Indians' blankets

Who thought up "the Trails of Tears"
Who blew up the Maine
& started the Spanish American War

Who got Sharon back in Power
Who backed Batista, Hitler, Bilbo,
Chiang kai Chek

who WHO  WHO

Who decided Affirmative Action had to go
Reconstruction, The New Deal,
The New Frontier, The Great Society,

                Who do Tom Ass Clarence Work for

            Who doo doo come out the Colon's mouth

       Who know what kind of Skeeza is a Condoleeza

             Who pay Connelly to be a wooden negro

    Who give Genius Awards to Homo Locus Subsidere

Who overthrew Nkrumah, Bishop,
Who poison Robeson,
Who try to put DuBois in Jail
Who frame Rap Jamil al Amin,
Who frame the Rosenbergs, Garvey, The Scottsboro Boys,
The Hollywood Ten

                        Who set the Reichstag Fire


       Who knew the World Trade Center was gonna get
                                        bombed

       Who told 4000 Israeli workers at the Twin Towers
                             To stay home that day

                           Why did Sharon stay away?




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

from Harrisdirect.  Start with award-winning research.  Then
add access to round-the-clock customer service from
Series-7 trained representatives.  Open an account today and
receive a $100 credit!

http://www.harrisdirect.com/b4.htm?OINYT100C

\----------------------------------------------------------/


Millions of Italians Take to the Streets in a General Strike

April 17, 2002 

By MELINDA HENNEBERGER


In the first daylong general strike in 20 years, millions of
Italian workers protested the conservative government's
plans to create a more flexible labor market.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/17/international/europe/17ITAL.html?ex=1020484701&ei=1&en=79d65a7f229847f5

---------------------------------

or other creative advertising opportunities with The
New York Times on the Web, please contact
onlinesales@... or visit our online media
kit at http://www.nytimes.com/adinfo

For general information about NYTimes.com, write to 
help@....  

Copyright 2002 The New York Times Company

Post ID:2691
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 11:33:16
Subject:Fwd: A New Play about NEW BRUNSWICK
Message:

>From: Kelly Ryman <kryman@...>
>Reply-To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
>To: hub city <TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com>, PRAB <PRAB@yahoogroups.com>
>Subject: [TheHubCityNJ] A New Play about NEW BRUNSWICK
>Date: Mon, 22 Apr 2002 10:41:32 -0400
>
>For Immediate Release
>April 22, 2002
>
>                      PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES
>     a new play celebrating NEW BRUNSWICK at George Street Playhouse
>      "NAME YOUR OWN PRICE" for Theatre Tickets on Tuesday, April 23
>
>A glorious sympohy of stories about our town...  tales of murder and
>arson; a baby saved and a baby lost; an impossible love between a free
>man and an enslaved woman; and three silver spoons that haunt a family
>for four generations... all come together under the embracing branches
>of Joyce Kilmer's immortalized tree.
>
>Inspired by the personal testimonies of present day New Brunswick area
>residents, PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES is a beautifully woven tapestry
>of over one hundred and eight years of Hispanic, Hungarian, Irish and
>African-American life in our town.
>
>"Name Your Own Price" tickets may be purchased in person at the box
>office on Tuesday, April 23 for that evening's 8 pm performance.  The
>price of the ticket is at the discretion of the person making the
>purchase (GSP asks that it be at least $1). The GSP box office will open
>at 10 am on Tuesday, April 23.
>
>PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES
>April 23 - May 19
>George Street Playhouse
>9 Livingston Avenue
>New Brunswick, NJ
>Regularly priced tickets range from $26 - $45 and are now on sale by
>calling (732) 246-7717.
>For more information, or to purchase tickets on-line visit
>www.georgestplayhouse.org.
>
>Public Ghosts-Private Stories is sponsored by the Gannett Foundation,
>Home News Tribune, Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, Magyar Savings Bank,
>the City of New Brunswick, Verizon, and in part by funds from the New
>Jersey State Council onf the Arts/Department of State, a Partner Agency
>of the National Endowment for the Arts and by funds from the National
>Endowment for the Arts.




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp.

Post ID:2692
Sender:Joseph Kaminski <jkaminsk@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 13:01:10
Subject:Re: [RUGreens] Fwd: A New Play about NEW BRUNSWICK
Message:

please remove me from this god-forsaken list

Joe Kaminski

On Mon, 22 Apr 2002, peoples campaign wrote:

> >From: Kelly Ryman <kryman@...>
> >Reply-To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
> >To: hub city <TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com>, PRAB <PRAB@yahoogroups.com>
> >Subject: [TheHubCityNJ] A New Play about NEW BRUNSWICK
> >Date: Mon, 22 Apr 2002 10:41:32 -0400
> >
> >For Immediate Release
> >April 22, 2002
> >
> >                      PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES
> >     a new play celebrating NEW BRUNSWICK at George Street Playhouse
> >      "NAME YOUR OWN PRICE" for Theatre Tickets on Tuesday, April 23
> >
> >A glorious sympohy of stories about our town...  tales of murder and
> >arson; a baby saved and a baby lost; an impossible love between a free
> >man and an enslaved woman; and three silver spoons that haunt a family
> >for four generations... all come together under the embracing branches
> >of Joyce Kilmer's immortalized tree.
> >
> >Inspired by the personal testimonies of present day New Brunswick area
> >residents, PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES is a beautifully woven tapestry
> >of over one hundred and eight years of Hispanic, Hungarian, Irish and
> >African-American life in our town.
> >
> >"Name Your Own Price" tickets may be purchased in person at the box
> >office on Tuesday, April 23 for that evening's 8 pm performance.  The
> >price of the ticket is at the discretion of the person making the
> >purchase (GSP asks that it be at least $1). The GSP box office will open
> >at 10 am on Tuesday, April 23.
> >
> >PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES
> >April 23 - May 19
> >George Street Playhouse
> >9 Livingston Avenue
> >New Brunswick, NJ
> >Regularly priced tickets range from $26 - $45 and are now on sale by
> >calling (732) 246-7717.
> >For more information, or to purchase tickets on-line visit
> >www.georgestplayhouse.org.
> >
> >Public Ghosts-Private Stories is sponsored by the Gannett Foundation,
> >Home News Tribune, Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, Magyar Savings Bank,
> >the City of New Brunswick, Verizon, and in part by funds from the New
> >Jersey State Council onf the Arts/Department of State, a Partner Agency
> >of the National Endowment for the Arts and by funds from the National
> >Endowment for the Arts.
> 
> 
>

> Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

>be used
>To cover the other)

>                                     It wasn't the Klan or the Skin heads

>                        Churches, or reincarnates us on Death Row

>It wasn't Trent Lott
>Or David Duke or Giuliani
>Or Schundler, Helms retiring
>

>the gonorrhea in costume
>the white sheet diseases
>That have murdered black people
>Terrorized reason and sanity
>Most of humanity, as they pleases
>

>                               The first plantation

>                                 Who rape your ma
>                             Who lynched your pa
>

>    Who had the match, who set the fires
>    Who killed and hired
>    Who say they God & still be the Devil
>

>                             Who the most goodest
>                          Who do Jesus resemble
>

>                                   Who the smartest
>                                    Who the greatest
>                                      Who the richest
>

>
>    Who define art
>    Who define science
>    Who made the guns
>    Who bought the slaves, who sold them
>

>
>                        Who say Dahmer wasn't insane

Post ID:2695
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 14:12:01
Subject:Fwd: Re: recommendation for POP involvement in Ras Baraka's campaign
Message:

>From: JeanRoss55@...
>To: nbpc_2002@...
>CC: poprogress@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: recommendation for POP involvement in Ras Baraka's campaign
>Date: Mon, 22 Apr 2002 13:21:03 EDT
>
>Hi Joe,
>
>I'm responding to your e-mail about POP's involvement in Ras Baraka's
>campaign, because I believe that it contains a good recommendation which is
>undermined by it's approach and tone. As an example of political
>conversation, I suggest that it is not likely to effectively elicit the
>support that you seek, but rather will either divert energy from our
>complementary modes of work or just be ignored.
>
>As a member of POP, an organization that I suspect is allied with or at 
>least
>has coals in common with NBPC,  I suggest that a positive approach relying 
>on
>the merits of the substance of your suggestion would be much more effective
>than personal and organizational attacks that denigrate the  complementary
>work that we do. Only the fifth paragraph of your e-mail contains a 
>positive
>proposal.
>
>Why did you take such an approach? Why can't we acknowledge complementary
>efforts? If there is disagreement about priorities, why can't they be aired
>without sarcasm and disdain. If there is a good argument for a particular 
>appr
>oach, then use that argument without denigrating others' priorities? Why 
>not
>urge, encourage and support the work of allied organizations? An approach
>that is not an attack is more likely to change people's minds. We have 
>enough
>common adversaries. Let's treat each other's allied organizations with
>courtesy and respect.
>
>On a substantive level, do you know the efforts that POP has made to 
>support
>Ras Baraka or what plans we have to do so? Have you spoken with him and his
>campaign about POP's involvement? If he wants more help or you think we
>should do more, then it is much more effective to ask for help in the work
>that needs to be done than to brag that your organization has done more? 
>Why
>not tell us what you have been doing and suggest ways that we add to 
>existing
>efforts?
>
>I am, myself, particularly "disappointed" that you would choose to 
>criticize
>the attention that POP has paid to the Faison case and the Faison family, 
>for
>several reasons.  I suggest that we need to tend to the needs of 
>individuals,
>because individuals need support in our society, individual struggles help 
>us
>understand systemic problems better, and such actions best demonstrate our
>underlying humanity.
>
>I agree that political direction is also necessary.
>
>I suspect that people in POP will pass by the unconstructive elements of 
>your
>e-mail, cut to the chase, and think about what we could and should be doing
>to help Ras. I certainly intend to bring up the substantive issue at
>Thursday's  meeting this week. So I hope that this e-mail will not spawn a
>diversion of analysis. This is simple stuff we should all know about how to
>work together. Please try to do better in the future.
>
>Jean Ross




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Post ID:2696
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 16:17:23
Subject:Fwd: Re: POP proposal
Message:

>From: makemba@...

Some people will say and do anything for a free lunch.

I must give my comments here.   And let me be very clear and upfront
in saying that I am not speaking for the organization right now.

It is not your suggestion per se that I object to, for I am always
open  to hearing suggestions from concerned people in the
community about things POP can and should
be doing.   What I object to is your arrogant and condescending
attitude that is thinly disguised as a suggestion.  And quite frankly,
you ain't got no reason to be arrogant or condescending!

As an individual member of POP I could personally give a hoot
as to whether or not your organization is satisfied with the work that
I do!   To put it bluntly --  I don't do things for the sake of impressing
people who live outside of my community.

I have seen this attitude before from certain people who live way outside of
this community.
They come around here with their little superior acting attitudes
and then think they are going to put people in this community down because
they don't think as they do!

I could go ON AND ON AND ON about the things I don't see your organization
doing!


People in POP have been fighting hard and have been on
the front line of these issues!   And we are comprised of
people who share many different ideologies that don't allow
are differences to get in the way of what we must do.

And POP was one of the first organizations to start to become
very vocal about issues that other organizations in NJ did not
want to touch!

Furthermore, people in POP LIVE THESE ISSUES ! ! !
We take a personal hands on approach with our community.
We don't just sit around and intellectualize and theorize about
things!

One of the main problems with the progessive movement in
this country is that there are those who LIVE it and there are
those for which this is a fad -- something "in" to do!   There are
those who can change their affiliations and ideas just as they are
changing their clothes.  When it's no longer vogue to belong to
the progressive movement they can just drop things and go right
back into their communities and get their nice jobs and call it
a day!  History proves me true on this point.

I remember about  a little over 10 years people were
talking about how they weren't liberal.   I don't recall anybody too much
talking about being liberal back in the 80's and 90's.
Then it simply wasn't fashionable for many
to be affiliated with progressive causes.

In fact back in 1991 when I was victimized by police brutality,
I couldn't find people who wanted to hear about it.  I had a difficult
enough time finding people locally.   And forget about finding
anyone who lived outside of this area!

I hope we won't see that trend again within the progressive movement!

So here's some advice.  Before you began to want to criticize others
make sure you look inward first.

Personally, I think your comment about your free lunch was very revealing.

Lisa Davis



New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!


_________________________________________________________________
Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

Baraka's campa...
Date: Tue, 23 Apr 2002 07:37:33 EDT

In a message dated 4/22/02 1:25:07 PM Eastern Daylight Time,
JeanRoss55@... writes:


 > I'm responding to your e-mail about POP's involvement in Ras Baraka's
 > campaign, because I believe that it contains a good recommendation which 
is
 > undermined by it's approach and tone

Thank you, Jean for saying what I'm sure so many of us feel about Mr. Joe
Smith's approach. Although he claims to be a communist, he still clearly has
not learned the difference between how to approach people's organizations 
and
how to approach our enemies. He says he upholds Mao but obviously doesn't
practice the wisdom contained in his supposed mentor's "On Contradiction,"
i.e., that  there is a difference between antagonistic and non-antagonistic
contradictions and therefore a difference in how we need to approach our
friends and our enemies.

I intend to become more involved in the Ras Baraka campaign between now and
election day, despite Mr. Smith. I only hope to be able to do so and at the
same time am able to stay as far way from Mr. Smith as possible. I think Ras
should be informed of the disservice Mr. Smith has done to his campaign by
attacking groups like POP and, before this, the Greens.

Joe Fortunato


New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Democrats vs. Israel

April 22, 2002 

By WILLIAM SAFIRE


Most of the leaders of the Democratic Party and its liberal
media voices distanced themselves from Israel in the midst
of its defense against Arafat's war.

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/22/opinion/22SAFI.html?ex=1020566455&ei=1&en=ca0e9410e42ecb1a

You have been sent this message from nbpc_2002@... as a courtesy of the Washington Post (http://www.washingtonpost.com).

contradictions amongst the ruling class must be exploited by the people. death to imperialism!!republicans in the garbage can!!
no support for green disrupters in state & nation elections. we must fight where we can win. 
SUPPORT RAS BARAKA!!
vote B-16!!


To view the entire article, go to http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A27349-2002Apr22.html

On Earth Day, Bush V. Gore

By Dan Balz and Dana Milbank

On the 32nd anniversary of Earth Day, President Bush said yesterday that his environmental initiatives would reduce power plant emissions more than those of any previous administration. But he faced a barrage of criticism from environmental groups and former rival Al Gore, who charged that Bush has broken his word and sold out to polluters and special interests.

>Well, Well, Well, Mr. Joe Smith ,
>
>I speak at this time not on behalf of POP. I am speaking
>as an individual who is a member of POP. Let it be known
>that in the organization of the People's Organization
>for Progress we reserve the right to our individuality
>although we are united under our "Aims and Purposes"
>which does not include endorsing specific parties or
>candidates or following specific religions. I will send
>you a copy of our newsletter which states the POP Aims
>and Purposes if you would like to have one.
>
>As for your disappointment, I am well aware of Ras
>Baraka's campaign. I live in Newark and have every
>intention of voting for him. By the way , I am still
>waiting for the window poster I was supposed to get as
>promised by one of the "involved campaign workers." Just
>because you have not seen people that you know as POP
>members down at the campaign headquarters, does not mean
>that there is no support for Ras by POP members. YOU
>SHOULD KNOW THAT! After all, is it more important for me
>to show up at the headquarters under the pretense of
>support or actually talking to my neighbors and co-
>workers about the great very qualified person I believe
>Ras to be. I support Ras everyday and maybe I might get
>a chance to get to the headquarters or maybe I won't. I
>ask you Mr. Joe Smith, by not showing up for you or
>anyone else to see, have I caused any harm to his
>campaign or have I convinced a few people to go to the
>polls on May 14th and cast a vote for Ras Baraka. As you
>have said , there is  still time-tic...  You speak , it
>appears without much thought but with much passion.
>Before you attack the POP members for lack of
>"involvement," think of another approach.
>
>Debby Brown

case of a probable run-off.

campaign. what happened? why has this not developed into 
more participation?

anything is more important to the struggle for democracy, ie. 
socialism, that we in new jersey can accomplish, then getting 
ras baraka elected to newark city council may 14.  my approach 
& tone aside, everything else can wait. -joe

Post ID:2705
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-25 09:17:39
Subject:Re: B-16 take it personal!!
Message:

*******the issue is this**********
there is no way for pop, fabw, or the greens to put forward that
any work is more important to the struggle for democracy, ie.
socialism, that we in new jersey can accomplish, then getting
ras baraka elected to newark city council may 14.� my approach
& tone aside, everything else can either be combined or wait.

debby, it is definitely not my "job" to look up directions, drive over, & 
stick a sign in your lawn. but if i didn't, who would? it is my DUTY to the 
struggle for democracy!! that is what the baraka campaign represents; an 
advance on behalf of the international peoples forces in the struggle for 
democracy. all those marching in DC did great, but a stronger show of 
international solidarity is to seize these local governments & our cities 
institutions.

what does that mean "leave it alone, let it be"?
it is POP's organizational DUTY to support & elect ras baraka (as an 
organization! not individuals!), anything less is a betrayal of those 
struggling right along side you. so no debby, NBPC will not let it be & we 
will not leave it alone. we will criticize & expose what we see as mistakes 
in POP & any other organization that claims to represent the people, in 
order to advance our collective struggle.

joe smith
new brunswick peoples campaign

Post ID:2706
Sender:"joseph smith" <can_bush@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-25 12:57:37
Subject:Re: No Longer A Green Party Listserve
Message:

higbee, how does the gp explain wasting much needed resources on no chance 
state&national campaigns when the independent movement in our local cities 
are losing elections?

your strategy has produced bush2, where is the greens self-criticism & 
growth?
that is the only way to re-start efforts in new brunswick.

side note- coleman for governor - 71 votes in new brunswick '01
                 - new brunswick campaign to win the elected school board 
campaign  - 2994 votes '00, peoples
                   campaign candidates - 2000+ votes '00

^^^proof that it is the local movement that the people will identify with^^^

dump fortunato, glick & all campaigns that cannot win!!
use all independent resources to organize locally - city councils, mayors 
&tc.

joe smith
new brunswick peoples campaign2002



>From: whcoon@...
>To: RUGreens@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [RUGreens] No Longer A Green Party Listserve
>Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2002 11:21:12 -0400
>
>Dear Friends,
>              Obviously, this listserve has served only as a soapbox for 
>Joseph Smith and the People's Campaign of New Burnswick. This list is no 
>longer a Green Party list. I have asked the Joseph Smith has stated on 
>several occasions that the Green Party is "ruled by Corporations" and "only 
>gets Republicans Elected". Now, I consider the RUGreens list his listserve, 
>and I ask anyone interested in re-starting an RUGREENS chapter to please 
>contact me as soon as you can. Thank you.
>                                         ~Ray Higbee
>                                          NJ Campus Coordinator

Post ID:2710
Sender:whcoon@...
Post Date/Time:2002-04-25 22:07:57
Subject:The Green Party not Wasting Resources
Message:

First of all, Mr.Smith, the Green Party is not wasting money on federal and state elections. In 2000, if Ralph Nader has recieved 5% of the popular vote, the Green Party of the United States would have recieved federal money for the 2004 Presidetnal Elections. This would have given the 2004 Presidental Nominee the opptunity to boardcast on Television, Radio, and major Newspapers arguments for incrasing the minimum wage to 11 dollars per hour (what the United States Department of Labor states is the amount needed for a person to live in the United States without health care. 
      Speaking of Health Care, The GPUS would have the oppotunity to raise the issue of Univeral Health Care and Child Care. Arguments could be heard on why and how to clean the air, waterways, and land from short-term and long-term toxic chemicals, and how to replace an economy based on oil to an economy based on renewable energies, such as solar and wind power. 
      Neither President Bush or Al Gore stated that they wished to do this things. Research the NY Times arcivies at your local library to read Bush's or Gore's speeches at their conventions, or on the campaign trails. 

      Now, on the state level. In New Jersey, if a political party recieves 10% of the total general assembly vote, then that party recieves ballot access (i.e. not having to stand in front of supermarkets to get a candidate on the ballot.), and it able to hold primaries if they so desire (21 State Green Parties, including California, New York, Texas, and Minnoseta, have ballot status). This would be a very democratic way for elections to held, a choice between at least three canddiates instead of two, what a wonderful thing!
      
      Finally, there is a Green Party in every state in the USA and in most countries around the world. We have suceeded in gaining seats in German, French, and English parliaments (to name a few). We have had state assemblypersons in California, and will continue to do so among the rest of the states in the great country. If the Democratic Party claims we cost them elections, then their canddiate should be one that makes any Green Party candidate obselete. Please use the non-partasian websites WWW.OPENSECRETS.ORG and WWW.VOTE-SMART.ORG to see how many Democratic candidates are funded, in many cases, by the same money the Republican Party is funded with. I hope you use this knowledge.
                                           Peacefully,
                                                `Ray Higbee





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:2711
Sender:"joseph smith" <can_bush@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-26 00:21:28
Subject:Fwd:UNITY & STRUGGLE  BULLETIN     4 /19/02
Message:

UNITY & STRUGGLE �BULLETIN ����4 /19/02


The Trojan Horse

Communists & REVOLUTIONARY DEMOCRATS understand that there can be no 
socialist revolution without the completion of the Democratic Revolution. 
(See Lenin, Mao). They also know that the Revolutionaries must take the lead 
in the completion of a Democratic Revolution and even when utilizing the 
bourgeois instrument of Electoral Politics, must use it to forward the 
themes, the political lines, the ideological clarity of the revolutionary 
leaders of the Working Class.
For these reasons Revolutionaries running in bourgeois elections never 
consider Only their own candidacy, but take in to consideration the critical 
needs and issues of the working class. If they narrow their view to consider 
Only their own election to a seat, and do not put out the issues and themes 
that affect the whole working class, then they have become somewhat 
politically retarded so that their "insurgency" is reduced to the narrow 
career considerations of the petty bourgeois democrat !
In the Newark elections of May 14, Ras Baraka and in the alliance with the 
Puerto Rican north ward candidate, Hector Corchado, are without a doubt the 
most progressive force in the election. The very political strength and 
democratic leadership that their alliance has projected "Black-Latino Unity" 
draws the entire mass base of the grassroots constituency together, in 
defiance of the bogus "teams" both mayoral candidates have projected which 
excludes both Baraka and Corchado.
This theme is especially relevant and necessary because of the betrayals to 
this unity which were demonstrated in the New York City and Los Angeles 
Mayoral contests where Black & Latino Bourgeois Democratic politicians 
sabotaged that unity so that both Latino Mayoral candidates were defeated 
and so called "moderate" whites �were elected. Bloomberg in NYC spent 59 
million and bought colored quislings on the spot. Hahn in LA using the beard 
of his father's bravery in meeting Dr. King at the airport, and his palm 
greasing of Negro politicians, zig zagged his way into office, and upon 
being elected immediately announced that he was firing the Black Police 
Chief. Now the Negroes are whining, betrayal. But it was their betrayal 
which allowed Hahn's.
In Newark, some people believe that as long as they vote for RAS BARAKA and 
HECTOR CORCHADO, they have fulfilled their progressive obligations so that 
they can covertly vote for the Wall St Trojan Horse, Corey Booker. But this 
is simply a failure to closely examine and analyze the entire meaning of 
this campaign.
On one hand you have Sharpe James, in public office since the Community's 
Choice Campaign of 1970. He is part of the Afro American National 
Bourgeoisie. Always compromising with Corporate Capital, usually shaky in 
confronting the big dogs of government and business. an important operative 
in the Democratic Party, usually self hypnotized by the beauties of his ego, 
never completely honest, manipulative, capable of any trick, betrayal, scam 
one can think of.
Yet he is the national bourgeoisie, as shaky as Chiang Kai Chek, and on site 
representative of the self promoting Tonto politics of the congressional 
black caucus, though there are a few exceptions. But the National 
Bourgeoisie for all its weak wavering dishonest compromise is a flawed but 
actual representative of "Home Rule", a very weak example of this city's 
Self Determination. That it is so weak must also raise questions of the 
weakness of Newark's would be revolutionaries.
Corey Booker, on the other hand, is a Comprador, straight out. He has raised 
earlier, 795,000 from Wall St. (See Star Ledger, NYTimes) and another 
400,000 from New Jersey suburbs! �Now that figure is nearly three million 
dollars! Including contributions from Goldman- Sachs Brokerage, Jack Kemp, 
the National Republican party, &C . With over One Million dollars raised 
from Outside Newark,
It indicates that those are his true sponsors and backers.
In addition, Booker is an active Republican. Yes, the Republicans of Bush, 
Ashcroft, Thomas, Whitman, budget cuts, tax rebates to the corporations, 
Enron, World Trade Center suspiciousness, Afghanistan, Enablers of Sharon's 
Massacre Crusade of the Palestinians, Spy plane over China, Confederate 
Flag, Environmental Terror, Right wing election crooks, &c &C
Booker escorted �Bush 2's Spouse Laura, Republican Senate Candidate Bob 
Franks and the super rightist Gubernatorial candidate Bret Schundler through 
Newark. Booker backs Privatization, Charter Schools, the general Republican 
anti -working class anti -minority anti -immigrant , pro corpora-e Agenda. 
He is quite simply a Trojan horse for the Republican initiative to take 
Newark, now that they have been kicked out of Trenton.
For the people of Newark, a Republican victory would mean the Destruction of 
the Public School System, The Privatization of the businesses and resources 
that will come from the building of the Arena, the privatization of the 
entire so called Newark Renaissance. Ironically, when Booker claims to be 
calling for the benefits of this renaissance to be spread among the whole 
Newark Community not just for Downtown. We must realize Booker Is Downtown. 
A representative of Corporate Republican Interests . They are his Sponsors, 
not the people of Newark!
If Booker's Economic base is Right Wing Corporate , his social base is the 
suburban Yuppies and Buppies who form the majority of his staff. His triumph 
would mean the Elimination of 16,000 jobs from the City Hall Infra structure 
and staffs. These jobs would then be refilled by the suburban white Yuppie 
and Buppie Negro contingent, already easing in with NJPAC, and city hall's 
offices would become almost instantly "foreign" i.e., the other part of the 
middle management largely white college crowd who will also be the �staff 
for the new businesses coming into the city. The young folks who the new 
downtown condominiums are being built!
It is as simple as Home Rule Vs Foreign Domination. �Self Determination Vs 
Corporate Rule! Mao made a United Front with Chiang Kai Chek's Kuomintang 
against the Japanese Imperialists, but when the Japanese were defeated 
Chiang tried to destroy the Revolutionaries led by Mao , but were defeated 
and run out of China.
So that the clear task of Revolutionaries in Newark is to Elect Ras Baraka 
and Hector Corchado, not by copying the Opportunism of the bourgeois 
candidates but putting out a clear Revolutionary Democratic Line. E.g. 
DEMOCRACY & SELF DETERMINATION- 1END STATE TAKEOVER OF EDUCATION-
2RESTORE NEWARK CITIZENS RIGHT TO SPEAK AT CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS- 3COMMUNITY 
CONTROL OF POLICE- 4REDUCE DRUGS AND CRIME BY MASSIVE CAMPAIGN FOR JOBS, 
EDUCATION AND RECREATION- 5 TO MAKE NEWARK'S "RENAISSANCE" CITY WIDE 
&-REBUILD THE ECONOMY - STRESS COOPERATION BETWEEN THE PEOPLE OF NEWARK, 
CITY & STATE AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT, BIG AND SMALL BUSINESS, & INSTITUTIONS 
&C

If the Political Line is �clear & strong enough and distributed broadly with 
the necessary outreach to the community , the grass roots and indigenous 
people of Newark, Ras Baraka's Campaign, as well as the Baraka-Corchado 
Black-Latino Unity ticket, �will be successful. �But the Campaign must be an 
example of Revolutionary Democratic Organization and Mobilization not just 
career building with the present campaign, but as a method of Organizing the 
whole working class for the broader struggle against Imperialism & National 
Oppression. Against War and Rising Fascism!
True Revolutionaries cannot turn their backs on the need to defeat the Right 
Wing Assault. But certainly, Booker will be back in 2006, some analysts 
think that is his real battlefield. That the present campaign is just 
advertising for the real Armageddon, �Booker's backers know that after the 
present Mayor is gone, the next candidate representing Newark's people might 
be an actual Revolutionary.

Post ID:2712
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-26 02:26:08
Subject:Program Friday--Combatting Stereotypes of Arabs in America
Message:

This Friday, the United Muslims Organization and the Islamic Society of
Rutgers University will be co sponsoring a documentary entitled:

" A Nation Terrorized by Stereotypes", Produced by Carlos Ivan Merino.

The program describes mass media images of Arabs and Arab Americans,
revealing stereotypes and bias and emphasizing the possibilities inherent in
moving beyond such stock portrayals.

It will be shown at the Busch Student Center starting at 7pm, Friday, April
26.

Pizza and drinks will be served.

For additonal information please contact  Mansoor Ali Rizvi at
masoomeen@... or 732 254 6965.

                              Charlotte L. Kates
  ckates@... ** ckates@...
 http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

fortunato asks - "Again, which side are you on?"
nbpc has no support for democrats. our objective in elections in which

bush2 & schundler.

>Mr. Smith:
>
>Your emails expose the essentially reformist and even reactionary nature of
>your political line. You have become nothing more than a shill for the
>Democratic Party, although you clothe your support for this ruling class
>Party behind "revolutionary" rhetoric. On the very same day you put out 
>your
>email claiming there are splits in the ruling class concerning support for
>Israel's colonial settler policies, with the Democrats supposedly 
>supporting
>Palestinian rights, the New York Times reported that the American Israel
>Public Affairs Committee was meeting in Washington with leading members of
>both parties attending and "stress[ing] their credentials as friends of
>Israel." This group included DEMOCRAT Tom Daschle, the Senate majority
>leader. While protesters circled the hotel, a banquet was being held inside
>that drew half the Senators, nearly 100 representatives and 26 
>ambassadors."
>(NYT, Wed., April 24).That's Democrats and Republicans, Joe. So, on which
>side does your raggedy line place you?
>
>The House is now about to consider (again) a resolution expressing support
>for Israel and condemning Arafat's "terrorism." Two years ago, Congressman
>Pascrell, who I'm running against, supported a similar resolution, causing
>widespread outrage in the Arab community in Paterson and a demonstration
>outside his office in Paterson. Again, which side are you on?
>
>Also, your email exposes that you measure success by the amount of votes 
>you
>get in losing causes, as in New Brunswick. In that race, you clothed your
>program with the language of "seizing power." Explain to me how you will
>"seize power" this way, even if you win a local office? No, your line 
>merely
>builds illusion. The Greens believe in running for local office and have
>acheived two electoral victories in New Jersey with our line, in Califon 
>and
>in Rutherford. Our outlook is that we need to build an INDEPENDENT 
>political
>movement...independent of both corporate-controlled parties.
>
>Have fun supporting the Democrats. Enjoy it while you can because the
>movement is going to march right past your reactionary political line and
>leave it on the dung heap of history.
>
>Joe Fortunato
>Green Party Candidate for Congress
>8th Congressional District
>




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002

Post ID:2714
Sender:<razer@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-26 13:02:32
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Re: Fwd:Re: No Longer A Green Party Listserve
Message:

Hey Joe,

If you're planning on being a full-time cheerleader for the Democrats
I have a few suggestions for you.

First, join the CP-USA... they've been at it far longer than you. 
Maybe they could give you some pointers in mainstream brown-nosing.

Second, Clinton bombed Yugoslavia, Sudan, and Iraq, expanded NATO,
raised the military budget, and repealed welfare.  Do you have some
reason to believe that his Democratic successor would have an
agenda that differed in the least bit in its goals than, as you
affectionately refer to him, "Bush 2"?

The ends are the same.  I prefer the "honesty" of the Bush 
administration, because at least it is doing its part to mobilize
and unite the opposition, instead of the bastards sitting at home
wondering why the "progressive" president they have elected is 
doing such nasty things.

Someday, you will join your brother in working for some government
floozy (if you're very, very lucky), and the angst that drives your 
politics will subside.  Those people whose convictions are based on 
their moral fiber, and not on post-adolescent anomie, will continue 
to build their organizations.  Not with instant self-gratification 
in mind, but with the thought of a more just and free society for 
their children and grandchildren if not for themselves.

I'm hoping you will unravel sooner than later.  You have polluted
this list and, indeed, the activist community with your hare-brained
rants for long enough.

Chris

Post ID:2715
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-26 20:12:21
Subject:rain on broadway
Message:

N.Y. revue to spotlight Rutgers students

Friday, April 26, 2002

BY BETTE SPERO
Star-Ledger Staff

Whatever Rutgers University's students at the Mason Gross School of the Arts 
in New Brunswick may accomplish in their show business careers, some soon 
can put a Broadway credit at the top of their r�sum�s.

On Sunday, Mason Gross students, along with fellow thespians from
alumni to professors, will present "Rutgers on Broadway" at the Majestic 
Theater in New York.

Their stage setting augurs well -- it's where "The Phantom of the Opera" 
plays (except on Sundays, that
show's day off).

"It's pretty exciting acting on a Broadway stage for the first time,"
says Michael Sorvino, 24, a Mason Gross graduate last year. "I hope it
isn't the last time I act on Broadway."

Sorvino, a Tenafly native, attended Mason Gross at the suggestion of
his father: actor Paul Sorvino. The elder Sorvino studied in New York
with acting coach William Esper, who has taught theater at Rutgers
for the past 25 years.

"It's a straightforward, truly usable acting program -- not a lot of 
baloney," says Michael Sorvino. "You get 'a good box of tools' and come out 
of there knowing how to work. The curriculum is comprehensive, everything 
from stage combat to stage management."

Sorvino said he leaned toward performing an original comic monologue on 
Sunday. He and a Mason Gross classmate, Ivan Sanchez, co-wrote a one-act 
play, "Coffee," for their senior project. "There's a novella in me 
somewhere," says Sorvino.

Esper is directing about 25 Mason Gross students in the 90-minute program of 
scenes from various plays and films. Rain Denise Wilson, who's receiving a 
master's degree in acting from Mason Gross on May 23, is one of them.

Wilson played Titania, queen of the fairies, in Shakespeare's "A Midsummer 
Night's Dream," which Esper staged at Rutgers this season. At the Majestic, 
she will perform a dramatic scene from the film, "Losing Isaiah," and a 
romantic scene from the play, "Jelly's Last Jam."

The actress, a Chicago native in her 20s, describes the master's program at 
Mason Gross as "three long, intense, beautiful years."

"This was the right place," she says. "After coming here, I'm so much more 
ready to get on with the business of acting. Can you imagine starting a 
career on Broadway?"

Esper says he's confident Rutgers fans would fill the 1,500-seat Majestic.

"We're adaptable," he says. "A lot of friends will be in the audience."

Alumni on stage will vary from Kristin Davis, a 1987 graduate who acts in 
the television show "Sex and the City," to Terrell Tilford, a 1998 graduate 
who played David Grant on the CBS daytime drama, "Guiding Light."

Avery Brooks, an illustrious Mason Gross alumnus and teacher, will act a 
scene from "Paul Robeson," Phillip Hayes Dean's drama about another famous 
Rutgers graduate. Brooks did the play in the 1980s at Crossroads Theatre 
Company in New Brunswick and on Broadway.

Brooks' television acting has ranged from playing Hawk on "Spenser: For 
Hire" (with the late Robert Urich) and "A Man Called Hawk" in the 1980s to 
portraying Commander Benjamin Sisko on "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine" in the 
1990s.

George B. Stauffer, dean of Mason Gross, began the practice last year of 
spotlighting Rutgers arts students annually in prestigious professional 
settings in New York. Then, the school's music students gave a sold-out 
concert in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

"Our musicians performed for a packed house. They were a smashing success," 
says Stauffer. "We're equally optimistic this year. This is a chance to see 
future stars of stage and screen begin their professional careers and to 
celebrate artists who already are successful."

Rutgers on Broadway

Where: Majestic Theater, 247 W. 44th St., New York

When: 4 p.m. Sunday

How much: $15-$30. Call (732) 932-7511.







unite the many, defeat the few!

>condescending and abusive is a way to rally support for
>Baraka!.  Especially to people who have said they are
>supporting him!   Surely you can't be that unintelligent.
>
>What needs to be most exposed right now are the  flukes and
>agent provacatuers masquarading around as champions of the people
>whereas their main objective is to cause disharmony and disunity among
>progressive forces where ever they go!
>
>We must remember that there are those who will do anything
>to sabotage the current civil rights and progressive movement
>that is amassing.   And they will use any and all means necessary.
>
>And that includes getting people to pretend they are for
>a progressive movement, but whose actions demonstrate
>that they are only trying to destroy it.
>
>I don't believe for one minute that Joe Smith is supporting
>Ras Baraka!   Only one thing can result from his
>actions -- sabotaging the Baraka campaign.  And that is
>all that his actions are attempting to do!
>He continuously berates any progressive person and any progressive
>group that he can.   And he does this in the Baraka name.
>He is intentionally setting out to disrupt the relationship that POP
>and others have with the Barakas.
>
>POP has worked very closely and very well with the Baraka family
>for a very long time.   (Even more specifically Larry Hamm has.  And I
>might add he's been working with them long before Smith ever came along.)
>I have had many opportunities to hear Ras Baraka speak and he has
>never treated people in the condescending manner that Smith has.
>
>How can you talk about contributing to a people's movement when you
>don't respect PEOPLE? ? ?  DUH?????  You even had the audacity to
>belittle the Faison issue.
>
>Let me remind you of one thing!   You didn't create Baraka!  He and
>his family are the products of Newark!   They are the products of the
>heart, the soul, the spirit, the pain and the life blood of the people
>of Newark and its surrounding communities!   Although I recognize
>that people have been suffering all throughout NJ,  but the progessive
>and civil rights movement in NJ was borne out of Newark!  You are simply
>tailgating off of that!  That's all!
>
>And now you are supposedly inspired enough to come out
>of New Brunswick and to tell  "the Negros" in Newark
>what we should be doing.  You made repeated
>references to "Negros" and "Coloreds" in another of your e-mails.
>You even made a comment about  "whining Negros"
>Quite frankly, I find your using this word
>extremely disdainful.
>
>As you are completely lacking in social skills, let me
>educate you about something.  There are certain unwritten
>social rules.   People within a group will
>make references to themselves in a certain way
>that is acceptable only if you are a member of
>the group.  When people outside of the group make
>those same references about the same group,
>the references have a completely different connotation
>and are unacceptable.
>A White person making a reference about a "redneck"
>has a completely different connotation then when
>a Black person uses the word "redneck."  I've been
>among Italian people, Jewish people, Homosexual people, etc.
>that referred to themselves in ways that I understood
>I could never do because I am not a member of
>that group.
>
>I understood and respected that.  In my e-mails to you
>I never once used any word that anyone would construe
>as being racially offensive.  And neither has anyone
>else on this list serve for that matter.    I don't know where you get
>off thinking you can use any word you like when referring
>to people within a certain ethnic group.  You are not African American
>and you are not on the front line of any of our causes!
>Are you getting my point here?  Are you getting my
>message on this one?
>
>Futhermore, if you were so inspired by the message of Baraka,
>why aren't you in your own community creating candidates to run?
>In the Burbs of New Brunswick, Princeton, East Brunswick, etc.?
>Or better yet, instead of ranting about Newark, why don't you go to South
>Jersey
>and do that?   Why don't you start by earning a sandwich doing
>work in your own community?
>
>That's what NBPC needs to do!   DO THAT!
>RAISE YOUR OWN CANDIDATES IN YOUR OWN
>COMMUNITIES!   Now that would be progressive.
>Did you ever go into South Jersey and try to register a 1000 voters
>and convert them to your way of thinking?  ? ?  I doubt it!
>(Personally I doubt that you even did that in Newark)
>
>
>And as far as telling POP what to do, I have a little difficulty with
>someone telling POP what to do who never has supported POP and
>has never come to a POP meeting.
>
>If you were of any substance and if you intended for your
>so called proposal to have any merit, you would come and speak to POP
>at a meeting face to face with its members and present your proposal
>and your criticisms (or at least your so-called proposal).  Many people
>and organizations have done that.   POP has always been opened
>to people doing that.
>
>No, but you chose not to because your true intentions are not
>to rally support for Baraka at all!  Your actions speak much louder
>than your loud and abusive rantings!
>
>And your spiel about the democratic party and greens are
>so tired.  Your bottom so-called revolutionary message is
>vote democrat regardless of who the candidate is and how horrible
>he has been!    GIVE ME  A BREAK.  That's revolutionary
>way of thinking is stupefying.
>
>One more thing, I am not going to waste any more words or
>breath on you!  Rather, I will put my efforts toward making sure
>that every condescending e-mail that you have sent and will send
>goes to the Baraka camp and his supporters within different
>groups such as the Black Nia Force and the NBPP.
>I think people need to be made fully
>aware of the tactics that people are using in the Baraka name that can
>only harm his campaign.   And your actions show how
>that is your true intention.
>
>
>Lisa Davis
>
>
>
>
>In a message dated 4/25/02 9:20:59 AM Eastern Daylight Time,
>nbpc_2002@... writes:
>
>
> > *******the issue is this**********
> > there is no way for pop, fabw, or the greens to put forward that
> > any work is more important to the struggle for democracy, ie.
> > socialism, that we in new jersey can accomplish, then getting
> > ras baraka elected to newark city council may 14.  my approach
> > & tone aside, everything else can either be combined or wait.
> >
> > debby, it is definitely not my "job" to look up directions, drive over, 
>&
> > stick a sign in your lawn. but if i didn't, who would? it is my DUTY to 
>the
> >
> > struggle for democracy!! that is what the baraka campaign represents; an
> > advance on behalf of the international peoples forces in the struggle 
>for
> > democracy. all those marching in DC did great, but a stronger show of
> > international solidarity is to seize these local governments & our 
>cities
> > institutions.
> >
> > what does that mean "leave it alone, let it be"?
> > it is POP's organizational DUTY to support & elect ras baraka (as an
> > organization! not individuals!), anything less is a betrayal of those
> > struggling right along side you. so no debby, NBPC will not let it be & 
>we
> > will not leave it alone. we will criticize & expose what we see as 
>mistakes
> >
> > in POP & any other organization that claims to represent the people, in
> > order to advance our collective struggle.
> >
> > joe smith
> > new brunswick peoples campaign
> >
> >
> > >From: nasra@...
> > >Reply-To: poprogress@yahoogroups.com
> > >To: poprogress@yahoogroups.com
> > >Subject: Re: [poprogress] B-16 take it personal!!
> > >Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2002 00:16:01 +0000
> > >
> > >Joe, my name is Debby, not Debbie and there is a
> > >difference. It is not POP's job to hand out signs for
> > >Ras Baraka, so let it be. Leave it alone. You just see
> > >that your campaign workers exercise integrity and keep
> > >their word .
> > >
> > >Debby ( spelled with a "y")
