Post ID:3002
Sender:ckates@...
Post Date/Time:2002-10-20 22:02:27
Subject:Fwd: For wide distribution
Message:

Fwd: For wide distribution

Indonesian cleric charged in church bombings 

Officials have linked Abu Bakar Bashir to Al Qaeda terror network 

JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP-CP) -- Indonesia today arrested the spiritual leader of a militant Islamic group suspected in last week's Bali nightclub bombing and blamed the attack on Al Qaeda and its allies in Southeast Asia.

Defence Minister Matori Abdul Djalil said the cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, was linked to Al Qaeda and that his right-hand man, known as Hambali, was behind many of the country's terrorist bombings.

Matori stopped short of accusing Bashir of organizing the Bali attack, but said that it was logical to believe that Hambali, whose real name is Riduan Isamuddin, helped orchestrate them and that Bashir knew about it.

The two men are accused of being leaders of Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda's biggest ally in Southeast Asia.

Hambali is one of the region's most-wanted figures. He is accused of arranging a meeting of two of the Sept. 11 hijackers with other Al Qaeda figures in Malaysia in January 2000 and was behind an alleged plot to blow up the U.S. Embassy and other western targets in Singapore.

"Al Qaeda and its internal network is behind this Bali bomb blast," Matori told a news conference in Bali, a week after bombs tore through a nightclub district and killed at least 183 people and injured more than 300, mostly foreign tourists. Four Canadians were injured in the blast and another is missing.

"A lot of information and the progress of our intelligence work confirm that Hambali is Abu Bakar Bashir's vice-chairman," Matori said. "Hambali is a terrorist from Indonesia. He's always been mentioned by those who did bombings in the past as their commander."

"It is illogical if Abu Bakar Bashir says that he doesn't know about the bombings in Indonesia," Matori said.

Bashir, 64, hospitalized since Friday with breathing problems, is under police guard at the main hospital in his home town of Solo in the western part of Indonesia's main island of Java.

Saturday afternoon, authorities sent police doctors to Solo to determine if Bashir is healthy enough to travel to Jakarta.

"The police don't believe he is sick," said National Police spokesman Gen. Saleh Saaf. "He might be pretending."

Bashir, who runs an Islamic school, has not been named as a suspect in the Bali attacks. His arrest Saturday stemmed from his alleged connection to a spate of church bombings Dec. 24, 2000, in which 19 people died. He has denied involvement in those attacks as well as the Bali bombings.

The carnage in Bali triggered international demands that Indonesia -- the world's most populous Muslim country -- crack down on extremists and militants allegedly linked to al-Qaida.

Warning of the threat of new attacks, Australia urged its citizens to leave Indonesia, saying areas in Jakarta could be hit. The United States, which has evacuated 350 diplomats and dependants, advised Americans to put off travel to the country. The Department of Foreign Affairs in Ottawa issued a similar travel bulletin for Canadians on Friday. People have also been advised to avoid crowded areas frequented by foreigners.

President Megawati Sukarnoputri, slow to act against religious militancy in the past because of Islamic sensitivities, on Friday rammed through emergency measures by decree after months of legislative delay. It was made retroactive to cover those responsible for the Bali bombing.

"After what happened in Bali, Indonesia urgently needs a law to fight terrorism," Justice Minister Yusril Mahendra said.

The decree allows for suspects to be detained initially for three days. With a judge's approval, that can be extended by another six months without charge. Those convicted of carrying out or threatening acts of terror will face prison sentences ranging from four years to life or the death penalty.

The measures will be enforced by the police. Many human rights activists are leery of wider powers for the Indonesian military, which has a long record of brutal abuses. Human Rights Watch warned that the decree could lead to abuses due to the weak judiciary and rampant corruption.

Police Brig.-Gen. Edward Aritonang said in Bali that investigators had questioned 67 people about the nightclub blasts, but said there were no formal suspects.

More than 100 foreign investigators from Australia, the United States, France, Germany and Japan are working in Bali. They expect to reopen the blast site to the public Wednesday.

Bashir is likely to be released from Muhammadiyah Hospital in two days, doctors said. Police officials told reporters that questioning would be postponed until then.

It was unclear what would happen to Bashir afterward, but options include confining him to Solo -- between his home and the hospital -- under police supervision, or taking him to a police hospital in Jakarta.

Several dozen riot policemen were posted at the hospital to prevent Bashir's students from mounting street protests.

Indonesia has been under international pressure to arrest Bashir for months. The government, fearing an Islamic extremist backlash, balked and said there was not enough evidence.

Officials changed their position Friday after a team of Indonesian investigators returned from questioning Omar al-Faruq, an alleged al-Qaida operative in Southeast Asia who was arrested in Indonesia and turned over to the United States in June.

Al-Faruq fingered Bashir as ordering the church bombings, and implicated him in the activities of Jemaah Islamiyah. Bashir said he does not know al-Faruq.

We must not lose sight of our ethics

Indonesian cleric charged in church bombings 

Officials have linked Abu Bakar Bashir to Al Qaeda terror network 

JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP-CP) -- Indonesia today arrested the spiritual leader of a militant Islamic group suspected in last week's Bali nightclub bombing and blamed the attack on Al Qaeda and its allies in Southeast Asia.

Defence Minister Matori Abdul Djalil said the cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, was linked to Al Qaeda and that his right-hand man, known as Hambali, was behind many of the country's terrorist bombings.

Matori stopped short of accusing Bashir of organizing the Bali attack, but said that it was logical to believe that Hambali, whose real name is Riduan Isamuddin, helped orchestrate them and that Bashir knew about it.

The two men are accused of being leaders of Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda's biggest ally in Southeast Asia.

Hambali is one of the region's most-wanted figures. He is accused of arranging a meeting of two of the Sept. 11 hijackers with other Al Qaeda figures in Malaysia in January 2000 and was behind an alleged plot to blow up the U.S. Embassy and other western targets in Singapore.

"Al Qaeda and its internal network is behind this Bali bomb blast," Matori told a news conference in Bali, a week after bombs tore through a nightclub district and killed at least 183 people and injured more than 300, mostly foreign tourists. Four Canadians were injured in the blast and another is missing.

"A lot of information and the progress of our intelligence work confirm that Hambali is Abu Bakar Bashir's vice-chairman," Matori said. "Hambali is a terrorist from Indonesia. He's always been mentioned by those who did bombings in the past as their commander."

"It is illogical if Abu Bakar Bashir says that he doesn't know about the bombings in Indonesia," Matori said.

Bashir, 64, hospitalized since Friday with breathing problems, is under police guard at the main hospital in his home town of Solo in the western part of Indonesia's main island of Java.

"The police don't believe he is sick," said National Police spokesman Gen. Saleh Saaf. "He might be pretending."

The United States, which has evacuated 350 diplomats and dependants, advised Americans to put off travel to the country. The Department of Foreign Affairs in Ottawa issued a similar travel bulletin for Canadians on Friday. People have also been advised to avoid crowded areas frequented by foreigners.

The measures will be enforced by the police. Many human rights activists are leery of wider powers for the Indonesian military, which has a long record of brutal abuses. Human Rights Watch warned that the decree could lead to abuses due to the weak judiciary and rampant corruption.

Police Brig.-Gen. Edward Aritonang said in Bali that investigators had questioned 67 people about the nightclub blasts, but said there were no formal suspects.

More than 100 foreign investigators from Australia, the United States, France, Germany and Japan are working in Bali. They expect to reopen the blast site to the public Wednesday.

Bashir is likely to be released from Muhammadiyah Hospital in two days, doctors said. Police officials told reporters that questioning would be postponed until then.

It was unclear what would happen to Bashir afterward, but options include confining him to Solo -- between his home and the hospital -- under police supervision, or taking him to a police hospital in Jakarta.

Several dozen riot policemen were posted at the hospital to prevent Bashir's students from mounting street protests.

Indonesia has been under international pressure to arrest Bashir for months. The government, fearing an Islamic extremist backlash, balked and said there was not enough evidence.

Officials changed their position Friday after a team of Indonesian investigators returned from questioning Omar al-Faruq, an alleged al-Qaida operative in Southeast Asia who was arrested in Indonesia and turned over to the United States in June.

Al-Faruq fingered Bashir as ordering the church bombings, and implicated him in the activities of Jemaah Islamiyah. Bashir said he does not know al-Faruq.

Subject:Quote of the day from Bertrand Russell
Message:

Quote of the day from Bertrand Russell

Indonesian cleric charged in church bombings 

Officials have linked Abu Bakar Bashir to Al Qaeda terror network 

JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP-CP) -- Indonesia today arrested the spiritual leader of a militant Islamic group suspected in last week's Bali nightclub bombing and blamed the attack on Al Qaeda and its allies in Southeast Asia.

Defence Minister Matori Abdul Djalil said the cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, was linked to Al Qaeda and that his right-hand man, known as Hambali, was behind many of the country's terrorist bombings.

Matori stopped short of accusing Bashir of organizing the Bali attack, but said that it was logical to believe that Hambali, whose real name is Riduan Isamuddin, helped orchestrate them and that Bashir knew about it.

The two men are accused of being leaders of Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda's biggest ally in Southeast Asia.

Hambali is one of the region's most-wanted figures. He is accused of arranging a meeting of two of the Sept. 11 hijackers with other Al Qaeda figures in Malaysia in January 2000 and was behind an alleged plot to blow up the U.S. Embassy and other western targets in Singapore.

"Al Qaeda and its internal network is behind this Bali bomb blast," Matori told a news conference in Bali, a week after bombs tore through a nightclub district and killed at least 183 people and injured more than 300, mostly foreign tourists. Four Canadians were injured in the blast and another is missing.

"A lot of information and the progress of our intelligence work confirm that Hambali is Abu Bakar Bashir's vice-chairman," Matori said. "Hambali is a terrorist from Indonesia. He's always been mentioned by those who did bombings in the past as their commander."

"It is illogical if Abu Bakar Bashir says that he doesn't know about the bombings in Indonesia," Matori said.

Bashir, 64, hospitalized since Friday with breathing problems, is under police guard at the main hospital in his home town of Solo in the western part of Indonesia's main island of Java.

Saturday afternoon, authorities sent police doctors to Solo to determine if Bashir is healthy enough to travel to Jakarta.

"The police don't believe he is sick," said National Police spokesman Gen. Saleh Saaf. "He might be pretending."

Bashir, who runs an Islamic school, has not been named as a suspect in the Bali attacks. His arrest Saturday stemmed from his alleged connection to a spate of church bombings Dec. 24, 2000, in which 19 people died. He has denied involvement in those attacks as well as the Bali bombings.

The carnage in Bali triggered international demands that Indonesia -- the world's most populous Muslim country -- crack down on extremists and militants allegedly linked to al-Qaida.

Warning of the threat of new attacks, Australia urged its citizens to leave Indonesia, saying areas in Jakarta could be hit. The United States, which has evacuated 350 diplomats and dependants, advised Americans to put off travel to the country. The Department of Foreign Affairs in Ottawa issued a similar travel bulletin for Canadians on Friday. People have also been advised to avoid crowded areas frequented by foreigners.

President Megawati Sukarnoputri, slow to act against religious militancy in the past because of Islamic sensitivities, on Friday rammed through emergency measures by decree after months of legislative delay. It was made retroactive to cover those responsible for the Bali bombing.

"After what happened in Bali, Indonesia urgently needs a law to fight terrorism," Justice Minister Yusril Mahendra said.

The decree allows for suspects to be detained initially for three days. With a judge's approval, that can be extended by another six months without charge. Those convicted of carrying out or threatening acts of terror will face prison sentences ranging from four years to life or the death penalty.

The measures will be enforced by the police. Many human rights activists are leery of wider powers for the Indonesian military, which has a long record of brutal abuses. Human Rights Watch warned that the decree could lead to abuses due to the weak judiciary and rampant corruption.

Police Brig.-Gen. Edward Aritonang said in Bali that investigators had questioned 67 people about the nightclub blasts, but said there were no formal suspects.

More than 100 foreign investigators from Australia, the United States, France, Germany and Japan are working in Bali. They expect to reopen the blast site to the public Wednesday.

Bashir is likely to be released from Muhammadiyah Hospital in two days, doctors said. Police officials told reporters that questioning would be postponed until then.

It was unclear what would happen to Bashir afterward, but options include confining him to Solo -- between his home and the hospital -- under police supervision, or taking him to a police hospital in Jakarta.

Several dozen riot policemen were posted at the hospital to prevent Bashir's students from mounting street protests.

Indonesia has been under international pressure to arrest Bashir for months. The government, fearing an Islamic extremist backlash, balked and said there was not enough evidence.

Officials changed their position Friday after a team of Indonesian investigators returned from questioning Omar al-Faruq, an alleged al-Qaida operative in Southeast Asia who was arrested in Indonesia and turned over to the United States in June.

Al-Faruq fingered Bashir as ordering the church bombings, and implicated him in the activities of Jemaah Islamiyah. Bashir said he does not know al-Faruq.

Sender:ckates@...

Subject:Wake up MUllahs in Iran before its too late
Message:

Wake up MUllahs in Iran before its too late

Indonesian cleric charged in church bombings 

Officials have linked Abu Bakar Bashir to Al Qaeda terror network 

JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP-CP) -- Indonesia today arrested the spiritual leader of a militant Islamic group suspected in last week's Bali nightclub bombing and blamed the attack on Al Qaeda and its allies in Southeast Asia.

Defence Minister Matori Abdul Djalil said the cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, was linked to Al Qaeda and that his right-hand man, known as Hambali, was behind many of the country's terrorist bombings.

Matori stopped short of accusing Bashir of organizing the Bali attack, but said that it was logical to believe that Hambali, whose real name is Riduan Isamuddin, helped orchestrate them and that Bashir knew about it.

The two men are accused of being leaders of Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda's biggest ally in Southeast Asia.

Hambali is one of the region's most-wanted figures. He is accused of arranging a meeting of two of the Sept. 11 hijackers with other Al Qaeda figures in Malaysia in January 2000 and was behind an alleged plot to blow up the U.S. Embassy and other western targets in Singapore.

"Al Qaeda and its internal network is behind this Bali bomb blast," Matori told a news conference in Bali, a week after bombs tore through a nightclub district and killed at least 183 people and injured more than 300, mostly foreign tourists. Four Canadians were injured in the blast and another is missing.

"It is illogical if Abu Bakar Bashir says that he doesn't know about the bombings in Indonesia," Matori said.

President Megawati Sukarnoputri, slow to act against religious militancy in the past because of Islamic sensitivities, on Friday rammed through emergency measures by decree after months of legislative delay. It was made retroactive to cover those responsible for the Bali bombing.

"After what happened in Bali, Indonesia urgently needs a law to fight terrorism," Justice Minister Yusril Mahendra said.

The decree allows for suspects to be detained initially for three days. With a judge's approval, that can be extended by another six months without charge. Those convicted of carrying out or threatening acts of terror will face prison sentences ranging from four years to life or the death penalty.

The measures will be enforced by the police. Many human rights activists are leery of wider powers for the Indonesian military, which has a long record of brutal abuses. Human Rights Watch warned that the decree could lead to abuses due to the weak judiciary and rampant corruption.

Police Brig.-Gen. Edward Aritonang said in Bali that investigators had questioned 67 people about the nightclub blasts, but said there were no formal suspects.

Several dozen riot policemen were posted at the hospital to prevent Bashir's students from mounting street protests.

Officials changed their position Friday after a team of Indonesian investigators returned from questioning Omar al-Faruq, an alleged al-Qaida operative in Southeast Asia who was arrested in Indonesia and turned over to the United States in June.

Al-Faruq fingered Bashir as ordering the church bombings, and implicated him in the activities of Jemaah Islamiyah. Bashir said he does not know al-Faruq.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3006
Sender:ckates@...
Post Date/Time:2002-10-20 23:06:38
Subject:israeli nazis, or zionazi pigs and toilet scum
Message:

israeli nazis, or zionazi pigs and toilet scum

A funny thing happened in Iran the other day. The official
Iranian news agency, IRNA, published a poll on Iranian
attitudes toward America, conducted by Iran's National
Institute for Research Studies and Opinion Polls. The poll
asked 1,500 Iranians whether they favored opening talks
with America, and 75 percent said "yes." More interesting,
46 percent said U.S. policies on Iran - which include an
economic boycott and labeling Iran part of an "axis of
evil" - were "to some extent correct." 

Oops! 

You can imagine what happened next. Iran's hard-liners shut
down the polling institute and threatened the IRNA official
who published the results. Never mind. The fact that the
hard-liners had to do such a thing shows how out of touch
they are with Iran's courageous mainstream. 

I relate this incident because it is very useful in
thinking about the task of democratic transition in the
Middle East. The Arab and Muslim worlds today are largely
dominated by autocratic regimes. If you want to know what
it would look like for them to move from autocracy to
democracy, check out Iran. In many countries it will
involve an Iranian-like mixture of theocracy and democracy,
in which the Islamists initially win power by the ballot
box, but then can't deliver the jobs and rising living
standards that their young people desire, so they come
under popular pressure and can only hold on to power by
force. 

But eventually they will lose, because the young generation
in Iran today knows two things: (1) They've had enough
democracy to know they want more of it. (2) They've had
enough theocracy crammed down their throats to know they
want less of it. Eventually, they will force a new balance
in Iran, involving real democracy and an honored place for
Islam, but not an imposed one. 

But why is it taking so long? Why isn't Iran like Poland or
Hungary after the fall of the Berlin Wall? And why might
Iraq not be like them after the fall of Saddam? The answer
is spelled O-I-L. 

The transition from autocracy to real democracy in Iran is
dragged out much longer than in Europe for many reasons,
but the most important is because the hard-line mullahs
control Iran's oil wealth. What that means is that they
have a pool of money that they can use to monopolize all
the instruments of coercion - the army, police and
intelligence services. And their pool of money is not
dependent on their opening Iran's economy or political
system or being truly responsive to their people's
aspirations. 

Think of it like this: There are two ways for a government
to get rich in the Middle East. One is by drilling a sand
dune and the other is by drilling the talents,
intelligence, creativity and energy of its men and women.
As long as the autocratic leaders of Iran, Iraq or Saudi
Arabia can get rich by drilling their natural resources,
they can stay in power a long, long time. All they have to
do is capture control of the oil tap. Only when a
government has to drill its human resources will it
organize itself in a way that enables it to extract those
talents - with modern education, open trade, and freedom of
thought, of scientific enquiry and of the press. 

For all these reasons, if we really want to hasten the
transition from autocracy to something more democratic in
places like Iraq or Iran, the most important thing we can
do is gradually, but steadily, bring down the price of oil
- through conservation and alternative energies. 

I know that Dick Cheney thinks conservation is for sissies.
Real men send B-52's. But he's dead wrong. In the Middle
East, conservation and alternative energies are strategic
tools. Ronald Reagan helped bring down the Soviet Union by
using two tactics: he delegitimized the Soviets and he
defueled them. He delegitimized them by branding the Soviet
Union an "Evil Empire," and by exposing its youth to what
was going on elsewhere in the world, and he defueled them
by so outspending them on Star Wars that the Soviet Union
went bankrupt. In the Middle East today, the Bush team is
delegitimizing the worst regimes as an "axis of evil," but
it is doing nothing to defuel them. Just the opposite. We
refuel them with our big cars. 

Which was the first and only real Arab democracy? Lebanon.
Which Arab country had no oil? Lebanon. Which is the first
Arab oil state to turn itself into a constitutional
monarchy? Bahrain. Which is the first Arab oil state to run
out of oil? Bahrain. 

Ousting Saddam is necessary for promoting the spread of
democracy in the Middle East, but it won't be sufficient,
it won't stick, without the Mideast states kicking their
oil dependency and without us kicking ours.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3007
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-20 23:25:05
Subject:Spam and Forgery
Message:

Hi, everyone!

I apologize to everyone for your misfortune in being on an email list with a
pro-Palestinian activist. Hundreds of activists have been forged, and spam
sent in their names, to numerous Yahoo! groups of which they are a part. As
Yahoo! checks only the content of the "from" line for membership rather than
the actual originating host, it's relatively easy for the forgeries to pass
through.

This article from Wired News gives an overview of the problem:
http://www.wired.com/news/print/0,1294,54708,00.html

This has been an attempt to target pro-Palestinian activists. It usually
occurs on pro-Palestine-only lists, rather than in random places. I
sincerely hope the spammer has had his fun and will not return.

-Charlotte


                                 Charlotte L. Kates
    ckates@... ** ckates@...
                         ckates@...
    http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
http://www.njsolidarity.org/  ** http://www.campus-watch-watch.com/
        Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3008
Sender:ckates@...
Post Date/Time:2002-10-21 00:32:57
Subject:UN report details West Bank wreckage
Message:




The Serial Sniper has had once 

Condom-Lisa-Rise in his viewer 

and he did not shoot her. 

Not because he did not want to 

as much as that he was stunned 

by her ugliness, 

not her very obvious political-ugliness 

but rather her physical one. 



If I were to be a Sniper, 

I would have done a favor to many people 

especially to her husband. 



Before someone accuses me of "Hate-Mail" 

I insist to inform that I am not a "Sniper" 

and that my weapon is not a "gun" 





Back to Mrs. Condom-Lisa-Rice.... 

before anyone accuses me also 

as "Male-chauvinist" 

I ask you , who would ever make love 

to a person with such a face ?? 



Having said that , 

I would still forgive her ugly face 



What bothers me , is exactly , what bothers 

Harry Bellafonte who compared her to the 

"slaves still serving their Masters" 

100 years after Abe Lincoln 

noticed that America needs the Africans. 



I would not go so far as Harry Bellafonte 

but I would suggest that 

the Klux Klux Klan, 

would allow Codom-lisa as member....... 

How ? 

Very easy !! 

once she will wear their "uniform" 

and the "Mask" above her ugly-face 

no one could tell 

how ugly her politics is. 

I guess Colin Powell could also join , as well. 





Finally , I remember some African leader saying 

"Racism has no color" 

I say : 

""Neo-Fascism,Imperialism and Despotism 

also have no color "" 

-------------------------------------------- 

Raja Chemayel 

On the day Saddam showed G.W.Bush that prisoners-amnesty is possible. 

20th October 2002

Post ID:3009
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-21 00:49:24
Subject:Vieques Walk/Lynne Stewart Activity
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is honored to announce that former Puerto 
Rican Political Prisoner DYLCIA PAGAN WILL BE PARTICIPATING IN THE VIEQUES 
WALK-A-THON!!  She will be walking with the Oscar Lopez Rivera Contingent!!

WALK WITH DYLCIA!!  JOIN THE VIEQUES WALK-A-THON OSCAR LOPEZ RIVERA
CONTINGENT!!

Check this page out on Dylcia Pagan and The WALK-a-THON
http://ProLibertadWeb.tripod.com/page16.html

Saturday, October 26th, 2002 at 10am
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is urging all supporters of the struggle 
for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, Vieques and Puerto Rico to join us 
on Saturday October 26th at St. Mary's Church 521 w126th St. between 
Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue at 10am for the VIEQUES WALK-A-THON!!

ProLibertad is organizing an Oscar Lopez Rivera Contingent to the Vieques  
WALK-A-THON in solidarity with the people of Vieques, their valiant struggle 
to remove the US Navy from Vieques and with Oscar Lopez Rivera, who ran a 
500 mile marathon for Vieques behind the walls of his prison, YOU CAN NEVER 
JAIL OR REPRESS THE SPIRIT OF THE REVOLUTIONARY BORICUA!!

Join the Vieques WALK-A-THON and join the Oscar Lopez Rivera Contingent!!

Contact ProLibertad@... to join the Oscar Lopez Rivera contingent 
and To register as a walker, to make a monetary pledge, to work as a 
volunteer or to have your organization become a sponsor, please contact: 
(718)601-4901 (212)348-8004 gee.lee@...,  gerena339@...
________________________________________________________________________

If you are interested in endorsing this activity please email us at
ProLibertad@...

Saturday November 2nd, 2002 at  6:30 PM
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign stands in solidarity with Lynne Stewart!!  
Lynne is a people�s lawyer that has defended the rights of many people; she 
has worked on the legal teams for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners and 
on many other progressive cases!!

Now is the time to support Lynne!!  We cannot allow the state to persecute 
one of our own!!

St. Mary�s Church 521 W126th St. (between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway)Take 
the 1 or 9 to w125th St. and Broadway

Program:
LYNNE STEWART WILL BE SPEAKING
THE SPOKEN WORD OF LOUIS REYES RIVERA
DANIEL VILA OF THE COMMITTEE TO RELEASE FAROUK ABDEL MUHTI

Suggested donation: $10 includes traditional food (No one will be turned 
away for lack of funds)

Sponored by:
La Iglesia San Romero de Las Americas,
El Comite para La Justicia en Chile,
The Vieques Support Campaign
Free Mumia Coalition
El Partido Nacionalista de Puerto Rico
Committee for the Popular defense of Palestine
Venecermos Brigade
THe Malcolm X Grassroots Movement
December 12th Movement
The American Jurist Association
The Committee for the release of Farouk Abdel Muhti

Post ID:3012
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-21 08:23:45
Subject:TO THE MODERATORS: STOPPING THE SPAM
Message:

I've changed my subscribed address to this address. However, these lists
accept email from people who are not members of the lists. The other
affected lists--who accept email only from list members--have seen the spam
stop (I've received bounce messages from the spam they're *trying* to send.)
You can stop the spam on these two lists by setting the lists to *only
members posting*. There's really no reason why someone not a list member
would want to post to it--except to spam it. I've changed this address,
hoping to cause bounces, but so long as nonmembers can post, the spam can
start up again at any time, in anyone's name.

-Charlotte

                                 Charlotte L. Kates
    ckates@... ** ckates@...
                         ckates@...
    http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
http://www.njsolidarity.org/  ** http://www.campus-watch-watch.com/
        Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3013
Sender:ckates@...
Post Date/Time:2002-10-21 12:11:01
Subject:Hi Jaffer
Message:

Terror network growing in Asia, Australia 

SINGAPORE (CNN) --Intelligence officials say that Jemaah Islamiya -- a militant Islamic group suspected of having links to the bombings in Bali as well as recent attacks in the Philippines -- appears to have set up networks throughout Southeast Asia and Australia. 

Though the man alleged to be the group's spiritual leader, radical Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Ba'asyir, has been arrested by Indonesian authorities, intelligence officials say a threat from the group still remains. 

The officials tell CNN they believe Ba'asyir's deputy and operations chief Riduan Isamuddin, also known as Hambali, is still directing operatives across the region from Indonesia. 

Singapore intelligence says Hambali is a long-time al Qaeda member who sits on the shura or consultative council of both al Qaeda and its regional network, the Jemaah Islamiya (JI). 

"The Jemaah Islamiya network is more or less the al Qaeda cell in Southeast Asia," Southeast Asian analysts Zachary Abuza says. 
Regional cells 

Regional intelligence documents obtained by CNN show operational cells, known as mantiqis, have carved out the region: 

Mantiqi 1 covers Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand. 
Mantiqi 2 covers most of Indonesia. 
Mantiqi 3 is the Philippines, Brunei, east Malaysia and Kalimantan and Sulawesi in Indonesia. 
Mantiqi 4 operates in Australia and West Papua. 

However, sources say it is unclear whether the JI cells thought to have been set up inside Australia itself are for logistical support or if they are operational. 

Intelligence sources say they believe the nightclub involved in the Bali bombings was chosen because of the predominance of Australians among its clientele. 

Although he has been placed under arrest, Ba'asyir has not been linked to the Bali blasts, despite authorities' suspicions that his group is linked to the attack. 
Hybrid groups 

Intelligence officials say that three key al Qaeda operatives, working with JI, infiltrated and co-opted homegrown Muslim groups, like the Moro Islamic Liberation Front in the Philippines or Laskar Jundullah in Indonesia. 

"They are plugging into the different extremist organizations in each country which may have its own agenda, but at the same time, they can work together to perpetrate these attacks," Concepcion Clamor from the Philippine National Intelligence Coordinating Agency (NICA) says. 

Regional intelligence sources tell CNN that these hybrid groups account for at least 12 tons of explosives missing in the region -- 4 tons from Malaysia, 4.6 tons in the Philippines and at least 4 tons from Indonesia. 

U.S. intelligence sources tell CNN a Saudi sheikh -- a pseudonym used by Osama Bin Laden -- wired $74,000 to Ba'asyir to purchase several tons of explosives. 

"It is very likely that a portion of that explosives was used to construct the device and the devices that were detonated in Bali," terrorism expert Rohan Gunaratna says. 

Security experts say governments in the region need to work closely together to dismantle this existing network and find the missing explosives. 

If they delay, analysts warn, it will only be a matter of time before the next attack takes place. Find this article at:
http://asia.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/asiapcf/southeast/10/21/seasia.network 

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

to remove the US Navy from Vieques and with Oscar Lopez Rivera, who ran a 
500 mile marathon for Vieques behind the walls of his prison, YOU CAN NEVER 
JAIL OR REPRESS THE SPIRIT OF THE REVOLUTIONARY BORICUA!!

Join the Vieques WALK-A-THON and join the Oscar Lopez Rivera Contingent!!

Contact ProLibertad@... to join the Oscar Lopez Rivera contingent 
and To register as a walker, to make a monetary pledge, to work as a 
volunteer or to have your organization become a sponsor, please contact: 
(718)601-4901 (212)348-8004 gee.lee@...,  gerena339@...
________________________________________________________________________

If you are interested in endorsing this activity please email us at
ProLibertad@...

Saturday November 2nd, 2002 at  6:30 PM
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign stands in solidarity with Lynne Stewart!!  
Lynne is a people�s lawyer that has defended the rights of many people; she 
has worked on the legal teams for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners and 
on many other progressive cases!!

Now is the time to support Lynne!!  We cannot allow the state to persecute 
one of our own!!

St. Mary�s Church 521 W126th St. (between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway)Take 
the 1 or 9 to w125th St. and Broadway

Program:
LYNNE STEWART WILL BE SPEAKING
THE SPOKEN WORD OF LOUIS REYES RIVERA

Post ID:3018
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-25 19:24:59
Subject:Fwd: [TheHubCityNJ] What James Neal had to say
Message:


----Original Message Follows----
From: "mark barry" <mbarry@...>
Reply-To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [TheHubCityNJ] What James Neal had to say
Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 04:00:37 -0000

People, Issues and Politics:  Talks with candidates for New
Brunswick mayor

Drumming to a different beat

Published 10/19/02
New Brunswick Spokesman/The Somerset Spectator

By MARK GRIECO
Staff writer

NEW BRUNSWICK � Even if you don't like his politics, it's
difficult
to not like the man, say some city residents.  He is, as his
campaign literature has assured the voters in four unsuccessful
mayoral elections, "the real deal", and now in his fifth mayoral
bid "the only deal".

He wears his heart on his sleeve, whether he's talking about his
Royal Unique Drill Team and Drum Corp, his blue-collar roots, or the
older cops, white and black, that watched over him as a kid on the
streets of New Brunswick and later mentored him when he joined their
ranks.

This is not a slick politician dispensing sound bytes with a sickly-
sweet smile. This is old-school and occasionally in your face
stuff: "The first order of business is to get rid of this Mayor
(that's one-time baseball teammate Mayor James Cahill)."  Yep, one
hundred per cent bona fide James Neal, 24-7.

"Kids want to get involved, you've got to find a way for them to do
that," he says.  He's talking in reference to his passion, the Royal
Unique Drill Team and Drum Corp, a nationally competing marching
band that he founded and has led for 20 years. "Instead of guns and
drugs, they have band practice. It improves their concentration and
they do better in school."

After some 45 minutes of watching marching band clips on his wide-
screen TV and being shown marching band catalogs,  I began to wonder
when we would talk about politics.  Typically, candidates want to
wow you with their wealth of knowledge of bond issues, housing, land
use planning, etc. � real wonk issues.

That's not Neal, this guy is about matters of the heart; pride,
dignity, community. He'll tell you frankly as mayor he can hire
experts to talk about the day-to-day running of the machinery of the
city.  Micro- management is not his gig, people are.

"A $51 million budget is not that big," he says.   "It just takes a
caring man. I'm people oriented. I'll listen to them. It's what the
people want, not what Neal wants."

A wall of his modest city home � located in a neighborhood rough
enough that he insisted I park my bicycle in his living room instead
of locking it outside � is filled with plaques commemorating his
work with the Uniques and other city youth.

Neal has financially backed the band on what he earns as a city
patrolman.  "My pension and paycheck go to the Uniques," he said.
Other funding comes from the kids asking for donations at the
intersection of Handy Street and Jersey Avenue.  Parents help, but
it's clear the band bears his philosophy.

He believes that given the chance, and some help, people will lift
themselves up from where they're at. Speaking of the kids in the
band  � some 80 kids a year are involved � he said, "It's
amazing.
They'll rise to the occasion if they're supported. Kids need
stability." Arguably, the Royal Unique experience is a model for
what he says he could do as mayor: lift people up.

A Mayor Neal?

Asked what a typical day in the life of a Mayor Neal would be like,
he's short on details of policy and comes back to what he believes
he knows best: people.

"I would be the best mayor," he said. "People would walk with their
heads up because they know I care."

This goes beyond being merely chipper, this is almost a spiritual
happiness he's talking about. "We'd have a world class city, not
just materially, the soul would be better."

He added, "I'd be busy helping folks... trying to get them jobs, a
place to stay, encouraging them to be better students."

The chance to build a shining city upon the hill, or in this case on
the banks of the Raritan, has eluded him four times � this is his
fifth run for mayor.  Conventional political wisdom would probably
say, "Give it up, already."

Critics have also said that once again, Neal's ticket � this time
it's Danny Rosado and Joe Smith for council against incumbents
Blanquita Valenti and Joseph Egan � will be splitting the anti-
incumbent vote.

Another independent ticket � mayoral candidate Keith Thomas is
challenging incumbent Mayor James Cahill, and council candidates
Benjamin Rivera and Kelley Stephenson round out Thomas's ticket �
have been grabbing the headlines lately with their rent leveling
petition and class action suit involving the mayor.  If controversy
is an indication of voter support, Thomas's ticket could well be the
front running challengers, say observers.

Already a political career

Neal is unfazed.  He's out-lived, politically speaking, other
challengers to Cahill , who accepted the torch of Democratic
leadership passed to him from the legendary Mayor John Lynch.  Neal
is the perennial challenger;  always losing, but always fighting.
He rattles off the names of people that have challenged the regular
Democrats, lost, then eventually dropped out of sight: Dave
Meiswinkle, Tom Clark, Mike Shapiro.

He doesn't mention them, but the list of council challengers �
the
regular Democrats have yet to lose a council seat in most residents'
life time � is certainly even longer and the names escapes most
residents' memories.

"I haven't failed, I've gained," says Neal. "Other people," he
claims as he shows me campaign literature from around the state,"
have stolen my ideas."

He adds,"I'm the one that can beat Cahill. I don't see Keith Thomas
as a threat. That's their [Thomas's slate] right to run. But if they
were sincere, they'd be behind me."

There's no doubt in his head who should be the front running
challenger: "I'm a legitimate candidate.  I've gotten votes. I've
been consistent for the last 16 years."

"Commitment is the key. My wife and I [Deborah] are committed to the
city," he said. "I'm out to win this election."

Neal, often animated and streetwise, has been around this city his
whole life. But he gets quiet, emotional, talking about his parents.
His dad was a truck driver and his mother was a domestic servant for
a family in Metuchen. They were a deacon and deaconess at their
church.  Mets fans, too.

Days gone by

Born and raised in the city, Neal remembers the days before the
nation's civil rights period.  The site where the Foodtown on
Livingston Avenue now sits was once a city swimming pool...for
whites only.

A star athlete at New Brunswick High School, and an African-
American, he often looked longingly at the pool as he walked home
from practice. When civil rights advances enforced African-
Americans' right to enter the pool, he claims it was promptly
demolished and a new one built in Milltown, then a virtually all-
white town.

According to Neal, not much is different today for city residents.
He points to what he describes as a failing school system, poor
housing, drugs on the city's streets � "all the major components
that rate a city" � and contends "little has changed."

He said, "If you look at the things that matter, the taxpayers will
agree with me."

Neal claims that most of the city's cops, firefighters, and
teachers, live outside the city.  That's something he would try to
change. "I'd provide grants for them to own homes in the city. If we
can give tax abatements to wealthy developers, we can give residents
respect and do the same," he says.

The city's police have been a major influence in his life. "I knew
all the cops as a kid, black and white. I guess that's why I'm one
now," says Neal, who has over 25 years on the force. "Older cops
inspired me to care about people.  If I was mayor, the Juvenile Aid
Bureau would be as important as the patrol division."

Anyone in the game as long as Neal has taken a few hits and had some
good days, too.  Asked about a personal low point, he gives me one
about the city as a whole: "I see the city continuing down the road
for the rich and the special interests and not for people that have
been living here for years."

High point? "Being there, bringing issues to the city. Putting a
smile on somebody's face when you're trying to help them. You try to
make a difference and they appreciate it."

If he should lose, then what?  "There's other races we can run like
freeholder ... assembly," he says.

Critics might point out that it would be difficult to see how after
losing several city races, he could be a viable candidate for larger
office.  Again, he is unfazed by what some might say is practical
politics.

"I'm older, my ego is not in this, my heart is."

-----

http://resourcecenter.msn.com/access/plans/default.asp

Post ID:3019
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-26 20:40:23
Subject:Baraka's son to attend rally in New Brunswick, home news tribune
Message:

Baraka's son to attend rally in New Brunswick

Published in the Home News Tribune 10/26/02
By SHARON WATERS
STAFF WRITER

NEW BRUNSWICK: Newark Deputy Mayor Ras Baraka, son of the state's poet 
laureate, will attend a People's Campaign rally today and decide whether to 
endorse the slate of independent candidates.

The rally will be held today at Feaster Park on Throop Avenue from 1 to 3 
p.m. The People's Campaign ticket includes mayoral candidate James Neal and 
City Council candidates Danny Rosado and Joe Smith.

Baraka is the son of New Jersey's poet laureate Amiri Baraka, who made 
headlines recently when some lines in one of his poems were viewed as 
anti-Semitic. The father rebuffed the governor's request to resign.

Smith supported Baraka in his run for Newark City Council, as did members of 
New Brunswick United, a second set of independent candidates. Both groups 
want Baraka's endorsement.

Keith V. Thomas, mayoral candidate with New Brunswick United, said his 
campaign would like to be endorsed by Baraka but won't push the issue. 
Thomas is running with council candidates Benjamin Rivera and Kelley 
Stephenson.

"I intend to come down there and see what's going on," said Ras Baraka about 
the rally.

The independents face Democratic incumbents Mayor Jim Cahill and council 
members Joseph V. Egan and Blanquita Valenti.

"The people of New Brunswick are the ones who will decide this election, not 
a politician coming in from Newark," said city spokesman Edward Bray.




unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:3023
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-10-27 15:08:46
Subject:why wont cahill debate?
Message:

New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign 2002

Why Won�t Cahill Debate?

To the Editor:

New Brunswick Mayor James Cahill says he has no time to debate challenger 
James Neal before the November 5 election.  This must be because Cahill 
knows how long it would take to explain his corrupt, backward 
administration.

Corporate slogans and glossy brochures don�t take much time for Mayor 
Cahill, but how would he quickly answer �Why was the mayor a key character 
witness for convicted pimps, James Marshall and Marco Chinchilla, who held 
high rank on his police force?�  Testimony shows one of their brothels was 
on Paterson St., around the corner from Cahill�s City Hall.

Cahill must not have been so pressed for time that day in court, but it 
might take a minute to explain �Why did his appointed police chief, Michael 
Beltranena, quit the force within a month of the guilty verdict, to take a 
job in Montgomery?�  �Why did his police force offer a $10,000 reward for 
the capture of a fabricated Young Black Male suspect, after dirty 
detectives, Marshall and Chinchilla, staged a Remsen Ave. neighborhood 
shoot-out, in order to file for early retirement to avoid their prostitution 
prosecution?�

Cahill must not have time to explain why his appointed board of education 
produces the worst test scores in Middlesex County, with only 12% of Lincoln 
School 4th graders passing their recent statewide proficiency tests, and 
only 51% of New Brunswick High School 11th graders passed the HSPT, required 
for graduation.

Cahill may need time to explain why his aides, like Kevin Jones, pay 
cut-rate rents in Renaissance Apartments, while Cahill�s tenants paid 
illegally inflated rents, and most of the former residents of the demolished 
Memorial Homes projects still have a memory, but no homes, in New Brunswick.

It may disturb Cahill�s busy schedule to explain how many of his proclaimed 
�new jobs� are the temporary, minimum wage grinds of undocumented 
immigrants, with no voting rights, security, benefits, or health care.

Why is there no school band to support the undefeated Zebra football team?  
How can $100+ million be found to build a corporate tower at Monument 
Square, while premiere Crossroads� Theater is vacated from its lease across 
the street? How come the fabulous city superstar, Jaheim, will have a #1 
album, �Still Ghetto�, release on election day, but he is not promoted by 
the city? Why is there no Women�s Center in the city? Why is there no public 
pool?

The Douglass College Government Association will sponsor a debate at 8:00 
pm, Wednesday, October 30, in the Douglass Student Center.  James Neal will 
be there to openly address the concerns of the community.  Will James Cahill 
be watching the clock?

Cliff Smith, campaign manager
James Neal, Danny Rosado, Joe Smith
New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign 2002

732.214.8828
39 Throop Ave. #1
New Brunswick, New Jersey 08901



unite the many, defeat the few!

Subject:REMINDER: Penny Rosenwasser/The Face of Re-Occupation/Tomorrow/New Brunswick!
Message:


NJ Solidarity Proudly Presents
PENNY ROSENWASSER

The Face of Occupation

Penny Rosenwasser spent 3 weeks in July doing solidarity actions with peace activists in Israel and Palestine, visiting and photographing unforgettable people and places in the region. She will present a slideshow and discussion revealing the quality of life under the occupation and the efforts of activists seeking peace and justice. Penny Rosenwasser is Assistant Director of the Middle East Children's Alliance and author of "Voices from a 'Promised Land': Palestinians and Israeli Peace Activists Speak Their Hearts." 

Tuesday, October 29: 7PM: New Brunswick Public Library

Flyer can be found at: http://www.pegasus.rutgers.edu/~ckates/penny.doc
please distribute widely! 

For more information please contact New Jersey Solidarity at info@... or visit our website at www.njsolidarity.org

Post ID:3031
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>

Subject:REMINDER: Norman Finkelstein in New Brunswick Monday Nov 4
Message:

Please forward!

New Jersey Solidarity is proud to present NORMAN FINKELSTEIN, author of
Image and Reality of the Israel-Palestine Conflict, The Rise and Fall of
Palestine, A Nation on Trial and The Holocaust Industry: Reflections on the
Exploitation of Jewish Suffering.

Finkelstein, a radical and incisive critic of the politics of the Israeli
state, the Zionist movement, and the so-called 'peace process', will speak
Monday evening in the Douglass College Center at Rutgers University in New
Brunswick. For more information about Norman Finkelstein, visit his website,
www.normanfinkelstein.com.

Norman Finkelstein
Whither the 'Peace Process'?
Monday, November 4
7:00 PM
Trayes Hall B
Douglass College Center
100 George Street
New Brunswick, NJ
Questions? More information? See www.njsolidarity.org or email
info@...

Sponsored by New Jersey Solidarity, Rutgers Association for Middle East
Justice, Rutgers College Cultural Affairs Program Council, Caellian, LABIA,
Women's Defense Coalition, and the Islamic Society of Rutgers University.

New Jersey Solidarity is a grassroots organization dedicated to resistance
and action in support of the Palestinian people's right to national
liberation, human rights, freedom and self-determination.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3032
Sender:<chief315@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-11-05 23:57:19
Subject:Re: Israel goes on collective punishment rampage
Message:

NetCloak 3.2.3f
2:40 PM, 11/5/02

You may think you know what happened on Jan. 3, when Israeli Navy Seals seized the Karine A, a cargo ship carrying 50 tons of contraband Katyusha rockets, anti-tank missiles, mortars, mines, explosives, and sniper rifles.

You may think the ship's captain acknowledged on TV that he is a Palestinian Authority (PA) employee acting under military orders, that he was dispatched to the Iranian shoreline to load the arms onto his ship. You may think he was heading to the waters off Gaza to release the arms in watertight cases for a pick-up by small Palestinian boats.

If you thought this, you would be in good company. "Unequivocal" was how Israel's chief of staff called the evidence of this being a PA smuggling operation. Condoleezza Rice, the U.S. national security advisor, said her government "seriously suspects" PA Chairman Yasser Arafat himself knew about the shipment. And Arafat, while denying personal culpability, acknowledged that his officers were implicated in the scheme.

But the Middle East media knows better. "The story of the arms ship is but a licensed fabrication by Israel," announces the editor-in-chief of the Egyptian government's daily, Al-Akhbar.

Saudi media agree that the episode was a hoax, with Arab News calling it "an elaborate trap" and Ar-Riyadh alleging that it "was necessary to fabricate the ship story" to implicate other Arab and Muslim countries as sponsors of terrorism. Qatar's Ash-Sharq interpreted it as an Israeli "pretext for more oppression and terrorism against the Palestinians" and a story that "no sane person can believe."

In other words, Middle Eastern media engaged in a bald, flat-out, and blatant denial of reality.

This fits into a well-established and important pattern. The home-video showing Osama bin Laden smirking as he described the devastation at the World Trade Center struck many Muslims as a fake. "I think this recording is forged . . . I don't believe this tape is authentic," announced Muhammad Salih, a Saudi religious figure.

The head of Jordan's Islamic Action Front, 'Abd al-Latif 'Arabiyat agreed: "Do the Americans really thing the world is that stupid to think that it would believe that this tape is evidence?"

Hani Siba'i of the Egyptian Islamic Jihad accused the Pentagon of using technology to simulate bin Laden's laugh. "It's a fake," he told Al-Jazeera. "The Americans fabricated it."

Muhammad Rizieq of the radical Indonesian Defenders Front called the tape "U.S. propaganda to cover up their war crimes in Afghanistan."

Of course, the Muslim world also refused responsibility for the attacks on Sept. 11: Gen. Hameed Gul, former head of Pakistani intelligence, deemed Israeli and U.S. agents "the obvious culprits. . . . This was clearly an inside job."

The father of Mohamed Atta, the alleged ringleader of the 9/11 attacks, completely refused to acknowledge his son's complicity, calling the evidence "a farce . . . a forgery, a fabrication."

Such willful denial is not new. Just last year, Iraqi Defense Minister Lt.-Gen. Sultan Hashim Ahmed declared that because the U.S. government did not accomplish its goals in the 1991 Kuwait war, it had "lost the war," a sentiment shared by many in the region.

Likewise, the Egyptian government claimed victory over Israel in the October War of 1973 - and even built a museum dedicated to this fantasy. One Egyptian diplomat acknowledges, "I never knew we lost the war until I was 26." As his experience suggests, these lies are so often repeated that they become widely believed.

This pattern of avoiding unpleasant facts offers an insight into the problems of Muslim society. Turning defeat into victory, evidence into forgery, and terrorism into an "inside job" creates an alternate and more hospitable world.

But this denial avoids problems rather than dealing with them. Not acknowledging who carried out the 9/11 atrocities, for example, means ignoring its many causes, from a radicalized school curriculum to the use of Islamic "charities" for money-laundering.

Part of the U.S. war on terrorism, therefore, has to be working with Muslim governments and pressing them to face reality. This will not be easy, but so long as they remain in denial, the stage is set for fresh disasters.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3033
Sender:Charlotte Kates <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-11-06 12:22:44
Subject:SPEAK OUT AGAINST RACISM ON CAMPUS!
Message:

PLEASE MEET TONIGHT! November 6, 2002 - 9:00 PM -- 4th Floor S-Lounge--
Rutgers Student Center-- College Avenue Campus--New Brunswick, NJ

OUR VOICES MUST BE HEARD!

Please forward!

Friends,

On Monday November 4. 2002, the Daily Targum, Rutgers University Campus
paper, published a racist advertisement attacking Palestinians ( In order to
see the advertisement please go to:
<http://www.eden.rutgers.edu/~ckates/t1mtg.doc>
http://www.eden.rutgers.edu/~ckates/t1mtg.doc.)

New Jersey Solidarity ( www.njsolidarity.org <http://www.njsolidarity.org> )
will launch an ad campaign in the targum in order to:

1. Condemn the Targum for allowing racist ads to run
2. To educate students on the topic by providing informative, factual ads
such as UN resolutions, Amnesty international PR's, etc.

New Jersey Solidarity needs your help. In order to purchase space in the
Targum we will need donations from the community. Please help us fight
racism on campus,  in our community, our country and in the world . You can
make your donations online :

https://www.paypal.com/xclick/business=info%40njsolidarity.org
<https://www.paypal.com/xclick/business=info%40njsolidarity.org&item_name=NJ
+Solidarity%3A+College+Campus+Campaign&return=http%3A//www.njsolidarity.org&
cancel_return=http%3A//www.njsolidarity.org&cn=Comments%3A>
&item_name=NJ+Solidarity%3A+College+Campus+Campaign&return=http%3A//www.njso
lidarity.org&cancel_return=http%3A//www.njsolidarity.org&cn=Comments%3A
<https://www.paypal.com/xclick/business=ssharaf74%40msn.com&item_name=New+Je
rsey+Solidarity+-+Campus+Campaign+Fund>


Additional information:

ANTI-ARAB RACISM: The Last Acceptable Bigotry?
This advertisement appeared in the Daily Targum, the daily newspaper of
Rutgers University, on Monday, November 4, 2002. Posing as counterpoints the
alleged "heroes" of Israeli and Palestinian children, the advertisement
demonizes and dehumanizes the Palestinian people. In its association of
militancy and militarism solely with Palestinians (ignoring the ubiquity of
the Israeli army, the fourth-most-powerful in the world), it dramatically
misrepresents the Israel-Palestine conflict.

Beyond those political distortions, however, lies the real danger of this
advertisement. It is not merely a bit of pro-Israeli sloganeering. Rather,
it is an overtly racist attack upon the Palestinian people, young and old,
portraying them as somehow internally prone to violence and hatred--and
clearly inferior to Israelis, who are portrayed as instinctually heroic,
happy and positive.

The advertisement does not merely put forth a political perspective. It
demonizes Palestinians and seemingly exposes an inherent inferiority and
propensity to violence on the part of Palestinians. Even the youngest,
most innocent Palestinian--the school child--is demonized as nothing
morethan a future gunman. In the view of this advertisement, only some lives
are precious--and none of those are Palestinian. Rather than recognizing
common humanity, criticizing a political system, action or law, this
advertisement classifies all Palestinians as dangerous terrorists, whose
lives are not worth protecting--after all, every Palestinian will
inevitably grow into a life of violence. In its depiction of what is
clearly a "superior" race or ethnic group, and an "inferior" group, this
advertisement is blatant racism. Unlike student articles and commentaries,
which may raise issues of freedom of speech, this racist advertisement is
a paid promotion for anti-Arab racism. While we pay Targum fees on our
term bill every semester, the Targum should not be seeking profit in the
promotion of racism, bigotry and hatred.

The Daily Targum should NOT profit from racism! DEMAND AN APOLOGY!
WRITE:
The Daily Targum
126 College Ave, Suite 431
New Brunswick, NJ 08901
CALL:
(732)932-7051
EMAIL:
opinions@...
To aid this campaign, contact:
NEW JERSEY SOLIDARITY
 info@...
 <http://www.njsolidarity.org/> http://www.njsolidarity.org/

Post ID:3035
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-11-07 19:07:41
Subject:Justice for Palestine: Diana Buttu in Newark November 15
Message:


  NJ Solidarity Proudly Presents

Diana Buttu 
Legal Adviser to the Palestine Liberation Organization 

"Why a Fair Settlement is Essential to Peace 
Throughout The Middle East " 

Friday, November 15th 
4:00 p.m. 
Center for Law and Justice - Room 090 Rutgers 
Newark Law School * 123 Washington Street * Newark, NJ 
Free Admission - SEATS ARE LIMITED - PLEASE ARRIVE EARLY!

For directions and/or more information please contact: info@... or visit our website: www.njsolidarity.org
  Diana Buttu is a legal advisor to the negotiations support unit of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Since October 2000 she been an influential part of the Palestinian team in negotiations with Israel. She is a passionate and informed advocate for a just, honest, and peaceful solution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. 

  Ms. Buttu offers insightful analysis of the current political crisis and the humanitarian disaster facing Palestinians.  She will speak from first hand experience of the struggle of Palestinians for freedom and statehood. 

  Ms. Buttu lives in Ramalla. She is editor of the Palestine Yearbook of International Law and a member of the Ontario Bar. She previously served as legal council to the Canadian Department of Justice in Ottowa.  She received a B.A. and an LL. M from Stanford University; a J.D. from Queen's University in Ontario, and a J.S.M from Stanford University.  Currently she is pursuing a doctoral degree in Law and Refugee Compensation from Stanford Law School. She is frequently quoted as an authority on the Palestinian perspective in such new sources as MSNBC, CNN and the Washington Post. 


Co-sponsored with Rutgers Student Lawyers Guild and American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee


                                 Charlotte L. Kates
    ckates@... ** ckates@...
                         ckates@... 
    http://www.ruwomenscenter.org/  ** http://www.offlines.org
http://www.njsolidarity.org/  ** http://www.campus-watch-watch.com/
        Practice organized resistance and conscious acts of solidarity!

Post ID:3038
Sender:Charlotte Kates <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-11-08 14:00:17
Subject:Upset about Targum Racism?
Message:

The _Daily Targum_ has, thus far, refused to apologize for printing the
racist advertisement on page 11 of the Monday, November 4 issue. When
confronted, the editorial staff and the business staff have referred
concerned students and community members to each other. We demand
accountability!

Advertisements may clearly be distinguished from student commentaries--and
while the Targum edits and rejects student commentaries, it applies a
principle of free speech seemingly only when that speech is *paid* speech.
Our communities deserve not only an apology for the racist advertisement,
but equal space--free--to raise our concerns about racism in the Targum,
at the university, and in our society. The rights of speech should not
belong to those who have the money to pay for it. For more information on
the racist advertisement, please see the Action Alert at
http://www.njsolidarity.org

As the Targum has been unresponsive, we must contact University
administration. Please contact Dr. Dennis' office and tell them that you
are concerned and upset about _Targum_ racism! Dr. Dennis has been
receptive to student concerns in the past. Please let him know how you
feel about racism!
 *** Emmet A. Dennis   (edennis@...) 732-932-8576

    -slavery and resistance to slavery in the Northeast
